video_title: Robert Treat Paine

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Let me tell you a war story that begins not on a battlefield, but on a city street. March 1770, Boston.  The air sharp with tension. Five are dead in the snow. The Boston Massacre. I am Robert Treat Payne, patriot, son of Massachusetts, and attorney who stood to prosecute the Redcoats who fired into the crowd. My opponent, John Adams. Two future signers. One courtroom. One question. To whom does the law apply? We tried them fairly. Some were acquitted. Some found guilty.  The trial didn't end the trouble, but it proved the colonies could hold themselves to justice. That was the beginning. For a time, I believed peace might hold. Then came Lexington, and conquered. Our hearts are full, our hands are full, I wrote. May God, in whom we trust, support us.  July 4th, 1776. Cool. That's all I wrote in my diary that day. Not for a lack of feeling, but because the moment left no room for embellishment. After the Congress, I returned home to become Massachusetts Attorney General. I prosecuted traitors, rioters, and slavers alike. I took part in a case, Commonwealth v. Jennison, that helped make our state the first to abolish slavery.  We didn't declare freedom to let it be rationed. And that's the story. No statues, no swords. Just paper, ink, and resolve. In the birth of this nation, I was not the loudest voice. But I was one of the clearest. And I hope in your time, you'll still hear it.

summary.SPEAKER_00: Robert Treat Payne recounts his experiences as a patriot and attorney during the American Revolution. He emphasises his role in the Boston Massacre trial, his belief in colonial justice, his involvement in abolishing slavery, and his modest reflection on signing the Declaration of Independence.
summary.high_level_summary: The speech recounts the life of Robert Treat Payne, a patriot and attorney involved in pivotal American Revolutionary events. Payne highlights his role in prosecuting British soldiers in the Boston Massacre, his efforts to uphold justice in the colonies, and his contributions to abolishing slavery in Massachusetts.

video_title: President Trump Participates in a Dinner with the Prime Minister of the State of Israel

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03

And I think it will only go on to be even greater success in the future. So it's really nice to have you at the White House.  And it's great to have you both and all of your wonderful people, Ron. We've worked together for a long time. We've done well together. And we had a great — we had a great time. I would say it's a lot of work, but we had a great result recently. And we're going to have a lot of great results. So it's great to have you.

We have great opportunities. The President has an extraordinary team, and I think our teams together make an extraordinary combination to meet challenges and seize opportunities. But the President has already realized great opportunities. He forged the Abraham Accords. He's forging peace as we speak.  in one country, in one region after the other. So I want to present to you, Mr. President, the letter I sent to the Nobel Prize Committee. It's nominated you for the Peace Prize, which is well-deserved, and you should get it.

Well, we're gonna just make it as comfortable as possible for  the state of Texas, they have a great governor, they have wonderful senators, they have wonderful representatives, and we're going to work together with them. Well, I think it's terribly unfortunate. Terribly unfortunate. We were just talking about it, how tragic it is. We're always subject to negotiate something that's fair, but we've talked to most of the countries and pretty much they've had their way for many, many decades, as you know.  And it was time that we just wanted fairness. This is not really equitable from our standpoint, because it's just a small token by comparison to the damage that's been done over the years. But we had no other president that was willing to do this. I did it in my first term with China and others. We took in hundreds of billions of dollars of tariffs. No inflation. The most successful  period of time that we've ever had financially in the country. The first term, I think this term is going to be much better, even much better than that. That was the best ever, and this is going to be, I think, substantially better. And we're on the way to doing that. We've already taken in over $100 billion worth of tariffs, and we haven't even started. And all I say to the other countries is, you know, some of them wanted to make a deal and wanted to be fair. Others perhaps got a little bit spoiled. They were a little bit spoiled because for 30, 40 years, 50 years, they were  Taking advantage of the country. So we're gonna I would say the final but if they call with a different offer if I like it I would say I would say firm but not a hundred percent firm if they call up and they say I  would like to do something a different way. We're going to be open to that. But, essentially, that's the way it is right now.

And those who – and I think we're getting close to finding several countries, and I think this will give, again,  the freedom to choose. Palestinians should have it.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03

Are we in the last chapter of closing out peace amongst this conflict now and all the others that you've worked on? Well, I hope so. Look, we did a job with India and Pakistan and Serbia, Kosovo, Rwanda and the Congo. And this was all over the list.  Three weeks or so, Marco, right? We did — and others that were ready to fight. And we stopped a lot of fights. I think a very big one, frankly — a very, very big one — was India and Pakistan. And we stopped that over trade. We're dealing with India and we're dealing with Pakistan. And we said, We're not going to be dealing with you at all if you're not — if you're going to fight. And they were maybe at a nuclear stage at both — you know, nuclear powers.  And I think something that was very important. We're trying to help out with a Biden-created monster, this whole thing that's happening with Russia and Ukraine. It's a horrible — it's a horrible thing. And I'm not happy with President Putin at all.  But this is something that would have never happened if I were President. This is a war that was never going to happen. Go ahead, Brian. The Press I was going to say, if I was going to address your critics, that in the election, they called — they said that you would cause the next World War III. And, in fact, you're suffering all the while. The President I'm stopping wars. I'm stopping wars. And I hate to see people killed. Like, as an example, Ukraine and Russia — they're not Americans that are being killed. They're not Israeli that are being killed. They're — these are all Russians.  And all Ukrainians. And — but it's 5,000. Maybe 7,000 last week. 7,500 last week. Mostly soldiers. But people in towns and cities that are getting hit. But mostly — death is mostly soldiers. Now — so they don't come from here, but it's 7,000 last week — souls. And if I can stop that. You know, they have parents, and they have sisters and brothers, and getting married, and —  Who knows? They're just people, but they're souls. And if I can stop a war, you know, because I have an ability to do so. I'm disappointed, frankly, that President Putin hasn't stopped. I'm not happy about it either. We have scheduled Iran talks and they want to talk. They took a big drumming. I think when we hit the  The three sites, really, I would say the three sites, not just the one. The one was a big one, and it was deep in granite, and it was obliterated. It turned out the Atomic Energy Commission said it is obliterated. I just want to take our hats off to those incredible flyers, the people that flew that big machine.  The mechanics and everybody else, they had zero. They flew for 37 hours with zero problem mechanically. I mean, when you think in carrying the biggest bombs ever.  The biggest bombs that we've ever dropped on anybody, would you think? Non-nuclear. And we want to keep it non-nuclear, by the way. But they did a phenomenal job. It was an amazing job. And I think that was — I was talking to Bibi about it before. That was the very beginning of the end. It ended very quickly after that. I don't want to say what it reminded me of, but if you go back a long time ago, it reminded people of a certain other event.  Harry Truman's picture is now in the lobby in a nice location, not in the lobby where it should have been, but that stopped a lot of fighting.  And this stopped a lot of fighting. When that happened, it was a whole different ballgame.

And, you know, we were — at the end, 14 missiles were shot.  And every single missile was shot out of the air. It was pretty amazing. And that was sort of the end. One o'clock, they said, would you like to make it later?  He said, no, let him come at one o'clock. And at one o'clock, everybody was, as you know, over 5000 people left the base. And we had three gunners and three assistants. And out of the 14 that was shot, all 14 were knocked down. And that was the end. That was about it. And we had a  We had a rough time, but sometimes — you know, sometimes you need the rough time in order to get — I think — I think things are going to be really settled down a lot in the Middle East. And they respect us and they respect Israel. They respect a lot of things that took place. Nobody has ever seen equipment like what we sent over to knock out those sites. But when those sites were knocked out, it essentially — that was — that was the end.

And we'll work out a peace in which our security, the sovereign power of security, always remains in our hands. Now, people will say it's not a complete state, it's not a state, it's not that. We don't care. You know, we vowed never again, never again is now. It's not going to happen again. Oh, well, look, I'm going to come there with President Trump.  And we'll see what the, how do you know who the mayor will be? I don't know that.

And that is a message that the President sent to everyone on the planet. And it is a message that will resonate toward a matter of peace, the likes of which I don't think we've ever seen. So, thank you.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: The biggest tax cuts ever. No tax on tips. No tax on Social Security. Don't think of it. No tax on overtime.  From a business standpoint, the jobs are coming in like we've never seen them before. As soon as that was signed, there were nine factories that announced that they were building the one-year deductibility. You know, things that, from a business standpoint, you'd understand. The jobs that are being created. And one of the things that is — and this is also that, but it's also because of the tariffs. It's a tremendous success. We're taking in hundreds of billions of dollars in tariffs.  And one of the things that is so exciting is the number of companies and car companies where they're building plants. AI is the big thing. We have over $15 trillion announced already. And it's been — I mean, really, I would say it's been during the last three months. But we're here for a short period of time. And some administrations never had anywhere near that number for a whole term — probably for a whole two terms.  But we're up to over 15 trillion dollars coming into our country. There's never been anything like it anywhere in the world. There's never been an investment like that anywhere in the world. We, uh, look, I told this story and I just told it to Bibi backstage. I was talking to him and I said, you know, the king of Saudi Arabia, smart guy. And also we went to Qatar and we went to UAE.  really three strong leaders, smart guys. They all told me the same thing. And then I was reiterated at NATO just recently when we got back, where they agreed to spend a trillion dollars a year, by the way, which is about three times what they were spending. But they all said the same thing.  We thought your country was dead. Horrible term, right? We thought the United States of America was dead, and now you're presiding over the hottest country anywhere in the world. We're the hottest country in the world. I think Bibi would admit it. Even hotter than Israel, though Israel was pretty hot about a week ago, I can tell you, for the wrong — for the wrong reasons. But we are the hottest country in the world right now.  It happened faster than anybody thought possible. But we have over $15 trillion, and that means jobs, and that means building, and that means things like we've never seen before. So all we can do is keep working hard. There'll be always surprises. Some of the surprises are going to be bad surprises.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: In your view, is the mortgage transfer all over? Or do those talks need to happen before you can talk?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Well, I would say that the best man to answer that is the Prime Minister. But I will tell you that, in my view, I hope it's over. Yeah. I think Iran wants to meet. I think they want to make peace. And I'm all for it. Now, if that's not the case, we are ready, willing, and able. But I don't think we're going to have to be. But I think Bibi would answer that question very well.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: I think the partnership between Israel and the United States, the partnership between President Trump and me, produced a historic victory. It's an incredible victory, actually. It brought the greatest capabilities of the United States that are unmatched with the great capabilities of Israel.  and the Army of Israel, the pilots of Israel, the soldiers of Israel, and the Mossad. And the combination of these two extraordinary capacities produced a decisive result. It set back the two tumors that were threatening the life of Israel.  the nuclear tumor and the ballistic missile tumor, because they were planning to build 20,000 of these things and launch it in a country the size of New Jersey. And no country can withstand that. So what do you do when you have two things that are going to kill you? You have to remove them. With our combined effort, we did. But when you remove a tumor, it doesn't mean that it can't come back. You have to constantly monitor the situation to make sure that there's no attempt to bring it back.  So we've had a great achievement, and I think part of the effort of consolidating this and ensuring that we don't have to repeat this is to monitor this carefully. Of course, the President and I are talking about it. Our teams are talking about it. But there's no question, this is a historic victory. And I think, as was said here today, this has already changed the face of the Middle East. But I think that there is an opportunity here to create  a historic expansion of the Abraham Accords, which were themselves an act of history that deserve a Nobel Prize for the President. But I think the opportunities are much bigger, and I hope – I'd like to believe that Iran would not test our fortitude, because it would be a mistake.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: It's better to go a different way. Do you believe that regime change is still necessary here?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: I think it's up to the people of Iran.  I think there's an opportunity to explore.  I think that everyone understands that the situation has changed. Before that, Iran was essentially running Syria, okay, directly through Hezbollah. Hezbollah has been brought to its knees. Iran is out of the picture. So I think this presents opportunities for stability, for security, and eventually for peace.  I think that's been opened up also by the fact that the President has opened up a channel. So they have something – there's a lot to lose by going back to conflict, and there's a lot to gain by moving towards peace.  I think that opportunity has been opened by the President and by the changed security situation which we brought about with the collapse of the Assad regime. Let's suppose there were. Would I answer yes? No. It's your duty to ask. It's my duty to ask you back.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: You know, at the request of a lot of countries in the surrounding area of the Middle East, including Bibi,  We will we took the sanctions of Syria and I met the new leader. I was very impressed by him Somebody said well, he comes from a very tough background. I said, well, you know, I'm not that surprised it's a tough part of the world, but I was very impressed when we took the sanctions off because  We want to give them a chance. They would never have had a chance without the sanctions. And one of the things we have with Iran is, you know, we have very — they call it biting — they are very biting sanctions. And I would love to be able to, at the right time, take those sanctions off, give them a chance at rebuilding. Because I'd like to see Iran build itself back up in a peaceful manner and not going around saying, death to America, death to the USA, death to Israel, as they were doing. You know, they were the bully of the Middle East, and now they're not the bully anymore.  But they were saying terrible things. And we'd like to see them. They have such potential. You know, they have the oil power, and they have great people, smart people, energetic people. Amazing. And I know so many Iranians. Iranians from New York. I have a lot of friends, and they're great people. So it's a shame when you see a thing like this happen. But I think that taking the sanctions off of Syria is going to give Syria a great shot at making it.  Well, we've done a lot of them in the last, as you know,  The — I always say the great big beautiful bill. I add the word great. But it was the largest bill of its kind ever passed. We were talking about it before. It was a beauty. But, you know, a lot of the things that we did in executive orders have been codified in the legislation that we just had passed.  And we're going to be sending it a lot more over the next period of about two months separately. But a lot of it was part of that big, that beautiful big bill. Oh, we've spoken to everybody. We know everything. It's all done. I told you, I told you we'll make some deals. But for the most part, we're going to send a letter. We're going to say,  Welcome to the United States, if you'd like to participate in the greatest, most successful country ever. I mean, we're doing better than ever. We have — I don't think — and you're going to see these numbers soon. We've never had numbers like this. We've never had investment like this. We have more than 90. We're going to have much more than 90. But most of those are going to be sent a letter. This is exactly what I said. Now, we've made a deal with United Kingdom. We've made a deal with China. We've made a deal — we're close to making a deal with India.  Others we've met with, and we don't think we're going to be able to make a deal, so we just send them a letter. If you want to — if you want to play ball, you have to — this is what you have to pay. So we're — as far as I'm concerned, we're done. We're sending out letters to various countries, telling them how much tariffs they have to pay. Some will maybe adjust a little bit, depending if they have a, you know, cause. We're not going to be unfair about it. And actually, it's a small fraction compared to what we should be getting. We should be — we could be asking for much more.  For the sake of relationships that we've had with a lot of really good countries, we're doing the way I do it. But we could be getting a lot more.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: We could ask for a lot more than what we're asking for.  I'm saying here it is.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Congratulations. Welcome to the United States. I hope you make a lot of money and you got to pay us money. They were ripping us. They were charging us tariffs.  at levels that nobody's ever seen before. We have some countries that are charging 200% tariffs and making it impossible to do business. And what the tariffs are doing is they're driving people in and companies in into the United States. That's why we're building all of the work that you see happening in this country right now. And it's at a record level. All the factories, all of the AI institutions that are being built.  It's largely because well, I think it's because of November 5th a good election and I think it's because of the test Thank you all very much

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03

video_title: President Trump’s America = Law and Order!

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Since President Trump took office, ICE has been committed to removing the worst of the worst. We've seen them arrest hundreds of illegals with violent criminal histories. Like this Yemeni national who was picked up in Detroit. Officials say that he has several previous convictions, including second-degree murder. Or this Dominican national arrested for alleged fentanyl trafficking.  or this Guatemala national who was charged with three counts of aggravated rape of a child.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Those criminals, murderers, rapists that are threatening safety in our communities, they're going to be the first ones on the list to go. It's a commitment for our national security interests.

summary.SPEAKER_00: Agrees with the prioritisation of deporting criminals, emphasising its importance for national security and community safety.
summary.SPEAKER_01: Highlights ICE arrests of non-citizens with serious criminal convictions including murder, fentanyl trafficking and aggravated rape of a child.

video_title: No more catch-and-release—ONLY CATCH AND DEPORT!

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: 70% of those who we've arrested under this administration have either been convicted of a crime or have pending criminal charges. We're talking everything from murder, aggravated assault to sexual assault of a child.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Secretary of State Marco Rubio said the 17 criminals with ties to Venezuelan gang Tren de Aragua and MS-13 included murderers and rapists.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01

video_title: President Trump’s ICE Took Out the Trash

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: We're going to not stop doing what the American people elected this president to do.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: I offer any one of you a rent-free home with no taxes to pay in any of these gang neighborhoods. And I said, your neighbors are MS-13 terrorists, or Mexican mafia, or Sinaloa cartel, or Trey de Aragua. I couldn't pay you to live there.  But yet you, with your coverage, are trying to force innocent Americans to have these people as their neighbors, and that one day their daughter may be abducted from their home and raped and murdered. So you're not going to get an ounce of sympathy from this administration or President Trump for the terrorists who've invaded our homes and our country.

summary.SPEAKER_00: The administration will continue implementing policies that the American people elected the President to do.
summary.SPEAKER_01: Makes a provocative statement offering a rent-free home in gang neighbourhoods to illustrate the perceived dangers of immigration, suggesting that the media is ignoring the risks these neighbourhoods pose to innocent Americans, implying that immigration leads to crime and violence.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation is a heated exchange about immigration and public safety, with one speaker defending the administration's policies and criticising the media, while the other speaker offers a provocative counterpoint.

video_title: One Nation Under God

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: As we prepare to celebrate two and a half centuries of freedom, I am inviting America's great religious communities to pray for our nation and for our people. From the beginning, this has always been a country sustained and strengthened by prayer. So important. If we bring religion back stronger, you're going to see everything get better and better and better. You're going to see it get better and better.  So as we chart our course for the next 250 years, let us rededicate ourselves to one nation under God. Right?

summary.SPEAKER_00: Invites religious communities to pray for the nation and its people, highlighting the historical role of prayer in sustaining America.
summary.high_level_summary: The speaker emphasises the significance of prayer and religion in the nation

video_title: President Trump Gaggles with Press Before Departing the White House, July 11, 2025

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: We're going to Texas. Some of you are coming with us. How are you? And it's a horrible thing. Horrible thing. Nobody can even believe it, such a thing. That much water that fast. Without a dam break, you'd think a dam would have to break to have it. So, it's a terrible thing. But we're going to be there with some of the great families and others, the governor, everybody. We're going to be there. The Press Do you plan to talk to the U.S. President about the tariffs?  Maybe at some point, I'll talk to him. Right now, I'm not. They're treating President Bolsonaro very unfairly. He's a good man. You know, I know him well. I negotiated with him.  He was a very tough negotiator, and I can tell you he was a very honest man, and he loved the people of Brazil. He was a very tough guy to negotiate with. I shouldn't like him because he was very tough in negotiation, but he was also very honest. And I know the honest one, and I know the crooked one. We're going to see. It was sent yesterday. They called.  I think it was fairly well received, what we need. So we'll see what happens. Washington drones hit a maternity hospital in Ukraine overnight. Your reaction to that? I know. You'll be seeing things happen. Now that you will go to Texas, are you planning on delivering any type of help for undocumented families that lost everything including their children?  I think we've done very well on immigration. We were given a very bad hand by Biden. He allowed 25 million people to come in totally unchecked, unvetted. We're getting the criminals out, and we're getting them out fast. The courts have ultimately done the right thing.  Amazingly, they've really done the right thing. And they understand it's really the survival of our country. It's a very important thing. We can't have, like, 11,888 murderers. And, you know, something that you should have that you haven't reported.  As you know, 300,000 children are missing. Right? 300,000 under Biden. And we've already gotten back 10,000 of those children. And we have a lot more planned to come back. We're getting them back by the thousands. But 300,000. And as of this morning, over 10,000 we've gotten back.  What is your advice to countries worldwide ahead of the upcoming tariff deadline? Oh, I think just keep working hard. You know, we've been taken advantage of for many, many years by countries, both friend and foe. And frankly, the friends have been worse than the foes in many cases. So I would say just keep working. It's all going to work out.  I think he's doing a terrible job. I think we should be, no, I think we should be three points lower interest rates. He's costing our country a lot of money. We should be number one. And we're not. And that's because of Jerome Powell. In terms of interest, we are number one in the world. Look, I'll tell you a little simple, a little simple language.  One year ago, our country was a dead country. We were going nowhere except down. We were the laughingstock all over the world. And now we're the hottest country anywhere in the world. We're number one everywhere, anywhere in the world. And that's all they're talking about is our country. One year ago, it was a dead country. Now it's the hottest country anywhere in the world.

video_title: 'GREAT DANGER': Trump sounds off on new Democrat bill to unmask ICE agents

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Joining me now is Wisconsin Senator Ron Johnson. Senator, I don't think we've talked since the BB bill passed. You always wanted several bills. We talked about it. We debated it on various times. But now that we have one big, beautiful bill into law, what comes next? Are we going to have another bill? Are you going to put forward another bill or do it all through rescissions or what?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Good morning, David. Well, first of all, I always was supportive of the major elements of the bill. We had to extend current tax law to take off, you know, an automatic tax increase off the table, avoid default in our debt. The Democrats left us such enormous messes. You know, the open border, we needed funding for that. The raging wars, we needed funding for defense. So, again, I was supportive of the main elements. I was just trying to make the bill better.  Your earlier guest was talking about the energy tax credits. We were subsidizing to the tune of about a trillion dollars. We cut it out to about a half trillion dollars. Energy sources that made our grid less reliable. Think about it. We're going to spend a half trillion dollars on these renewable energy sources that make our grid less reliable. It's a good thing we got rid of that as well.  Again, in total, absolutely had to pass the one big beautiful bill. I think it's going to do great things for our economy. Now we need to get folks on spending. That was my biggest complaint. I was trying to do everything I could to do more to reduce spending levels to a reasonable pre-pandemic level.  But in my discussions with the president, his economic advisors, the majority leader here in the Senate, the Speaker of the House, I think I've got their commitment to, over time, can't do it in one bill, it's gonna take a number of bites to the apple here, but return to a reasonable pre-pandemic level spending, and I got their commitment to a process to achieve and maintain it.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: And I'll be highly involved in that process. But talk about that process, Senator. Specifically, what are we talking about? A new reconciliation package, or is this gonna be done through rescissions?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, all of the above. We're going to have to figure out how to codify what this budget review panel is going to uncover. And again, what we're going to have is we're going to have members of the Senate, members of the House working very closely with OMB. We will hire auditors to go line-by-line, program-by-program through the federal budget in a very thoughtful, very thorough manner, present those findings to Congress, and then hopefully have, and we're pretty well assured that we'll have other budget reconciliation opportunities, maybe  one more or two more in this Congress yet to address that type of spending reduction. Again, I have to believe, Dave, when we've gone from $4.4 trillion to over $7 trillion in spending, there are hundreds of billions of dollars, hundreds of programs out of the 2,600 programs of the federal government that you could eliminate and nobody would even know except for the grifters that are sucking down the waste, fraud, abuse, and pork.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Yeah, yeah. Now, meanwhile, the Democrats, this has to be quick, but the Democrats have introduced a bill to ban ICE agents from wearing masks. Listen to what Donald Trump had to say about that. Roll tape.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Well, they wouldn't be saying that if they didn't hate our country. And they obviously do. You put them in great danger, tremendous danger. But when a patriot who works for ICE or Border Patrol puts a mask on so that  They won't recognize him and his family. So they can lead a little bit of a normal life after having worked so hard and so dangerously. There's a problem with that.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Where do you stand on this bill or this attempt to put together a bill by Democrats to unmask ICE agents?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, President Trump is 100% right. Democrats are 100% wrong. It is actually stunning how anti-law enforcement the Democratic Party in general has become. And I hope the American public is paying attention because we actually value law enforcement. We understand the service and sacrifice. Every day they go on the job, they're risking their lives. We should appreciate them. Democrats obviously don't.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Well, certainly 100%. They need to be appreciated and they don't need to be doxed by radicals who have plans to kill him. I mean, that's that's just absurd that they're planning to do this. Senator Ron Johnson. Enjoy that beautiful weather in Wisconsin. We hope you can get there soon from inside the Beltway. Appreciate you being here.

summary.SPEAKER_01: The host inquires about future legislative plans after the BB bill. He expresses interest in the process for reducing spending to pre-pandemic levels and asks about the methods, such as reconciliation packages or rescissions.
summary.SPEAKER_02: Senator Johnson supports the main elements of the BB bill but highlights his efforts to reduce spending and eliminate wasteful programs. He emphasises the commitment from the President and other leaders to return to pre-pandemic spending levels through a multi-step process involving a budget review panel and potential reconciliation opportunities. He criticises the Democratic Party for being anti-law enforcement and dismisses their bill to ban ICE agents from wearing masks as dangerous and absurd.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the recently passed BB bill, future spending plans, and a new Democratic bill regarding ICE agents.

video_title: GOP rep accuses Dems of ‘hypocrisy’ for voting no on Trump’s ‘historic’ tax bill

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Welcome back. As Republicans celebrate the passage of the big, beautiful bill, attention now turns to the Senate, where a rescission package is due next week. House Speaker Mike Johnson already teasing plans for two more significant reconciliation packages over the coming year. But the mega bill already in court over the Medicaid funding cuts to Planned Parenthood. Democrats are preparing targeted campaign ads against the bill going into reelection next year.  Joining me now is Louisiana Congressman and House Majority Leader Steve Scalise. Congressman, it's great to see you. Thank you so much for being here. And congrats to you and your colleagues for passing this big, beautiful bill. Tell us about the impact.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: quite a bit.  Trillions of more investment, people investing in America, again, because of this bill, stabilizing the tax code. Nobody gets a tax increase. I'd love, Maria, for every Democrat who's out bashing this bill, ask them this basic question. Will you pay the higher tax rate that you voted for for all Americans? Because every Democrat voted no, which means they voted for a higher tax rate for everybody in America.  will they pay that higher tax rate or are they going to take the benefits of this bill? There's a lot of hypocrisy out there because this bill delivers a lot of great things for a lot of people. No tax on tips. One of the great hallmarks President Trump said that he would do on the campaign trail.  Everybody who's a tip worker is going to get it. I'll tell you something, Marie. I've been talking about with constituents just in the last few days back home that they didn't even know about this bill. So not only do we say no tax on overtime, but let's say you're a cop. Let's say you're a nurse and you work overtime hours. This bill is retroactive to January, to when Donald Trump took office. So all the taxes you paid on your overtime this year, you're going to get that money back when you file your return.  That's going to be more money in your pockets. These are blue-collar workers. These aren't the millionaires and the billionaires that the Democrats have been lying about about this bill. This is blue-collar workers that get the benefits of this bill, plus more energy production, more border security. We revamp and modernize America's whole air traffic control system.  You know, we've seen all these horrible reports. LaGuardia being shut down for days. Every air flight in America being canceled because we're running off of floppy disks, for goodness sakes. We fixed that in this bill. Sean Duffy, the great job he's been doing over at Transportation, they will now have the resources to modernize America's air traffic control system. Every Democrat voted against that, Maria.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, they're going to try to use this bill against you. You know that in the upcoming reelection for 2026, how are you going to navigate that?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Well, we're going to tell the truth while they're out lying. You know, we've always said, if you keep lying about us, we're going to keep telling the truth about you. They've been saying everybody's going to die. You know, every hospital is going to close. Well, a year from now, Maria, we're actually going to be able to see results. It's all the hyperbole that you saw them saying on the House floor. They were all lies. You know, disabled people will get better Medicaid under this bill because  All of the fully able-bodied, the 35-year-old guy sitting at home playing video games in his mom's basement, he's going to have to go work because we put work requirements in place. And so he will not be crowding out disabled people in Medicaid. It's a crowded program. It's not the best form of health care right now. And so we're going to make that program work better for the people that are truly disabled and needy, not for somebody who's turning down work.  And by the way, when he gets a job, he's going to get health care with his job. That's better than Medicaid. So, you know, these are all components of the bill that they've been lying about. The truth is going to be something that the American people like, because these are all things that President Trump campaigned on, and so did we.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Let me ask you, Congressman, about Joe Biden. Speaking of health, the former president's doctor, Kevin O'Connor, pleading the fifth on key questions yesterday from the House Oversight Committee over the cover-up of Joe Biden's health and mental decline. Texas Congressman Jasmine Crockett claims that she has zero concerns about the former president. Watch this.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: It's kind of astounding to hear someone say, if you invoke the Fifth Amendment, that is only because you are guilty. We have a constitutional right that anyone who may be under fire can invoke. I think that he did what any good lawyer would advise him to do. I didn't see Joe Biden every single day, but I did have an opportunity to interact with the president. I never had a concern.  He may get fumbled up by words, but that's not anything new and it's not anything that came with age. We know that this is someone that was born with a stutter that ultimately had to get over it.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: So what about that, Congressman? I mean, we're all trying to understand who exactly was running the country for the last four years and who was using the auto pen. I asked President Trump who he wants to see questioned, and he said it was Lisa Monaco that he'd like to see questioned, the former deputy AG behind Merrick Garland. Your reaction to all of this and the fact that now his doctor is taking the fifth? Can't get answers from Kevin O'Connor.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: And first, this is not somebody who's been stumbling over words, Maria. Everybody in America's watched this cognitive decline for years. You know, some in the far-left media act like this was some new revelation at the debate where President Trump destroyed Joe Biden in the debate. It had been going on before that, and everybody knew about it. But the left was covering up, including the media in the left. And so, you know, let's not play that game. However, we're really concerned about things like the use of the auto pen.  the auto pen wasn't just used to sign some congratulatory note for somebody who turned 100 they were signing pardons with the auto pen other really important documents and then now there are people testifying saying Joe Biden probably didn't even know it was being used well if so who was  You know, why was somebody using President Biden's signature without President Biden's own knowledge? And we're digging into things like that. His doctor raises a lot of questions when you're asked, you know, were you ever pushed into lying about Joe Biden? And you plead the fifth, you know, raises a lot of serious questions, Maria. And we're going to keep digging to get answers.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: I mean, we know that right after the tapes came out from the Robert Herr interview, where we would have been able to see exactly how Biden answered those questions, suddenly the Democrats come up with an admission that Joe Biden has prostate cancer.  Right? I mean, how does that show up so fast? I mean, look, we've been questioning Biden's health on this program from almost the moment he stepped into office. Watch this.  We know that Biden is weak. We're not sure about his mental capacity. We know somebody else is running things, but the alternative is even worse. Kamala Harris. How is that presidential story going to look? One concern the Democrats have for Biden in 2024 is his age and health. I mean, look, we all watch him. It doesn't bring anybody any joy to point out cognitive issues.  So, I mean, look, if I'm there saying this back in 2021, Congressman, we know lots of people were recognizing what was going on with Joe Biden, not to mention Congress. You and your colleagues raised it many times. So it's no surprise. Can they continue to just take the fifth and not address this? Don't people deserve to know who made some of those policy decisions?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Yeah, and Maria, people want to know the truth. The American people deserve to know the truth. And we have some people who are talking. There were some people in the Biden White House who are talking to Chairman Comer's committee. You know, you were spot on in 2021. I have a number of my colleagues, we were all talking about this back then, because you could see it.  was a  I have Republicans that went on Jake Tapper's show to say he had a cognitive decline, and Jake Tapper read him the Riot Act, called him all kind of crazy names. Now he's got a book saying, gee whiz, we just realized it. No, he didn't. He knew it back then. And he was playing pit bull for the far left to attack any Republican who said there was a decline. The American people have figured this out.  The Democrat Party is still in denial. So, as you saw the clip from Crockett, they're trying to still cover up for it. They're still in denial about why they lost the election. Their party's being run by socialists. Go look in New York City. That's who they are. That's who their party is. And that's not where the American people are. We're fighting for blue-collar, hardworking families, and they're still yelling lies about millionaires and billionaires and people dying in the streets, and they wonder why they keep losing elections.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Congressman, real quick before you go, these attacks on ICE agents, the Democrats do not want to see ICE agents coming in and taking out illegals from the country. What should be done about this?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Well, first of all, it's criminal. You are seeing the President Trump and the Justice Department going aggressively after anybody who's attacking ICE agents, you know, whether they're slashing tires or whether they're ambushing and trying to murder them in shootouts. You know, they're going to do hard jail time. It's federal crime to attack and assault a federal officer. And so it's being fueled by the left. They'll make no doubt about it, Maria. You know, when you see Democrat politicians  at the highest levels, still out there publicly bashing ICE agents. The Democrat party who tried to defund police is now trying to defund ICE. They want chaos. They don't want rule of law. We are fighting for rule of law. And the ICE agents are doing a wonderful job. You know, these are heroes. These are people getting the pedophiles off of our streets, hardened criminals, gang leaders from foreign countries that Joe Biden let in.  They're the ones that are getting them out of our country to keep our communities safe. And the Democrat Party wants to go after them. Shame on them, Maria.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: All right, we will leave it there and keep watching it. Congressman, it's good to see you as always. Thank you so much.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Always great to be with you, Maria.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Thanks. And to you. Steve Scalise, Craig Bragan and Investors.

summary.SPEAKER_01: Promotes the Republican bill, highlighting its benefits such as no tax on tips and overtime pay retroactivity. Emphasises that the bill is for blue-collar workers and criticises Democrats for hypocrisy and spreading lies about its impact. Defends the work requirements for Medicaid and accuses the left of covering up President Biden's cognitive decline.
summary.SPEAKER_02: Hosts the discussion and questions the Republican bill's potential use against them in the 2026 re-election. Shifts the focus to President Biden's health, suggesting his doctor's pleading the fifth and the sudden admission of prostate cancer raise concerns. Expresses worry about who is making policy decisions and criticises Democrats for their stance on ICE agents.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses a recently passed Republican bill, its key provisions, and the Democrats' opposition. It also shifts to questions about President Biden's health and fitness for office, and the subsequent actions of his doctor and the White House.

video_title: Mother recalls her two sons’ harrowing escape from Texas floods

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Kelly Raban is a mother of two sons who survived the Texas floods and she joins us now. Kelly, thank God you your your boys did survive. How old are they and how did they get out?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Thank you so much. It's been a whirlwind of emotions over the last few days. So my oldest son, Braden, he's nine, and he'd attended Camp La Junta just five minutes down the road from Camp Mystic for, this would have been his third year.  And Brock, my youngest, he just graduated kindergarten. He's seven and this was his first time to go to camp.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: They were there. First time, that's extraordinary. So he didn't really have a lay of the land and yet he got out. How did he do it?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: So yeah, no lay of the land at all. In fact, they'd only been there for one full day. I mean, they probably didn't even know their cabin mates' names at that point.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Oops.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: So fortunate.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Keep talking. We can hear you, but we can't see you right now, Kelly. Go ahead. There you are.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Thank you. So I would say thanks to the very brave counselors and the cabin or the camp director. He was able to get out.  He ended up having to go from his bottom bunk to his top bunk to then to the rafters of the cabin. And I've actually now seen a photo of my little, little boy up in the rafters as the bunk beds are completely turned over as the water is high in his cabin. And it's  It's just unfathomable.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: How do you think you're gonna deal with this? I mean, this is something that leaves some scars. I mean, are you talking it out with your kids right now?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: We are gently talking it out, and they found it empowering to share their story with other people. But there are an incredible amount of resources that are coming forward for all of those affected by the Hill Country floods. Just last night, I participated in a virtual  therapy session with other you know with other storm survivors of various different natural events. But it's wonderful that so many resources are coming forward and we plan to take you know full usage of that.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Yeah, we we have to go, but I I heard yesterday you talking to Martha McCallum and saying that the kids actually want to go back to the camp. I mean, good for them for that. That shows a certain spirit in them. But what do you think about that? How are you going to deal with them going back to the same camp?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Oh, you know, I I would endorse it as well. I think you know, unfortunately in life tragedy happens and then we  Make things better and make things stronger and make things safer. And I have full confidence that the camp will be able to do that. It is such an important part of their lives and you know, I appreciate their resilience.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: God bless you. Thank thank God your your boys are alive and I know you're praying for those.  who weren't so lucky, but we appreciate you coming on, Kelly. Best of luck for your future. And by the way, Fox Corporation has joined relief efforts with a donation made to the Community Foundation of the Texas Hill Country's Kerr County Flood Relief Fund. To help, you can donate by going to the website you see on the screen right there. You can scan that CR code. If you have your phone handy, the QR code there, you can take a picture of that and get the link.

summary.SPEAKER_00: The interviewer expresses relief and gratitude that Kelly's sons survived the floods. They ask questions about the boys' harrowing escape, their emotional state, and how the family is coping with the trauma. The interviewer also highlights the resilience of the children by mentioning their desire to return to camp and acknowledges the broader impact of the floods by noting Fox Corporation's donation to relief efforts.
summary.SPEAKER_01: Kelly Raban recounts her sons' experience at camp during the Texas floods. Her oldest, Braden, is 9 and had been to camp before, while her youngest, Brock, is 7 and was there for his first time. Brock had to climb from his bottom bunk to the rafters to escape the rising water. Kelly expresses gratitude for the counselors and camp director who helped the boys. She discusses the emotional toll on her family, how they are seeking support through therapy sessions, and the overwhelming resources available to survivors. Kelly also shares that surprisingly, both her boys want to return to camp next year.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation is about a mother, Kelly Raban, whose two sons survived the Texas floods while attending camp. The boys faced a life-threatening situation but were rescued by brave counselors and the camp director. The family is now processing the trauma, utilising available resources, and surprisingly, the boys want to return to camp.

video_title: Iran warns a drone may strike Trump at Mar-a-Lago

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Well, Iran warning that a drone might strike Donald Trump while he's at Mar-a-Lago. Jillian Turner is at the State Department with more on this. Jillian, tell us about this.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Well, David, President Trump is now being targeted by Iranian death fatwas, including direct from regime officials themselves. Notably, this comes at the same time that Washington and Tehran now are trying to re-up, re-energize the Iran nuclear negotiations. Take a look at this pretty shocking commentary. It comes from an adviser to Iran's Ayatollah. He says...  Trump can no longer sunbathe in Mar-a-Lago, because, while he's lying down, a microdrone might target and strike him right in the navel. So, in addition to being really strange, this is not the first time the president has been on the receiving end of a threat like this. An Iranian assassination plot, you will remember, was uncovered just a few weeks before the now infamous Butler rally.  Nevertheless, the president didn't sound overly concerned about this new threat when he was asked about it yesterday. Take a listen.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Do you think that's a real threat? And when is the last time you went sunbathing?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Anyway, I've been a long time. It's been a long time. I don't know. Maybe I was around seven or so. I'm not too big into it. Uh, yeah, I guess it's a threat. I'm not sure it's a threat, actually, but perhaps it is.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: So, one watchdog group is now demanding sanctions on Iranian clerics that have issued fatwas, these being legal decrees that call for the torture and assassination of President Trump and any other Americans. The last fatwa, you will recall, against a U.S. citizen was Salman Rushdie. It nearly cost him his life when he was attacked on stage right there, you can see on your screen, at New York's Chautauqua Institute.  The State Department spokeswoman, Tammy Bruce, didn't provide us details this week when we asked where the nuclear negotiations stand right now. Listen.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: While I can't speak, obviously, to the choices President Trump will make, what we do all know is that he is a businessman. Americans appreciate that about him, the nature of how he looks at the issue of national security and safety.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: It's really, David, not just the president that faces a threat. Any Americans who have any ties to Iran are now fair targets to the regime here in the United States. They have said that. There's also a State Department Level 4 warning telling Americans not to go to Iran for any reason whatsoever. Believe it or not, Americans are still traveling there. It's causing a lot of headaches for the State Department.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Jillian Turner, thank you for that report.

summary.SPEAKER_00: (Trump) Dismisses the threat as somewhat uncertain. He casually remarks that he doesn't sunbathe much.
summary.SPEAKER_01: Reports on Iran's death fatwas against Trump, including a specific threat from an adviser to Iran's Ayatollah. Mentions the history of such threats, an uncovered Iranian assassination plot, and a watchdog group's demand for sanctions. Highlights the danger to Trump and any Americans with ties to Iran, and notes the State Department's Level 4 travel warning for Iran.
summary.SPEAKER_02: (State Department Spokeswoman) Defends Trump's approach to national security without directly addressing the threat. Emphasises Trump's business acumen and how Americans appreciate it.
summary.SPEAKER_03: Introduces the topic and asks Jillian Turner about the Iran warning. Later, asks Trump directly about the threat and his sunbathing habits.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses Iran's escalating threats against former President Donald Trump and the broader implications for U.S.-Iran relations and American citizens.

video_title: 'NO STONE UNTURNED': Rand Paul stresses protection of Trump amid Iranian official's threat

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Well, Senator Rand Paul joins me now. Senator, do you consider this a credible threat?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Well, you know, we live in a new era, and not everything about the modern era is great. I think the ability to kill individuals with drones, we've seen a great advance in that technology in the Ukrainian-Russian war. You see $400 drones taking out $2 million tanks.  I think ultimately we are going to live in an era where people are threatened in everyday walk of lives, where you live, where you are by drones. So we do have to be very conscious of it. I take it very seriously. I want the president to be protected. I think we should spare no stone, leave no stone unturned to make sure that the president is adequately protected. And I feel comfortable that the Secret Service believes the same thing.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Alright, I want to bring it back to domestic issues. Senator earlier in the program I asked Senator Ron Johnson what comes next for fixing our spending problem. Listen to what he said.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: The Democrats left us such enormous messes. The open border, we needed funding for that. The raging wars, we needed funding for defense. So, again, I was supportive of the main elements. I was just trying to make the bill better.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Of course, Senator, you voted against the bill. It passed. It is now law. What comes next? Where is it possible, do you think, for us to get the kind of cuts you wanted?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Well, you know, I'm hopeful that the tax cuts in the bill will successfully allow and cause economic growth. I voted for the tax cuts in 2017. We had some of the historically lowest unemployment we've had in a generation. So I'm hoping that will continue, that economic growth will come from continuing the tax cuts and making them permanent. As far as spending cuts, I think  I've got this plan and I'm just going to air this, this is brand new. I think if we send about 150 members of Congress to like a chiropractor for like additional, if we give them a spine, like a spinal transplant, I think that's the only thing I think that would get us to a point where we could have spending cuts.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Well, that's that's pretty. First of all, it's it's a great plan, but of course it's not going to work. So barring some kind of spinal implant, what what can we do? I mean, are rescissions going to be enough? Are you going to have to have a new reckon reconciliation bill quickly?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: We're going to find out on the rescissions very quickly. The president has sent us $9 billion to cut. I'm all for it. I will cut. It's only a rounding error. I will vote for it, but we have to see if we can get them to send us more after we get that approved.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: All right, Senator Rand Paul, let's hope that you have some input on these rescissions. Thank you very much for being here. Appreciate it.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Thank you.

summary.unstructured_summary:
{'high_level_summary': 'The conversation covers two main topics
: drone threats and domestic spending. Senator Rand Paul acknowledges the seriousness of drone threats and discusses the need for protection. On domestic spending, Paul criticises current spending levels, proposes a humorous but ineffective solution for achieving spending cuts, and expresses hope that tax cuts will stimulate economic growth. He also supports proposed rescissions but notes they are insufficient.', 'SPEAKER_01': 'The host initiates discussions on both drone threats and domestic spending. They bring up specific points, such as the potential impact of drones on everyday life and the recent spending bill passed in Congress. The host also challenges Senator Paul on finding practical solutions for achieving spending cuts and seeks clarity on his future approach.', 'SPEAKER_00': 'Senator Rand Paul takes drone threats seriously and emphasises the need for enhanced protection measures. He discusses the technological advancements in drones and their potential consequences. On domestic spending, Paul criticises the current administration and previous Congresses for leaving behind spending messes. He proposes a plan for economic growth through tax cuts but acknowledges the challenges in achieving significant spending cuts. Paul supports proposed rescissions but believes more substantial cuts are necessary.'}

video_title: FOLLOW THE MONEY: Mamdani 'grassroots' campaign donors revealed

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: So much for being anti-billionaire. According to the new reporting, the so-called grassroots revolution behind the rise of Zoran Mamdani leads right to Hollywood, Silicon Valley, and America's wealthiest zip codes. New campaign finance records show $2 million in political action committee support. Over 70% of that came from out of state.  Many of the top donors to those packs have zero ties to New York City. Steven Spielberg, Phoebe Gates, yes, that Gates, and rich Palo Alto tech investors. It's a lot of elitist power, not the kind of power to the people Mamdani likes to tout. So Liz, this kind of looks like that  Playbook to me of you got the rich elite power brokers who want to do a little ideological Experiment somewhere and now it's New York City.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: They want to export their craziness and they're doing it I mean, but by the way, it seems to me every time there's a progressive Candidate that makes a lot of noise and is out there in the front. They get funding from Hollywood they get funding from obviously George Soros and all these people and  And you just have to kind of wonder why. What is the agenda here? I mean, in California, things aren't going terribly well because the progressive agenda has meant higher taxes, people leaving the state, businesses leaving the state, higher cost of living. I mean, tell me one good thing other than the sunshine that happens in California that New Yorkers want. Why does Steven Spielberg think he has any insight at all into how to run New York City?  I don't know, but you remember Beto O'Rourke when he was running against Abbott? He got a lot of money from exactly the same crowd. Right. And all, I mean, you can go down the list of progressive hopefuls. They always get this following. And it's annoying, but you know what? It's legal, so you can't really combat it except to tell people the truth.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Well, it's funny you say Beto O'Rourke because I'm looking at that picture of Mamdani now, like the rolled up sleeves and the tie.  It's like I get why Spielberg likes it. He looks like a movie scene that doesn't bear any relation to reality But I don't know maybe they say misery loves company. Is that why all these Californians want to?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Project it on the rest of us as you know when I don't understand something I often lay in bed and I think about it and  I've thought about this a lot for the last 25 years. I think I finally understand. And I think that it's coming to light more and more with these candidates, the more progressive they become. And he's a perfect example of it. Why is Steven Spielberg endorsing him or Hollywood endorsing him? Because they have so much money, it doesn't matter to them. They won't be touched by it. He is not a Democrat socialist. He's not even a socialist. He is a communist wearing a socialist sheep's costume.  When you think about what communism really is, there's a super high band of elite on top, your Spielberg, Soros types. They retain control of everything. And you eradicate the middle class. There's everybody else. The rest that fall under that line have to share everything. And Spielberg doesn't care. Soros doesn't care, because they don't have to share. They just accumulate the power.  And that's really what this is about. It is an ideological shift, as you're talking about. We used to think about this maybe 10 years ago or 15 years ago and think it was crazy that we'd never see that happen in this country. But then the rise of AOC and people like Mondami and, you know.  That's what's happening slowly. And the problem is when people, when they need the grassroots to vote for this, because they don't have enough votes to be able to do this themselves. And they sucker you in by telling you you're going to get free things and everything's going to be so much better and blah, blah, blah. And then, you know, they really kick you in the behind and you see it only after.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Tiffany.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Yeah, I mean, from a political perspective, I say, let the dark money and the Hollywood elitists keep funding candidates like this, because it's not good for the Democrat Party. Voters have repeatedly rejected this far left progressive ideology or candidates. And Mondami is by far the most progressive  out-of-touch candidate our country is ever seeing, full stop. I will stand by that. I mean, it's wild what he's coming up with. Government-run grocery stores. I wonder how the people in New York would really like that. He is a communist. He's pushing these ideas. And, you know, he's a typical  Politician he's saying one thing and doing another he's saying he's grassroots funded and getting money from from Hollywood elitist What troubles me though is with that money you can sort of buy votes  And that's what I think that they have to watch for here in New York. But it's like, it's as if he thinks money grows on trees and he can create these beautiful communities and free housing and free grocery stores, government run grocery stores. I was with a 20 something year old New Yorker. I had lunch with her the other day and she said she would vote for Mondani. And I said,  Really? I was shocked, but it all sounds good. You know, everything he's saying... Free! Everything's free!

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Well, they are smart, Taylor, and this goes back to your hometown. They are really good at the slick message. They spend a lot of money, and so why do these people vote for him? Because Mamdani looks like a great Netflix show.  And they love watching Netflix. That's where Spielberg comes in.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: I told you, what was my first vote for my bullet train in California? I was suckered in. I loved it. 2008, you turn whatever, 18, 21, you put your vote in for my bullet train, my bullet train to nowhere. I'm glad you're big enough to admit this.  I have two pieces of good news. One, maybe they'll stop stealing from Duane Reade and Walgreens and start stealing from the government-run grocery stores so that when we go to Walgreens, things won't be locked up anymore. Second piece of good news... That's cold comfort for me, but give us your second.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01

To put it bluntly, they say Upstate can't afford a socialist New York mayor because the city pays for most of the services that Albany provides. Every dollar spent to bail out the Big Apple on a socialist experiment is a dollar that Kathy Hochul could be spending fruitfully elsewhere.  So maybe that's our good news.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00

summary.SPEAKER_01: SPEAKER_01 highlights the irony of Mamdani receiving significant funding from wealthy out-of-state donors, including Steven Spielberg and Phoebe Gates, which undermines his portrayal as a grassroots candidate. SPEAKER_01 also critiques Mamdani's policies, calling him out-of-touch and potentially harmful to New York City.

summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the funding of Zoran Mamdani, a progressive political candidate in New York City, by wealthy out-of-state donors, particularly from Hollywood and Silicon Valley. The speakers criticise this funding, arguing it contradicts Mamdani's grassroots image and suggests an ideological experiment by the elite. They express concerns about the potential impact of Mamdani's communist-leaning policies on New York City and the broader state, fearing it could lead to higher taxes, business exodus, and the erosion of the middle class.

video_title: This is the 'greatest enemy' to the plans of someone like Mamdani: Brian Brenberg

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Dare to take a stab, Lauren. Well, there is a huge mobilization right now to prevent this from happening. Right after he won the primary, days later, Saturday, 4th of July weekend, you had three fundraisers in the Hamptons and one in New Jersey, and they raised $300,000. Drop in the bucket, but it's something, it was immediate. I spoke to a broker who said, well, shock results, Mondani won, I lost two deals.  I hope they come out, but people are already scared. He does hope they come back. Last night, there was another fundraiser for Eric Adams, so Mondani does not win. It raised a million dollars. That's good.  This is craziness. I stood in front of one of the buildings that if you look at Mamdani's plan, he wants affordable housing to emulate this building. It was on the Upper West Side. It's across the street from a middle school. And we were there all day. And people were coming up to me, residents, saying we did everything in our power to prevent this from being built. It's a beautiful building. Half of it is affordable housing. This is a candidate who wants rents to stay the same for four years. What do you do if you're a landlord?  You can't. You don't renovate because there's no incentive. So I let the rats come in. The market. And the other half the building was for the unhoused, for homeless people. And they're loitering about across the street from the middle school. That's what he wants to do to New York City. He worked for three years in his entire life. He graduated from college.  dabbled in the markets to work, and then he became a state assemblyman. He's got no experience.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: The wrench in all of this, Jackie, we were talking about this yesterday, Cuomo's leading Adams in the polls. So we were thinking, okay, everyone rally behind Eric Adams, the incumbent, independent, just do it. But if those polls don't change soon, then that strategy isn't going to work if Cuomo's beating him.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Yeah, it's tough to say drop out when you're second and you're right under the person who's leading. The thing though is and the reason why people are saying that he should is because Adams has the experience, he's aligned himself with Trump and shown that he can bring results to the city very quickly. And a lot of people just don't like Cuomo  or not.  You really start to, and this is why I have a problem with the policies, because the policies don't even really address the underlying problem. The problem for me with homeless people isn't the fact that they don't have a home. Many times, and I've interacted with them on the streets of New York, and I'm sure you guys have too, you actually have a problem with mental illness that requires treatment. It's not just putting a roof over somebody's head. It's really trying to chip away at a bigger problem.  And until you do that, you know, you can just put the roof over their head and pay for it forever, but we're not really gonna solve our crisis here. And that's why people were so angry that so many dollars were going to migrants, for example, at these shelters and all these benefits that they were getting, when we could be spending those dollars to figure out our homeless problem with a root cause of mental illness. So again, it's like, you know, he puts the stuff out there that sounds good to people, but doesn't actually fix what is ailing the city.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: And if you're 26, that sounds great. But if you're 46, as we were saying in the break, and you have a family, even if you're liberal, those policies just don't work for your safety and security financially.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Maybe the 26-year-olds should take a field trip to a communist country and really grasp. That was a TikTok meme, right? They said, send them to a communist country, those voters, and see how they do. To a government-run grocery store and see how they live.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: How do you have an answer for that, though? They always say, yeah, but that's different. That's not what we're doing. We're doing this thing. That was a new building that you were looking at? Yeah, it was relatively new. See, the greatest enemy to the plans of somebody like Mamdani is time. Because they always point to the newest thing. Like they just cut the ribbon on this, and look how shiny it is.  Give it 10 years, right? And 10 years go by, and it's failed. But then the next one says, but we're going to do it different than that. They didn't really do it the right way. We're going to do it a different way. He's like the kid who comes into a, because I taught freshman economics for years.  He's like a kid who walks into a freshman economics class, and they're ambitious and smart, and they're like, I know how to fix the world. We gotta give stuff to people who need it. That's Marx, right? And the whole point of an economics class, almost the whole point, is to teach people to stop thinking about where stuff goes, and teach them about where it comes from.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Here's the problem, though. You are the one that on this set told me AOC has an economics background.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Yeah, that's why, that's... I thought she was a bartender. Well, she is a bartender, and she had an economics background, and that's the indictment of our education system that has created an economics discipline that fails in its number one task, which is to teach people how little they, this is Frederick Hayek, to teach people how little they know about what they imagine they can design. That's what economics should do, and it's failed to do that, and that's why you get guys like this who point to the shiny building and say, see, this works,

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: And you need the business community. You need developers to build that for you. And these developers are mostly Democrats. And they're saying, heck no, we will not do this for you. It doesn't work. Because there's such a thing as an American dream to aspire, to make money, and to have choice. Do you think if you go into a government-run food store that you're going to see all the  different types of flavors of M&M's and everything else. You can get white bread or maybe you can get wheat bread. That's it. No more choice. That's not American. That's not how we do things. Well, maybe it's Hollywood.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: He wouldn't survive.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: His Hollywood donors will build those buildings for him.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: It's a conversation we're going to continue to follow, as we always do.
