video_title: Senator's 'big beef' with Jerome Powell leads to unexpected endorsement

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: All right, so next week, the House will usher in Crypto Week. This is, the chamber begins to consider the Clarity Act, the Anti-CBDC and Surveillance State Act, of course, the Senate's Genius Act. Now, the goal, of course, of all of this is to make America, America the crypto capital of the world. And I can say no lawmaker on Capitol Hill has done as much as to make that a reality as my next guest, Senator Cynthia Lummis. And Senator, you know,  I gotta tell you, it's been absolutely phenomenal. I just wanna ask, could you imagine, could you have imagined the speed and the breadth of this crypto acceptance on Capitol Hill just a year ago from where we are now?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Charles, I couldn't. We were working with a banking committee that hadn't put a piece of legislation out in seven years, and here in year eight, we put out the Genius Act and got it passed the Senate. We have the House putting out market structure legislation in addition to legislation to prevent central bank digital currency. This is big stuff, and it's been a long time coming. This industry is maturing. The time is now.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: It is now, and that's why we want to discuss this digital asset tax legislation, because there's a whole lot of parts to this. But again, it's smart stuff, because listen, the more growth, we want to make sure people are protected with taxes. You want to talk about the most important parts of this?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: I do. There's a part that would prevent the double taxation of digital assets. Right now, they're taxed when they're identified, and they're taxed again when they're sold. We don't do that with things like gold and cattle. We tax them when they're sold, and so we need to change that for digital assets.  sponsoring legislation that would create a de minimis amount that people could spend. When we're using Bitcoin as a means of exchange, we want to have a de minimis amount that can be used and spent without being subject to taxation. That amount would be about $5,000 per year. So those are a couple of the main provisions.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Yeah, and the loss from wash sales, mark to market, digital asset mining stakes, charitable contributions. It's really detailed. This is smart stuff, and it's the kind of thing you want to get ahead of. I do want to ask you about a big story on Wall Street today.  The number one stock in the entire market, not just the S&P 500, not just the Russell 1000, but the entire market is NP Materials. They announced this major deal with the Pentagon to provide rare earth materials. And this is something I know you're very interested in as well.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Yeah, I'm from Wyoming. We have rare earth minerals. And tomorrow, we are dedicating the first rare earth mine that has been fully permitted and will be mining in 80 years. It's called the Ramoco Mine. It's up by Sheridan, Wyoming. I'm looking forward to being at the mine dedication along with Energy Secretary Chris Wright.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Wow, that is absolutely phenomenal. Again, I know everything in that space that you're on, you're laser focused on it. I want to shift gears here because the other big topic on Wall Street is really, it should be a big topic on Main Street, and that's Jay Powell. You also believe, along with many others, that he should resign now?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: You know, I do. We've had enough hiccups with Jay Powell. Obviously, inflation was not transitory. Obviously, other nations are now reducing their interest rates more quickly than the United States. My biggest beef with Jay Powell is the manner in which the Fed has managed bank supervision, and now we see the expenditure of an obscene amount of money.  to create a beautiful new addition and remodeling of the Federal Reserve building. It's just too much. It's time for a new Fed chairman. I would support Charles Payne for that position. Thank you. We finally have somebody who can communicate in a language that the American people understand.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Well, I appreciate that, and I appreciate everything that you're doing. Really, you are ahead of the curve. You were talking and doing things that no one thought about, again, a year ago, and they're coming to fruition. Senator Lummis, thank you very much.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: My pleasure, Charles.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: And thanks for the endorsement.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: You're welcome.

summary.SPEAKER_00: Senator Cynthia Lummis emphasises the rapid progress in crypto acceptance on Capitol Hill. She details her digital asset tax legislation, aiming to prevent double taxation, introduce a de minimis exemption for small transactions, and provide clarity on various tax treatment aspects. Lummis also discusses the opening of the first rare earth mine in Wyoming in 80 years and expresses her opposition to Jay Powell, calling for his resignation due to inflation mismanagement, bank supervision issues, and excessive spending by the Fed.
summary.SPEAKER_01: Host Charles Payne praises Senator Cynthia Lummis for her efforts in making America the crypto capital of the world. He discusses the various crypto bills being considered by Congress and highlights Lummis' digital asset tax legislation. Payne also shifts the topic to NP Materials' deal with the Pentagon and later to the criticism of Jay Powell, suggesting he should resign.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation covers crypto legislation, tax proposals, rare earth materials, and criticism of the Federal Reserve Chairman.

video_title: Larry Kudlow: President Trump was saved by the grace of God

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: All right, now we get to the normal riff, and the title of the riff is going to be, God Wanted Him to Live. That is our subject. So look, it's been nearly a year since the Butler, Pennsylvania attempted assassination of President Donald Trump. I'm going back to this unbelievable and horrible story tonight, because we have ace New York Post reporter Miranda Devine, who just interviewed Chief of Staff Susie Wiles, who told Miranda that, quote, I believe God wanted him to live.  Also this evening, we have the great Harris Faulkner, who actually interviewed President Trump just a few hours before the attempted assassination. Now, I personally have always believed that the president was saved by the grace of God. And the president himself has said several times that he was saved by God for a purpose, to make America great again.  Now let's go back to the Republican National Convention in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, where Mr. Trump spoke so movingly only five days after a bullet grazed his ear. Take a listen.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: I'm not supposed to be here tonight.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Not supposed to be here.

lines.speaker: Unidentified SPEAKER
lines.text: Yes you are!

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Yes you are! Thank you.  But I'm not. And I'll tell you, I stand before you in this arena only by the grace of Almighty God.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Wow. F-swallow hard after that one. All of a sudden, the set were out there in Wisconsin. Now, of course, six months later at his inauguration, President Trump continued his personal narrative on God's providential hand. Please take a listen.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: I felt then and believe even more so now that my life was saved for a reason. I was saved by God to make America great again.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: And now, roughly another six months after that, the list of accomplishments by President Trump and his team is remarkable, historic. Much of it encapsulated in the successful uphill battle to pass the president's one big beautiful bill with its tax cuts and deregulation and border security and national defense. Promises made, promises kept.  Even before the passage of the bill, Mr. Trump was boldly moving to reform and downsize the federal government, stop the woke culture wars of DEI and anti-Semitism, the deportation of the worst of the worst criminal illegals, a truly historic bombing mission that obliterated Iran's nuclear facilities, and his strong commitment to reciprocal free and fair trade, to level the playing field, and promote the on-shoring of manufacturing.  All this and more in just six months. The word remarkable really doesn't do it justice. Oh, and did I forget the stock market hitting all time high records all over the places we just talked about with Charles and Jerry. Mr. Trump will undoubtedly continue running his successful administration at breakneck speed, as Susie Wiles told Miranda Devine. But the one big thought, quite apart from President Trump's enormous achievement,  is the fact that God Almighty stopped a crazy America-hating kid from ending President Trump's second term even before it started. And that's my risk.

summary.SPEAKER_00: The host believes God saved President Trump from the assassination attempt. He recounts Trump's speeches crediting God with his survival and uses this as a starting point to discuss Trump's political accomplishments, portraying his administration as highly successful in fulfilling campaign promises. The host also emphasises the significance of Trump's survival in the broader political context.
summary.SPEAKER_01: President Trump stated that he believes he was saved by God for a purpose, and that he should not be alive after the assassination attempt. He emphasised this belief during his speeches at the Republican National Convention and his inauguration, highlighting how his survival has motivated him to continue his political work.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the attempted assassination of President Donald Trump, and how his survival is seen as divine intervention. The host reflects on President Trump's speeches attributing his survival to God, and uses this as a segue to highlight Trump's political achievements and to express gratitude that God allowed Trump to continue his political work.

lines.text: Joining us now is the host of My View with Lara Trump on Fox News, Lara Trump. Great to see you. Thank you so much for being here. Yeah, Jackie, what you just explained is called a scam. Whenever you're getting money for something, you shouldn't be, when you are an able-bodied person, as you just explained, or someone who isn't entitled to those benefits, you shouldn't get those benefits. I thought it was pretty amazing to hear President Trump say, you know, the only thing the Democrats do well is complain. I would actually add something to that. The other thing they do well is lie, and they have lied extensively about this bill.  This is gonna make the 2017 tax cuts permanent. Think about how impactful that will be for so many people. They were going to end, they were going to sunset, and then that would have been a huge tax increase for every single American. This strengthens our border, it strengthens our military, it makes it easier.  to do your taxes and incentivizes companies to come here into the United States and invest here in America for American workers. This is all great stuff for our country, but I think you continue to see the Democrats out there peddling lie after lie about this, because what is it that they're offering to the American people? Not a single Democrat voted for anything in this bill.  They all voted against it, and when the American people start to see the positive impact, as I asked President Trump there, when can we see it? He said, it's starting now, it's starting to happen now. They're gonna look even more foolish than they already do, because they are, every single day, working against the betterment of this country, and it's clearly to their own detriment. Just look at their polling as of late.  You know, but Laura, we both know that the Democrats lie and sometimes lies work. I mean, we've already seen the Democrat Congressional Campaign Committee. They're up with their first ad buy of the season, the digital ad buy for the 2026 midterm cycle. And it's about what they call Medicaid cuts. And I know you just laid out how, you know, that's not factual. But will those lies work? Do you worry about the impact of that? Because Americans are very protective over their health care.  Yeah, well, they've lied time after time. And look at the way—by the way, they lied about one person in particular so much. That's President Trump. I think he's probably the best weapon that we truly have as Republicans as we head into these 2026 midterms. Because you're right, Lisa, they're going to continue to peddle these lies. They're going to put ad after ad out. But think about how much they did that in the 2024 election.  Think about all the lies told about President Trump, all the lies, quite frankly, told about Kamala Harris to make her look better and look at the outcome of this election. All of the swing states, the popular vote, you know, historic landslide victory for President Trump. So I think it's up to us in the party to continue talking about the truth, to continue reminding people, hey, don't trust what the Democrats are telling you.  Trust how you feel. Do you feel safer in this country? Do you have more money in your pocket? Is your 401k going up? Do you have a better paying job? Those are all things that people are going to continue to see happen as time goes on and as this bill and everything that's in it actually takes hold here in America. So we're gonna have to keep talking about it and I think President Trump as well. He is our best weapon and he is the best, you know, he's the best salesperson for anything Republican that we have. Going forward, I'd say 26, 28 and probably beyond.  Yeah, nobody, on the Democrat side, they're not talking about the additions to defense spending, national security, the improvements at the border, all the things that are going to make us feel safer, which at this moment in time are so important. Absolutely. We also want to get to this, this weekend marking one year since the assassination attempt on President Trump, and we're learning that the Secret Service suspended six personnel for that back in February.  A Secret Service source also telling Fox that a Senate report on failures in Butler, Pennsylvania is expected to be released this week, and that President Trump has reviewed that report. Yeah, Lar, you exclusively sat down with President Trump for an interview airing this Saturday. Here's a bit from that.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: So they briefed me numerous times, the FBI, the Secret Service, sort of everybody. They should have had somebody in the building.  That was a mistake. They should have had communications with the local police. They weren't tied in. But I was satisfied in terms of the bigger plot, the larger plot. I was satisfied. And, you know, I have great confidence in these people.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Laura, you almost lost your father-in-law. We almost lost President Trump. We still know so little about Thomas Matthew Crooks, the guy who tried to assassinate him. 20 years old, yet he had three encrypted messaging applications hosted on servers in Belgium, Germany, and New Zealand. Has the President told you, will we find out more about him? Does he want to know more about him? Why do you think we don't have more information at this point?  And that's sort of how I led into that question, actually, with him. I said, look, we all remember that there were congressional members who visited constantly in the weeks following that assassination attempt. That space there in Butler, we heard time after time, we're going to get to the bottom of it. But I think the American people are kind of still waiting to get to the bottom of it. I'm very encouraged to hear the fact  that hopefully we get this Senate report. I think that will maybe go quite a long ways with the American people. But, you know, to hear the president, and as I know him, my father-in-law, say that he's satisfied with the information he has, that does make me, as his daughter-in-law, feel better. That makes me, as an American, feel better. I think if we can  Expose that to the American people. I think it'll be a big thing because we do all still have a lot of questions What I can tell you is that the new Secret Service director Sean Curran is doing a great job He is on top of everything I visited the Secret Service training center myself for for my show a couple months ago And it's pretty incredible to see what they're doing out there and the way they're training These incredible men and women of the United States Secret Service. So going forward. I think they know the mistakes that happen I think we all saw a lot of those mistakes and I do not think that they will  be repeated. And congrats on the success of your show, Laura.  And I would just say this.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00

So Laura, it's so great to see you. And we're so glad that he is safe and he's president of the United States. So thanks for joining us. Amen. Thank you, ladies. Appreciate it.

The debate centers around the bill's impact on healthcare, taxes, and the economy, with both sides engaging in name-calling and accusations of lying. video_title: Texas flood victims remembered following 'unimaginable' tragedy

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: all in our community, as we know it is a long road ahead to rebuild the many places we love across the Guadalupe River. For the unsung heroes in our community, that God's spirit would give them the endurance to do the work that he has given them to do.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: That was Kerrville, Texas, Youth Minister Wyatt Wintreck at a vigil attended by hundreds of mourners honoring the dead, the missing, and the heroes of Kerrville, Texas. You were looking at a video a short time ago of a search and rescue operation that is underway today. Search and rescue is still continuing. Crews are searching along the Guadalupe River for the 176 people still missing.  after the devastating July 4th flood. The total death toll at this hour stands at 120. Among those are at least 36 children. 2100 responders from federal, state, and local agencies are on the ground. Texas Governor Greg Abbott is vowing to continue the search efforts until every person is accounted for. And President Trump is scheduled to go to Camp Mystic tomorrow, the Christian camp that lost at least 26 campers to that vicious flooding. The human toll is immeasurable.  It is heartbreaking. AccuWeather estimates the cost of the cleanup and the rebuilding effort for this, $22 billion. Joining me now is a Texas real estate developer and philanthropist who's got a very personal connection of the tragedy in Kerrville, Rastegar Property Company CEO Ari Rastegar. I want to start with the fact that you have a very personal connection to Camp Mystic.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: I mean, it's still pretty difficult to even wrap your head around it. And you know, being from Dallas yourself, you know, where I grew up in the University Park area, Camp Mystic is a staple in the community. And so knowing several people that we grew up with that had children, family, friends,  I mean, it's truly just unimaginable. And I look at the, one of the systemic issues is floodplains. So as a developer, you know, when we build these large tracts of land, you know, you go through these hundred year floodplain plans, 500 year flood year plans. And I hope the real takeaway from this, aside from the obvious, is the state starts to take a much deeper look  at what we once called 100-year or 500-year floodplains that had maybe a 1% chance or a 0.2% chance. Camp Mystic part of it was in the 500-year floodplain. So I think this is going to create a real dialogue of what is and what isn't a floodplain per se.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: I do want to just honor the memory of Hadley Hannah. She's eight years old. You went to school with her mother. I just want to say that our prayers and thoughts are with her family, who've asked for privacy, but also for all of the children that have been lost, and the counselors, and the tremendous loss of life. It continues to be a heartbreaking story day to day. You mentioned something that I think is crucial. This was a 100-year flood event.  that it's unprecedented. But from a when you look at from a developer standpoint, how do you say yourself? Obviously, no one wants to ever see this happen again. And you mentioned that what six million people in Texas are in flood zones.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Correct.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: So how do we safeguard against that? How do we see this again?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: I think the thing that we can look at if we zoom out just a little bit is what we had called before. I think this is a great time to start using AI models and using some of these mechanics to figure out  Did the variables just change if this was 100 year or 500 year floodplain episode? And with 6 million people, 6 million Texans that live within these floodplains that are supposed to be 1% or 0.2% probability, I think this really disrupts the model. It's where we need to start thinking about more infrastructure, more safeguards, and reevaluating what we call floodplains in general.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: How long do you think it's going to take to rebuild Kerrville, the surrounding areas?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: I mean, you're talking right now. I mean, there's over $20 billion of costs that we just see on the front end. We haven't even recovered the bodies yet. So it's going to be years. It's going to be years, and it's not going to be pretty.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Yeah, no, there's a lot of people there that that is their home and they're not going anywhere. And once they get through this tragedy, then they've got to look at how to, you know, eventually move forward. Well, you know, we saw something similar with Superstorm Sandy, which was this freak event that took hundreds of people's hundreds of innocent lives here in the New York City area. You know, we're looking at a different situation here in New York with our  real estate picture. And I know that this is another national story. We just had on Curtis Lee, who's running for mayor in the city. But they're trying to do this thing where they want to, he wants to freeze the rent, hit the real estate community, hit the, you know, this hits not just  large-scale buildings, but this could be mom and pop landlords. Do you worry when you see a city like New York that could be going down a very dark path with something like this?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: I do, and I think there's a few points to look at. One is, if you give this rent relief, so to speak, yes, there are millions of people that would be saving a lot of money on the short term, but you can't freeze rents  to fix a housing shortage. So what I worry about is, first of all, you're going to disincentivize developers. Because if you can't raise rents at least enough to meet the inflationary limits of 2%, which is apparently the Fed chair's limit,  developers aren't going to build. And then the other problem is, if developers can't raise rents, you're going to have a big deferred maintenance plan, meaning landlords might not be upkeeping the building as well because they don't have enough of the finances to be able to fix the plumbing and the mechanics. So you wake up five years from now with affordability issue, less housing, and a higher affordability issue. So it's like, you know, finding a very, very short-sighted temporary solution, maybe to win a mayoral race,  and not addressing the larger problem for New York, which is over 500,000 units that are desperately needed. So you're going to shoot the developers in the foot to fix a problem that doesn't fix it?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: I know we have to go, but these are the policies, whether it's New York or California, that have driven people out of these cities, and in particular, the Californians that have headed to Dallas. You mentioned University Park. I mean, that area has exploded with people from California who said that they had to get out of California, and they chose Texas.  And it is a great state, and we both love our state. And I'm so glad that you were here today, Ari. And we're going to be following everything down there very closely. Ari Rastegar, great to see you again.

summary.SPEAKER_01: The host honours the victims, highlights the ongoing search and rescue efforts, and the immense human and economic toll of the flood. She also shifts the focus to discuss strategies for safeguarding against future floods and the broader implications of climate change on floodplain predictions.
summary.SPEAKER_02: Ari Rastegar, a Texas real estate developer, expresses grief over the loss of life, particularly at Camp Mystic. He emphasises the need to reevaluate floodplain models using AI, as current 100-year and 500-year floodplain predictions seem outdated and inadequate. Rastegar also warns about the potential consequences of rent control policies in New York City, arguing they could disincentivise development and worsen housing shortages.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the devastating July 4th flood in Kerrville, Texas, its impact, and potential long-term solutions.

video_title: Kevin Hassett SLAMS Federal Reserve for ‘absence of transparency'

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Last night we talked about the need for complete reform and cleansing and perestroika of the Federal Reserve System in connection with an important Wall Street Journal article. We interviewed Kevin Warsh Monday. Tonight we interview National Economic Council Director, my good friend, Kevin Hassett. So that's pretty good. Both Kevins in one week. Kevin Hassett, we talked last night on the show.  and have talked a lot before, how the Federal Reserve System in the age of Trump, the Federal Reserve System should go through the same downsizing, the same transformations, the same perestroika that other federal agencies have gone through. And yet there's no sign of it.  And I think a new Fed chairman, whether it's you or Kevin Walsh or whoever it may be, it's incumbent on you to take a look at this, because so far it's the same old models that haven't worked for 50 years with a lot of dead wood, you know, let alone the fact that they should be cutting interest rates. The president had another Truth Social ad on it today. They should be cutting rates. But even larger point than that, where's the downsizing? Where's the reforming?  Where is the auditing of the Fed?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Right. Well, I think that you're right, Larry. And the bottom line is that President Trump's objective is to take all of government and make it better and make it work better for the American people. And government has gotten very big throughout Washington. And one of the places that hasn't really responded yet to the downsizing that you're talking about is the Federal Reserve.  And I'm sure that whatever new leadership the president chooses for the new Federal Reserve, that they're going to pay close attention to the runaway spending, to the actual losses after years and years of profits, and so on. And with respect to interest rates, I think that everybody always understands that the Federal Reserve is an independent agency, but the president is allowed to speak his mind. But, also, you should look at the data.  And so one of the things, for example, you could do is look at what the European Central Bank has done with interest rates. And over time, those are highly, highly correlated with what happens here in the U.S. And so they've cut rates a lot. And if you were to take the rate cuts that they had and do the normal correlation for current Fed policy, then the current Federal Reserve rate would be about 3.  And so the president is wondering, why is it that the normal correlations seem to be breaking down right now, precisely while he's president? And I think that there's been an unfortunate pattern of perhaps not independent Federal Reserve taking actions where they, you know, cut right before the previous election, hiked right after he was elected last time.  And right now seem to be falling behind the curve compared to what other central banks are doing. I think that that raises the specter that they're not being nonpartisan, they're not being independent. And that's something that I'm sure the president is going to address in his next set of nominations.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: I mean, actually, surveys have shown from the Federal Election Committee that over 80 percent of the Fed staff donates to the Democratic Party. So there's another political point there. I really loved your point about Europe correlating Europe with the United States. The European Central Bank, I believe their overnight rate is now 2 percent. Ours is 4.5 percent. And yet our inflation rates are very similar here in the States.  Since January, for example, the CPI is 1.4% at an annual rate, something like that. So, right. Why are those interest rates deferentials? Someone's got to explain that. J-PAL never talks about that. He's too busy yapping about trade policy and tariffs and inflation, stuff he knows nothing about, and it's not the Fed's remit.  You know, Kevin here, look, the reason I want to see a thorough transformation, a thorough overhaul of the Fed, a house cleaning and a cleansing, if you will, is that these, you know, they are not an all-powerful central planning agency. They do not run the world, and their models are completely outdated. They've been outdated for almost 50 years, for heaven's sakes. Somebody's got to come in there and change all of that.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Right. Well, the bottom line is that the Federal Reserve has made a lot of errors, policy errors in recent years, and they haven't really explained where the errors came from. And so what I would like to see in any agency, any government agency, and you remember when I was chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, this was the highest priority as you worked with me in the White House, is that when we said something's going to be 3 percent,  We put out the model that explains why we think it's going to be 3%. If we get the number wrong, we explain what was wrong with our model. We reevaluate our models over time. And so one of the things that I find disappointing is that the Federal Reserve has been, as you say, yapping, but they've been talking on and on about the impact of tariffs on inflation, and yet they've not published a model that shows, like, what is the impact that they're concerned about.  that is causing interest rates to be, like, highly, you know, different from what they normally would be, given where interest rates around the world are. And so I think it's incumbent on anybody in government, if they've got strong policy positions, to explain where those positions come from and to, when they, you know, have things happen, like inflation get out of control, explain what they got wrong and why. And I think that the absence of transparency at the Fed is something that the president is highly valuing as he's thinking about what his next step should be.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: You know, I'm very concerned. And again, I think there's a lot of evidence that the growing large staff of the Federal Reserve and the reserve banks, I want to get to the district reserve banks in a minute. The large staff is very hostile to Mr. Trump's ideas.  very hostile to supply-side economics, for example, or growth economics. I mean, they're always targeting the same 1.8 percent that the Congressional Budget Office is targeting. Something's got to be done. Someone's got to do an audit of the Fed staff, who they are, what they're promoting, and, as you say, why their models aren't more transparent. The other thing I want to ask you about, you've got these district reserve banks, again,  Many of them, most of them if I'm not mistaken, have been appointed by Democratic presidents, Obama and Biden, and I think their biases are very much against President Trump and his program. I don't want to overstate it. I'm not here to make an audit of every Reserve Bank president, but they are appointed, however,  with the consent of the President of the United States. There is a process that goes through there. And, of course, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. So here, too, is another avenue nobody looks at. Who are these folks? What are their staffs like? What kind of models do they produce? Et cetera, et cetera. This is part of the opening and the, really, the, you know, reforming the Federal Reserve System, just like other agencies are being reformed throughout the government.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: I'd like to finish responding to that with an anecdote, because you remember that I worked with Alan Greenspan as a Fed staffer back when I was a young economist. And at the time, President Clinton was in the White House, and he proposed a BTU tax. Do you remember that? And then I got to noodling about a BTU tax, and I wrote an academic paper about how to think about a BTU tax, which was ultimately published in a peer-reviewed journal. Alan Greenspan wouldn't let the Fed publish the paper.  He wouldn't let the Fed publish the paper until all the legislative action on the BTU tax had been completed, because he didn't want the Fed to stick its nose into fiscal policy. He didn't want the Fed to look like it was intervening in the thinking of Washington. And so think about how different that view of what the Fed should be doing, when it's focused on monetary policy, maintaining its independence, how different that is from the Fed that we see today. It's very disappointing to me.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: All right. Well, we'll see how this plays out. But anyway, very many thanks, Kevin Hassett, NEC director. We appreciate it very much.

summary.SPEAKER_00: Acknowledges the need for Fed reform and downsizing. Agrees that the Fed has made policy errors and lacks transparency. Highlights the discrepancy between US and European interest rates and suggests the Fed should be more data-driven. Criticises the Fed for intervening in fiscal policy and emphasises the importance of independence and model transparency. Recalls an anecdote about Alan Greenspan to illustrate the Fed's past commitment to independence.
summary.SPEAKER_01: Calls for a complete overhaul of the Fed due to outdated models, dead wood, and political bias. Argues the Fed staff is overwhelmingly Democratic and hostile to Trump's ideas. Suggests cutting interest rates, auditing the Fed, and examining the appointments and staff of district reserve banks. Emphasises the need for transparency and accountability.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the need for reform, downsizing, and increased transparency at the Federal Reserve System. Both speakers criticise the Fed's outdated models, perceived political bias, and lack of accountability. They argue that the Fed should be more independent, explain its policy errors, and align its interest rate decisions with global trends.

video_title: If Dems cared about illegal immigrants, they would fight trafficking at the border: GOP lawmaker

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: We are normalizing a government agency disappearing people. They are kidnapping people and transporting them to concentration camps. It's a concentration camp what they're doing, and they are disappearing people. A government agency is disappearing people. Getting carted off to concentration camps. This BS administration is kidnapping people. It has nothing to do with my language. Carted off to concentration camps.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Okay, former MSNBC anchor Tiffany Cross now claiming ICE agents are making arrests and taking them to concentration camps. Let's welcome to the show Florida Republican Congresswoman Anna Paulina Luna. Congresswoman, that is some really strong language, I would say easily bordering on the reckless. Your response to it.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Look, it's simply not true. And I would say that this is not uncommon, though, for Democrats. They're still trying to recover from the last election, where they lost not just the national popular vote, but also the electoral college. What I will tell you is, interestingly enough, they're not mentioning the fact that it's actually a billionaire communist by the name of Neville Singham.  who is actually behind funding these and bankrolling these immigration riots, where they put, instead of BLM flags, Mexican flags. They don't actually care about Hispanic Americans. They don't care about illegals. If they did, they would want to fight border – what was happening at the border with trafficking, and they would support a border wall. But they don't. So this is nothing more than propaganda for the midterms. They're running on this. And instead of running on BLM, which is what they ran on previous to 2020, they're running on immigration, and it's not going to work.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: You know, it's a lot of obfuscation, I would say, on their part. On the other hand, ICE and the DHS are being really transparent about who they've been arresting. Look at this. ICE New Orleans announcing they deported a Jamaican national with criminal convictions for rape and sexual assault.  ICE Atlanta arrested a Mexican national accused of sexual battery. ICE in Texas announced they arrested a convicted pedophile. ICE in Nebraska even announcing the arrest of an MS-13 kingpin who's on El Salvador's top 100 most wanted list. They posted a video of the arrest. Watch this.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Get out. Get out. Walk back to me. Come on back. Come on back.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Congresswoman, I'm looking at that list. I'm looking at this video. I'm thinking to myself, that's what ICE is supposed to be doing. Your thoughts?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Correct. But there's a reason why they're not talking about this, right? You're not seeing Democrats go out there and say, we're arresting Jamaican nationals. We're arresting people from China that are here illegally that are bringing in agro bioweapons to kill Americans and farm produce. They're not talking about that. The reason they're not talking about that, though, and what I'm trying to prove here,  The largest voting minority in the country are Hispanic Americans, specifically those of Mexican descent. And that's exactly why you're seeing the footage strategically placed. It's why you're seeing them unfold brand-new Mexican flags and handing them out at these rights. So it's not actually about a substantive conversation. It's about propaganda. And, look, I'm a Mexican-American. I'm a second-generation U.S. citizen. And what I will tell you is, it's egregiously offensive.  that they try to say that only illegals are Hispanic, because in actuality, we know that there have been Chinese military-age males coming here. There's been people from the Middle East and Africa, but they're not talking about that. So stay awake, stay aware, and make sure that you're not buying the propaganda, because that's what this is.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: You know, I don't think the propaganda is very effective, frankly. I think it's meant to generate votes and win political support. I don't think it's going to work. What do you think?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: I would tell you that President Trump won the largest voting margin for Hispanic Americans in a very, very long time, I think an even larger margin than President Bush at the time. So what I will tell you is it's going to backfire, but it's our responsibility in the media, it's our responsibility as elected officials to educate people, because unfortunately  Sometimes our people are just seeing what they see on the internet as basically gospel, and they won't verify it. But it's really offensive. It's gross. And again, you see that Democrats really want cheap labor. They're talking about who's going to pick the crops if we deport all illegals, which is offensive. And that's not my words. That's theirs.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Right. Congresswoman Ana Paulina Luna, we really appreciate your perspective. Thanks for joining us tonight.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Thanks.

summary.SPEAKER_00: Moderates the discussion, presents ICE arrest data of individuals with criminal convictions, and questions the effectiveness and motives behind the inflammatory rhetoric and selective portrayal of ICE actions.
summary.SPEAKER_01: Claims ICE agents are kidnapping people and transporting them to concentration camps, likening the situation to government-sponsored disappearance.
summary.SPEAKER_02: Denies the claims, calling them Democratic propaganda. Accuses Democrats of using immigration as a political tactic, funded by a billionaire communist, and strategically highlighting Hispanic arrests for political gain. Emphasises ICE's role in arresting dangerous individuals but argues the narrative is skewed.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses claims of ICE abuse, political propaganda surrounding immigration, and the portrayal of ICE arrests.

video_title: It’s ‘WELL BEYOND TIME’ for answers on Trump assassination attempt: Miranda Devine

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Joining us now, the aforementioned Harris Faulkner and the great Harris Faulkner, host of the Faulkner Focus and co-host of Outnumbered on Fox News, and ace New York Post columnist Miranda Devine, Fox News contributor, host of the Pod Force One podcast. Welcome, ladies. I really appreciate your doing this. Harris, we have tape from this. You're interviewing him. Back then, a year ago almost,  I guess a couple hours before all this happened. We have tape on this. We have tape on it. It's another Harris Faulkner ace interview. Watch this.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: I don't want to belittle it because it's a very important position, especially if something bad should happen. But that's the most important. If something bad should happen.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: If something, if something, all right, we lost. If something bad should happen. And then let's play the tape, Miranda's podcast with Susie Wiles commenting on should something bad ever happen? Here it comes.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Do you ever look back at that and think that it was divine intervention?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: 100%. And I think in a candid moment, he would say so. Because I believe God wanted him to live.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Well, I do too, as I said. Miranda, interviewing with Susie Wiles. She believes God wanted her to live. What do you think about all that? How was the interview with Susie Wiles, especially this part of it?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Look, wonderful. And she was very warm and open. And she's a woman of faith. And I thought what you said was wonderful. And I agree with you wholeheartedly, as does Susie Wiles, as does the president, it seems.  He has talked about it himself. It's not something, as she says, you know, your faith is private. It's not something you really wear on your sleeve if you're a person like Donald Trump. But something changed in him that day. And he realised, I think, from what she says and from what I perceive, that he's here for a purpose and for a mission. And so I think he's redoubled his interest in saving America.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Harris Faulkner, you, too, are a woman, a person of faith, for sure. What do you make of all this? You've never really talked about this directly. What do you make of all this?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Well, first of all, I just want to thank the good Lord that our president made it.  I really understood that day how close it was because the bullet was just right there. And he had just been right there in front of me for four hours. We joked that until Joe Rogan, I was his longest interview on that day. And of course, I got eclipsed during later stages of the campaign. But we talked about everything. And we were in his home.  in Mar-a-Lago. We weren't someplace that had been staged for TV other than some lights. And there were people in the house, and it was a warm atmosphere. And Susie Wiles was there. She was in the living room area. And it was just an amazing, beautiful day. I'd never been to West Palm Beach. And all of it was just so warm. And we were laughing. I remember how much laughter there was before, during, and after the interview.  and how joyfully excited he was to go to Butler, Pennsylvania. Harris, do you want to go? Yeah. I'm like, oh my goodness, I have this whole team, but I'm sure I could explain dumping them. What I loved about those moments were, and all the times I have interviewed anybody at that stature, and Clinton was my first presidential interview, so that was an interesting story for another time. God was involved there too, but in a different way.  So, but for Trump, he had this awareness of something that we didn't know at the time. And that was how many threats were against him. And so when I asked him about making that decision, and you know, there'd been a little criticism about who he might choose for vice president. Well, he always, everything is like the end of The Apprentice.  You know, so he kind of draws that attention, yeah. But there was just a shift, and you see him lean in there, and he says, but if something bad should happen. Right, right. And then he says it again, and then he says it slightly phrased differently, but again. That ran on a loop that night. Wow. I mean, within two and a half hours of his departure, they were on the ground already.  and on their way to the stage, and as I saw it unfold in my hotel room, my team and I were getting ready to head to the convention, because it was a tight squeeze. That was Saturday, and we had to be on the air that Sunday evening from there. And I just, right before it happened, I just thought, oh, I wonder if he had time to really process all that laughter, because it was just so much fun.  And I see it across the screen on Fox. And I hit my knees. And I said, what do you mean? Like, I couldn't even take the pictures in. I could hear one of my crews screaming down the hall. And I said, yeah, this is real. This is really happening.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: And Susie Wiles thought that he was dead. I mean, I was here in Fox in the makeup room watching on TV. And the hairdresser and I both just screamed, he's dead. It looked like he was dead, because he was down for so long.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: At that point in the interview with her, what did she say? Some of it was covered in your column in today's Post. By the way, you only had one page in the Post today. Usually, you're the first eight pages. Very disappointing. I had two pages yesterday. But we're glad you're here at all. But what was the context? Susie thought he was dead and, and, and?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, Susie was there, and then she saw it happen, and she said, I thought he was dead. And then he stood up, and he raised his fist in the air, and she just said, my heart just broke. And she ran to the car. Then they were bundled off. But she then went through how miraculous it was that, you know, she said, normally in the rallies, the screen's on the other side. Normally in the rallies, he does the screen at the end.  But for some reason, he changed the order spontaneously. And do you remember, he called up Dave McCormick, the senator, well, senator prospective for Pennsylvania, and got him, said, come up. And Dave stood up and was walking towards the stage. And then, for some reason, Donald Trump changed his mind. And he decided to go to... So Dave McCormick could have been up there with him. Yeah. I mean, the whole thing is too horrible to think about.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Uh, you know, Contemporary... Cory can... Yeah, Cory, Contemporary, passed. His wife, Helen, has given a recent interview with Fox News, and she said that they were all just sitting ducks.  that it could have been anyone that day. And of course, the news with the six who've been suspended with the Secret Service came out just a few hours ago today. And so that's been breaking news for us here on Fox. But she just talked about everybody being focused that day and joyful and all of that, and that it could have been anyone who was hit. And of course, her beloved is gone.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: She wants answers. Yes, we all want answer a just that a year later. Do you think we're on her behalf?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: I know what I read, but what I read is very sparse really I mean I still don't feel I mean I just know he's some crazy America hating kid I  But I don't know beyond that.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Look how many of those are around us now.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Who's he in cahoots with, for example? We don't know that. We've never figured anything.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: We've been told nothing. And I remember the first interview I did with President Trump after he won, a couple of months after he won on Air Force One. I asked him about it and he turned to someone there in the cabin and he said,  He said, find out, because I deserve to know. Now, he still doesn't know, because the Secret Service deferred to the FBI, and the FBI has not released anything. I believe they're going to release something soon, but it's well beyond time.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Do you remember at the RNC convention, they were trying to track down the Secret Service then head, Kimberly Cheadle.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Remember her? Yes.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: So I had just interviewed with Senator Marsha Blackburn after the chase. Remember, they were chasing Kimberly Chief. For some reason, she showed up and wanted to be part of the fanfare. Like, why would you go to the convention and not expect people would want to know about your team that you were leading? And where were the failures that led to a president being shot and grazed in the ear?  and someone dying and others being injured. Like, where were you? I don't know what she thought, but Senator Blackburn and others physically chased her down to try to get answers. I think we should still be doing that with members of Biden's team. I mean, in a very helpful way, do it with the law books and not physically chasing them in five-inch heels like the senator. But why are we not pressing as a wider public?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: And it should be bipartisan. Well, you remember the New York Times, CNN, et cetera, all said, oh, he wasn't really almost assassinated. It was even the FBI director at the time, Comey, said it was just shrapnel.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: And it's breakneck speed. I don't wanna lose the thought of your interview. You two are fabulous, by the way, and I'm graced to have you here to talk about this.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: And with her, are you kidding?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Fabulous. But it's breakneck speed. That was one of the things Susie Wiles said. I know all about that breakneck speed case, having worked in the first term, but the second term is much more orderly. I think that is true. I think Susie Wiles is a brilliant woman. I think she's very smart, by the way, not to go on the Sunday talk shows every week.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Yes.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: The way a lot of these people do in the past. I'll give you the last word on that because I'm looking for more breakneck breakneck speech as we move ahead. I don't think the one big beautiful bill. Fine. OK we've got that done now. Let's go on to other things.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, look, he's had a few wins in the Supreme Court, so that's going to clear some of the logjams. She says that Donald Trump works, he's at superhuman energy, hard to keep up. He's not going to take his foot off the accelerator. And she creates this calm, orderly environment for him. She said to me her job is to take care of problems before they hit his desk, so he has the clear mind and the space to be able to work out solutions.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: That's a great line, I saw it.  I want him to have plenty of time for Big Think. We'll take care of the back office stuff. I just lost it. I would do this for another 20 minutes. Miranda Devine and Harris Faulkner. You can catch Harris hosting the Faulkner Focus weekdays at 11 a.m. Eastern on Fox News and just read the New York Post for heaven's sakes to see Miranda.

summary.SPEAKER_01: Hosts the conversation, shares her interview with the former President where he discussed the importance of his VP pick, and recounts the harrowing events of the assassination attempt. She expresses her shock and gratitude for his survival, and emphasises the need for answers from the Secret Service and FBI.
summary.SPEAKER_02: Columnist who interviewed Susie Wiles, the former President's campaign manager. She discusses Wiles' beliefs in divine intervention, the former President's changed outlook on life and purpose post-attack, and the chaos and security failures that day. She also highlights the lack of media coverage and bipartisan demand for answers.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses a former President's near-assassination, the divine intervention he believes saved him, and the subsequent lack of answers and accountability surrounding the incident. It also touches on his renewed focus and energy for his political mission.

video_title: NYC mayoral candidate Curtis Sliwa: I am saving residential neighborhoods

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Well, the New York mayoral race is heating up. The latest poll from political consulting firm Slingshot Strategy shows Democratic nominees Orrin Mundani ahead with 35% of the vote. Behind him, former New York Governor Andrew Cuomo, 25%. Current Mayor Eric Adams has fallen to the bottom at 11%, behind longtime Republican candidate Curtis Sliwa. Guardian Angels founder Curtis Sliwa joins me now live in our studio. And Curtis, I just want to add here, you were just endorsed by the New York City Council Republican delegation.  What is your strategy to stay in this race and beat Mamdani, Adams, and Cuomo?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Well, first off, I'm a major party candidate. I'm the Republican candidate that also has an independent line, first ever in electoral politics. Protect animals, which will get a lot of cross-party support if you don't want to vote for a Republican. No-kill shelters and put animal abusers in jail. That's something that resonates with people.  My strategy is I'm the mayor of the outer boroughs because both Zoran Mondami, Adams, and Andrew Cuomo, they want to basically support the developers going out there and doing away with residential neighborhoods as we know them. I'm the one defending residential neighborhoods. They call it City of Yes here.  Day one, I get elected. I'm repealing the city of yes. I'm saving the residential neighborhoods, which is where the blue collar working class live. They're the ones who have decided to improve, not move. Look, billionaires and zillionaires, they missed the boat by backing Cuomo. And now they're on the rebound and they're backing Eric Adams, who's last in the polls as sitting mayor.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Okay, let's talk about this. There's definitely been some infighting between Andrew Cuomo and Eric Adams on who should be on the ballot, okay? Here is what Mayor Adams told me on Tuesday on Mornings with Maria. Watch this. I wanna ask you this. There are some, obviously, you've got Andrew Cuomo. You've said that he called you and asked you to drop out. And your response was, again?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: If I were to use that term on air, they'd probably censor us. But the bottom line is,  I'm the city mayor, and he set up this scenario. He knew what he was doing. He knew Mudani was going to be on the ballot, no matter what, on the Rookins family lines. He knew I was going to be on the ballot. So why would he put himself on the ballot after the election? He should have won the primary. You don't spend $25 million, a 32-point poll lead, and feel you're not going to go out and campaign. That was wrong to do.  He had his opportunity. Give me an opportunity. I'm going to win this race and I'm going to and continue the city moves forward and for one reason only. I love New York.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: So obviously he told Cuomo no. Has Andrew Cuomo asked you to drop out of the race?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: First of all, he doesn't live in New York. He lives in Fort Lee, New Jersey. Everybody knows that about Eric Adams. Secondly, nobody's called me. You know, Eric Adams says he gets calls from God, you know, to tell him he should continue on in the campaign. I am in this race till November 4th. I am the designated Republican candidate, the time to have dropped out of the race.  would have been two weeks ago. Now, you get matching funds, you'd have to give it all back. You're still on the line. This is... This makes no sense. And when Eric Adams was responding to you, he was in the middle of a schoolyard fight with Andrew Cuomo. We're in the Hamptons, with the rich and the privileged, who have no impact on this race. Where was Curtis Sliwa? In Coney Island, with the blue-collar, working-class people. That's where this election will be won.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Zor Mamdani has picked up this momentum and again defeated very handily Andrew Cuomo because of the issue of affordability. If you look at data from Realtor.com, the median ASCII rent in New York City of 5.6% right now over last year, $3,397. Landlords and real estate executives are saying, look, they're going to have to flee. They can't afford to stay. They can't afford  to see this rent freeze that Mondani is pitching, okay? And to be clear here, the rent-stabilized market is... That's 2.4 million New York City residents that have rent stabilized. So they're thinking, great, you're gonna leave me alone. But the critics and many real estate professionals saying that Mondani is targeting the wrong people, because if you put in rent freezes,  Those buildings are going to fall apart, because those landlords, especially the smaller ones, aren't going to be able to afford the upkeep. You're going to see even worse conditions for these. He's actually pitching something that would harm those rent-stabilized renters.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: I hope that makes sense, but that's the underlying story.  Nobody would have known who Zoran Mandami was until Eric Adams failed as the sitting mayor, who, by the way, kept raising property taxes all the way. You had your greatest flight of wealth in the last two years. You had $21 billion of capital.  with 125,000 wealthy men and women flee to Florida. We can't blame Zorhan for that. That started with Eric Adams. So this is a continuation. This is what Democrats do. They raise fees, fines, taxes. I'll cut the property taxes, especially for the small landlords. For seniors, if you make less than $100,000, you'll pay no property taxes. We have to give relief so that people will stay and not flee. Now, I grant it.  If Zoran Mondani becomes the mayor, Kurt Russell will have to come out of retirement and do the sequel of Escape from New York Part 2.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: But, you know, he's also proposing to raise, well, first off, let me back up. Pennsylvania Senator John Fetterman today was asked about Mondani. I mean, this is the talk of the Democrats, and this is a national story to be clear what's happening in New York, and that is why you were here on a national network. But he said he's not a Democrat.  And he said, for the Republicans, Zora Mamdani is like Christmas in July because of these extreme progressive policies. I want to throw that out there. But he also is saying, I'm going to raise the corporate taxes to 11.5 percent. Businesses are going to flee the city. They've already, that's why you've got this amount of money. So, and you say what to that? Would you raise taxes on businesses in New York City? Do you want, do you want the millionaires and the billionaires to stay in New York City? Don't they fund services?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Of course, I'd like them to stay, but they already have one foot out the door. They've moved half their business to either Florida, North Carolina, South Carolina, Georgia, Texas, Tennessee. They're hedging their bets. I'm more concerned about the small landlords, the mid-sized landlords, the small mom-and-pop shops. We walk outside of the Fox News channel here on 6th Avenue, the gateway to the world.  Look at all the small stores that have brown paper on their windows that are closing each and every day. We lock up toothpaste in New York City under Eric Adams and not criminals.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: But I will say, and I talked about this with the mayor on Tuesday, but crime is down. I mean, if you look on the statistics here today.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: I'm glad I'm entertaining you. Wait a second. I'm in all 350 neighborhoods. No other candidate is there. I ride the subways every day. Find me a New Yorker who says they're safer. Are you kidding? Their number one concern is crime and the subways and they can't go out at night. Of course, Eric Adams is going to say that. He says it's a perception. It's all in our mind. Well, if you walk around with 10 NYPD armed police officers everywhere, you're going to be safe and secure.  I don't have any security. And I'm the only guy who's been targeted for an attack, shot by the mob in 1992. And then here's Zora and Mondami saying everybody should have social workers, no cops. And yet, who travels with them now? Off-duty, armed NYPD police officers with guns. They are all sanctimonious hypocrites. It's do as I say, but not as I do.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: We'll say, though, the stats do show that murders and felonies are down in the city. I just want to say that. But let's talk about something else here. Because, you know, if you look at overall, let's talk about crime. The Guardian Angels, in particular, during the pandemic, you really reemerged on the scene. And that's when you ran again for mayor because New Yorkers didn't feel safe, were not safe. In particular, you mentioned the subways. Here's the thing. If Zora Mundani says defund the police,  You're the anti-defund the police. Would you fund the police more? Oh, of course. Do you feel that you have support from NYPD? Do you feel that you have support from that voting bloc?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Absolutely. The men and women of the department. I would hire 7,000 more police officers. Now you say hi. How?  Jimmy Dolan, Madison Square Garden, pays no corporate property tax. Why? Because of his friends, the Democrats. You know, friend of Andrew Cuomo, friend of Eric Adam. He doesn't pay his fair share. And then you have Columbia and NYU buy a private property that has nothing to do with teaching or housing his students. They're in the real estate business. Hey, Columbia, NYU, $400 million apiece. We can hire 7,000 badly needed cops that we got to get out into the street.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Why is recruitment down for NYPD right now?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Because qualified immunity, which is the insurance that all civil servants have, was stripped from them by Cuomo, Adams, the city council, and the state legislature. Yet they're all protected by qualified immunity.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Curtis Lee, we'll come back any time.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Oh, this is going to be a long campaign. We've got till November. I'm not going anywhere. I'm the Republican candidate and the only one with Republican values.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Curtis Lee, well, great to see you again, sir. Thank you for being here.

summary.SPEAKER_00: Mayor Eric Adams defends his leadership, criticises Cuomo for interference, and downplays the significance of recent poll numbers. He asserts his commitment to public safety but acknowledges the city's challenges.
summary.SPEAKER_01: Curtis Sliwa emphasises his support for residential neighbourhoods, animal welfare, and anti-crime measures. He criticises Mundani and Cuomo for their progressive policies, which he believes will harm businesses and landlords. Sliwa vows to repeal the "City of Yes", cut property taxes, fund the police by increasing taxes on wealthy institutions, and highlights his own experiences with crime.
summary.SPEAKER_03: The interviewer moderates the discussion, highlighting poll numbers, rent control policies, crime statistics and asking questions about Sliwa's stance on various issues, the challenges faced by NYPD, and his plans for funding and support.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the New York mayoral race, focussing on Republican candidate Curtis Sliwa's strategies, criticisms of Democratic front-runners Orrin Mundani and Andrew Cuomo, and key issues like crime, housing, and taxes.

video_title: 'Wall Street and the stock market believes the economy will remain fine' says Charles Payne

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: So the stock market is booming. That's right, it is booming. Tariffs or no tariffs? It is booming, all right? Let's talk with Charles Payne, host of Making Money, right here on Fabulous Fox Business, and Jerry Willis, our Fabulous Fox Business correspondent.  Welcome, kids. Welcome, welcome. Thank you. All right, it's booming. You got records, S&P record, NASDAQ. I don't know, Dow's not too far away. Industrials, stocks are booming. Growth stocks are booming. Economic sensitive stock, pretty much everything's booming. It's fun to have booming stock. What's going on here?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Everything's wonderful and nothing hurts. You know, you heard all about how the tariffs were going to kill the economy, kill stocks. You know, your 401K was going to go into the toilet. And guess what? We had a tariff announcement today, and it's still going up, right? So professional investors, they allow themselves to change their minds on a whim. Sometimes they love things. Sometimes they hate things. They change their minds willy-nilly. But I think the real thing that markets are moving on today is the Federal Reserve in those meeting minutes, which showed they're thinking seriously about rate cuts.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Really? Well, OK, Charles.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: All right. Well, Daly also chimed in. Because you do have Bowman and Michelle Bowman, who in the minutes yesterday, they said that they're definitely the two everyone knows.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Chris Waller.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Chris Waller, yeah. Waller, I'm sorry, yeah. Mickey Bowman, yeah. But Daly, they also hinted at it. Mary Daly. Yeah, she also hinted.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: That little lefty from San Francisco. It's a lefty from San Francisco.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Wow. Yeah, yeah. This is her.  Yep, so I think she's putting September into play. What I love about today's session, all these high-flying stocks that are up every single day, a lot of them got hit today, right? Profit-taking, this happens occasionally. But the money didn't go to the sidelines.  Right, that's just what you want to see. You want to see, because the big beef right now is you've got 10 stocks that are 40% in the market, and that's going to be a disaster. But as money rotates out of that and it goes into other parts of the economy, that's really phenomenal. And the growth stocks keep leading the way. The growth stocks, the cyclical stocks,  would suggest that Wall Street and the stock market believes the economy will remain.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: There you go. I think that's really, you know, I think that one big beautiful bill has been an underrated factor in the rise of the stock markets for several months. All right. It's exactly several months. That's while while the  Federal Reserve and Jay, what's his name, says it's all about tariffs. The market and the companies, right? Profits of the mother's milk of stocks are saying, whoa, wait a minute. We got immediate expensing. We got full cost expensing for our factories. The rest of the expensing was put back on the table. We got small businesses incentives. We got incentives galore. And that has nothing to do with tariffs. Nothing.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: So that was the first thing.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Jay, what's his name?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Jay, what's his name? He may say what he wants. But the first thing that one of the traders mentioned to me was this expensing, CapEx expensing. You know, and we've never seen the kind of policy that's being put in place. It's really going to unleash just a mountain of spending. And all of that is going to trickle into everybody's pocketbooks across the country.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: I mean, it isn't just today. Charles, industrials have been leading year to date, which I find very interesting. It's like we forget we have technology stocks. We have NVIDIA. God bless NVIDIA. I get it. But we also have old-fashioned industrial companies that are doing very well. And the outlook, because of the tax cuts and maybe the deregulation, for example, and maybe the lack of inflation, for example,  is very helpful to these industrial stocks. And correct me if I'm wrong, but it used to be, back in the day when I was practicing, the stock market was a predictor of the future economy. There, I said it. Uh-oh. I know. It can change its mind. But if you have a rally like this and you can't keep it down, it suggests something. Old-fashioned company. Next thing you'll know, construction stocks are going to be roaring. Next thing you'll know, industrial stocks are going to be roaring, et cetera, et cetera.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Yeah, you're 100% right. And to that point, this is why this whole thing about not just the big, beautiful bill, but the tariffs and everything. Ultimately, we're talking about reshoring, building into America. Yes. And I don't think any sector reflects that more than the industrials.  One of the big movers today, Huntington Ingalls, they got another upgrade. They just keep getting upgrades. Keep watching that stock. It's HII. On the other hand, Delta had a great earnings report. That was one of the leaders today. But it's broadening out. The growth, the American exceptionalism story, it's still intact.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: You know, it's such a good story that President Trump  Texted on it today. Truth Social. He's a stock market maven. I don't have in front of me. Here it is. I do have in front of me. Here it is. Tech stocks, industrial stocks, and Nasdaq hit all time record highs. Crypto. We haven't talked about crypto. Throw the roof. NVIDIA is up 47% since Trump tariffs.  USA is taking in hundreds of billions of dollars in tariffs. Country is now back. A great credit. Fed should rapidly lower rates. Yeah, we know that. But the point, he makes another good point. The revenues are pouring in. The tariff revenues, which Jay, what's his name, never wants to talk about because he's going to finance the debt so he doesn't have to finance the debt by creating printing press money. I mean, look, Trump's right. This stuff is rolling.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: It's rolling. And so this kind of optimism begets more optimism. Do you know what I mean? Like people spend, and I think you're starting to see this with consumers, like they hear the good news, they see the opportunity, they start spending. I can't tell you how many people, more people are becoming entrepreneurs, more people are starting businesses, and I think it's this feeling. You and I were talking a couple of days ago about this 4th of July and how good that felt this year.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: That's a good point. That's a very good point. Charles, take it from there, but I think there's a lot more optimism in the air than people think.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: So, you know, the folks who've missed out on the rally, the media, all these folks who are anti-Trump for one reason or another came up with this taco tray thing.  Making fun of Trump. He always chickens out. Here's what Trump has done. He's got the tariffs that he wanted the whole time. We're at over 14% tariffs from 2%. They're breaking in hundreds of billions of dollars. The stock market's at a record high. Record entrepreneurship, to Jerry's point. He's getting everything that he wants while they focus on some kind of nonsense like this. So let them have their fun while the American public prospers.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Charles, anybody that thinks Trump is a chicken,  needs to be texted just a little bit of a picture of those B-2s going over Iran and obliterating their nuclear facilities, OK? I don't mean that the people saying that should be bombed, but they might look at that because here's a very decisive president who takes action and will continue to take action.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: He is doing things that you just don't do in Washington, D.C. He is totally unafraid, and they are not accustomed to that, because he's upsetting the apple cart, and he's trying to actually, what he's really trying to do, is he's trying to spread the wealth. And since 2009, the wealth has overwhelmingly gone to people who own assets, particularly the stock market. President Trump is trying to find a way to spread the wealth.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Yeah. Breaks on social security payments, wages, overtime pay.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Jay Powell, if things are so bad, why are they so good? I mean, some of the... Jay what's his name? Sorry. I got it back. Jerry Willis and Charles Payne. We appreciate it. You can catch Charles, of course, hosting Making Money weekdays at 2 p.m. Eastern, right here on Fabulous Fox Business.

summary.Donald_Trump: Claims credit for the stock market hitting record highs, including tech, industrial, and Nasdaq stocks. He asserts that NVIDIA is up significantly since implementing tariffs and that the country is taking in hundreds of billions of dollars in tariffs. He argues that the Fed should rapidly lower rates and emphasises the revenue generated from tariffs. He also highlights record entrepreneurship and suggests that his policies are spreading wealth.
summary.SPEAKER_00: The stock market is booming due to Federal Reserve meeting minutes hinting at rate cuts. He emphasises the significance of CapEx expensing and other tax policies in unleashing spending and benefiting the economy. He points out the broadening of the market growth, with industrials and other sectors performing well, and suggests that this optimism is leading to increased consumer spending and entrepreneurship.
summary.SPEAKER_01: The stock market rally is driven by various positive factors, including potential Fed rate cuts, favourable tax policies, and reshoring efforts. He highlights the performance of specific stocks and sectors, such as growth stocks, cyclical stocks, and industrials, as indicators of the economy's strength. He believes that the market is reflecting the belief in American exceptionalism and the success of the current administration's policies, including tariffs and tax cuts.
summary.SPEAKER_02: The stock market is booming despite previous concerns about tariffs. He attributes the market's growth to favourable tax policies, particularly immediate expensing for factories, and suggests that these policies have been underrated factors. He also mentions the performance of industrials and other sectors, indicating a broader economic recovery. He expresses optimism about the future and criticises the media and some economists for their negative views.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the current booming stock market performance and its underlying reasons. The speakers analyse various factors contributing to the market's growth, suggesting that it is driven by optimism about the economy, potential Federal Reserve rate cuts, favourable tax policies, and reshoring efforts. They also criticise the media and some economists for their pessimistic views and highlight the achievements of the current administration.

video_title: ‘Big government, taxes is not the solution’: Former Democrat

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Welcome to the show. Former AOC supporter and the Free Press social media editor, Lucy Biggers. Lucy, so good to have you on the program. You went through an incredible journey from AOC supporter to talking about Leslie. It was like right out of Milton Friedman's playbook or something. So my first question is, how the heck did you go from where you were to where you are now? And what does it mean for what Mamdani supporters need to hear?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Yeah. Thank you so much for having me on. I mean, I'm 35 years old. I have two kids. I have a mortgage now. And like the stereotypical person, you grow up, you start paying taxes and more and more of them as you get older and you sort of look around and go, where is this money going? Exactly. The government doesn't seem to be working exactly well. And, you know, I think like a lot of people, as you mature, you're  if you  I've lived long enough to know that really the best thing we need is for individuals to be empowered to make that innovation that makes our economy hum, and big government and more taxes is not the solution.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Well, you mentioned housing, and I know you had this to say about Mamdani's idea for rent control on TikTok. Listen to this.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: When you're indoctrinated into this sort of leftist, oppressor, oppressed mindset, you think business owners are evil. They're not. Many of them are small businesses. They're working on a margin. And so it's not affordable for them to put hundreds of thousands of dollars into an apartment that they cannot charge market rate for. That's why we have such a bad housing crisis right now in New York, is because of these leftist policies  that feels so good to vote for. Like, yay, of course you don't want to raise rent on rent-stabilized apartments. Like, that feels so good, but you guys have to understand, like, that's not how things work.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
