lines.text: Now, your logic is right on there. I'm with you on that. But I do think Mamdani is talking about affordability, and that is resonating with some of these young voters. How do you help them understand that even if the goal is right, the path they're taking to get there is disastrously wrong?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: I mean, if I had the answer to that, I think I would be a millionaire. It's the age old question, because we have these young people, they lead with their hearts, they see poverty, they see inequality, and they want to make a difference. I was one of those people. And unfortunately, I think Mom Donnie, he's a snake oil salesman, is maybe a little harsh, but he's selling a dream. He's saying, just give the government a little bit more money and then it will start doing well. And it'll really be a utopia. So just trust me, I'm going to be different this time.  Remember, New York City has a $110 billion budget and spends $40,000 per student in elementary school, and half of the kids can't even read at grade level. So the government's not working well, and the idea that we would throw more money at a system that does not work, it's wishful thinking, and maybe that will get through to them.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: It sounds like the adults in New York City need to step up and kind of throw their weight around a little bit and help those younger people become adults who can think clearly about the issues that affect our lives. Lucy, great stuff. Good to see you. Thanks for being with us today.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Thank you.

summary.SPEAKER_00: The host welcomes Lucy, highlights her political journey, and agrees with her critiques of Mamdani's policies. He emphasises the need to educate young voters about the practical implications of their political choices and the ineffectiveness of government spending.
summary.SPEAKER_01: Lucy explains her political shift due to personal experiences and growing concerns about government efficiency. She criticises Mamdani's rent control policies, arguing they hurt small businesses and contribute to housing crises. Lucy believes young voters are led by emotions and need to understand the economic realities and unintended consequences of leftist policies.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses Lucy Biggers' political shift from supporting AOC to opposing Mamdani. They critique Mamdani's policies, particularly rent control, arguing they harm businesses and worsen economic issues. The focus is on how to educate young voters about the unintended consequences of government intervention and the ineffectiveness of big government solutions.

video_title: ‘HELD TO ACCOUNT’: Former acting ICE director tears negative rhetoric on ICE agents

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Customs and Border Protection Senior Advisor and former Acting ICE Director Ron Vitello joins me now. Lots going on, sir. Can you give me an update first on that manhunt?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, we know that the FBI, the U.S. Attorney's Office, the local and state law enforcement, and the federal partners are actively looking for this individual. Alvarado turned out to be a shooting where an officer was injured, but it was absolutely a planned attack.  And so the person that it's at large will be apprehended quickly because the entirety of the interagency is looking for them, and they need to be held to account for that violent attack on that  installation, that ICE property detention center, that it needs to be taken care of.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: You know, you're seeing so many of these things happen, sir. How do you connect the dots between the incidents we're seeing, what it means, where it's coming from, how it needs to be dealt with?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, these leftist politicians that are old enough to know better need to tone down the rhetoric. You'll remember, Brian, that they used to say they wanted to abolish ICE back in 2018. They talked about defunding the police in 2020. And now they want the rest of America to believe that arresting illegal aliens inside of the United States is somehow a Gestapo tactics or is something that we shouldn't want in the United States, when in fact, the laws that are on the books that these patriots  are enforcing have been on the books for decades. The funding that they use to buy the cars and the trucks and the tactical vests to protect themselves have been funded by the same Congress members that are calling this kidnapping and Gestapo tactics. That needs to end. These politicians need to be held to account for the rhetoric that they're using. And we need to praise these patriots that are out there serving the American people. Their job is to keep the rest of us safe,  and getting in their way and impeding their activity is not only harmful to them and their families, but it also is against the law, and they will be prosecuted for getting in the way.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Let's talk about that rhetoric, because Democrats continue to ramp up what they're saying as violence against your officers continue. Listen to this.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Are Democrats not doing enough to fight these developments?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Well, we are in a more is more environment in terms of the unprecedented assault on the American way of life and our country that has been launched by Donald Trump and compliant House Republicans. It's terrorizing Americans, our friends and neighbors, otherwise known as immigrants, many of them.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: They're going after anybody that is brown, that looks like me, that can't pass as what they say is a typical American. That's why you're getting people who are not undocumented actually arrested. That's the fear that exists, that anybody—it doesn't matter if you're a citizen or not—could be arrested and held in detainment for a number of days.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: You know, your officers are being accused of terrorizing, and according to that one individual, racially looking at people based on the color of their skin. How do you respond to that, sir?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, it's nonsense. It's ridiculous. And people have a responsibility to tell the truth. What those men and women are doing out there is risking their own lives. That's why they're wearing masks, because they were threatened online. Their families were threatened online. Their homes, their personal homes, were targeted.  And for these politicians and the propagandists in the leftist media that are talking about making this look like kidnapping, et cetera, they ought to know better. And they absolutely do know better. But they want to convince the American people that this work doesn't need to be done. When we all know that it needs to be done, that's why  President Donald Trump is in the White House because people voted for this kind of activity. The Secretary of Homeland Security has given the front line the tools that they need to succeed. They are out there succeeding, and the left is losing their mind over it. It's irresponsible rhetoric, and it could be very, very dangerous.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Ron Vitello, thank you for joining us. Good to see you.

summary.SPEAKER_01: Hosts the conversation, asks questions about the manhunt, the increasing incidents of violence against ICE officers, and the rhetoric from both political parties regarding immigration enforcement.
summary.SPEAKER_02: Former Acting ICE Director, emphasises that the attack was planned and condemns violent rhetoric from leftist politicians. He argues that their statements, such as calling for ICE abolition or defunding the police, create a hostile environment for ICE officers and contribute to the violence they face. He defends ICE actions, stating they are enforcing existing laws.
summary.SPEAKER_03: Accuses Donald Trump and compliant House Republicans of launching an unprecedented assault on the American way of life. Claims that ICE is terrorising immigrants, including citizens, and that there is widespread fear of arbitrary arrest and detention based on race.
summary.SPEAKER_04: Questions whether Democrats are doing enough to fight the developments (presumably the violent attacks on ICE officers), but no clear stance is provided beyond this question.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses a manhunt for an individual who attacked an ICE property detention centre, leading to an injured officer. It delves into the broader issue of rhetoric surrounding ICE and immigration enforcement, with both sides accusing the other of inciting violence and spreading misinformation.

video_title: Trump VA head hits back at Chuck Schumer: This is what’s ‘cruel’

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: The Department of Veterans Affairs, they are largely scaling back layoffs to less than half of the initial plan. That's thanks to success with early retirements, deferred resignations, and the federal hiring freeze.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: So originally the VA was eyeing a downsized goal of 83,000 employees. Now that goal is 30,000.  At the beginning of this year, the federal agency employed 484,000 people. Six months later, that number reached 467,000, down 17,000 employees, eliminating the need for a large scale reduction in force. So you would think that the Democrats would rejoice over this, but wrong.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: A cut of 30,000 will decimate the ability of the VA to provide good health care to our veterans who have risked their lives for us.  What Secretary Collins is doing is making the VA so toxic that workers are leaving on their own. It's a vicious cycle, a cynical double whammy, where veterans pay the ultimate price for Donald Trump's cruelty.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Joining us now is Veterans Affairs Secretary Doug Collins. Doug, it's always great to have you on the program. We were just talking about Medicaid, for example. We're going to be talking about interpretations of the Constitution. Now we're talking about the VA and DOJ and cutting. If you're a Democrat, there is no room in any aspect of the government or life or the system to reform anything  even if things haven't been enacted correctly for the betterment of the country, it's really difficult for me to get my head around.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: It seems to obviously to be difficult for Chuck Schumer as well. You know, what's cruel is over the last four years, we had a increase in personnel, an increase in hundreds of billions of dollars at the a hundred billion dollars in the budget at the VA, but yet our wait times for our patients went up. Our wait times into community care went up. Our backlog of disability claims was at 260,000 when I came in and  you know, I didn't hear Chuck Schumer talking about it then. I didn't hear Chuck Schumer talking about the cruelty of making patients wait over 20 and 30, 40 days to get their mental health appointments. Where was Chuck Schumer then? He was, he was wanting to protect his union workforce. He was wanting to protect just stuff that he doesn't really want to look into because what we really needed was leadership and we needed a force at the, at the VA that said our workforce is about serving veterans. Our workforce is not about increasing federal government payrolls.  And that's what we've been able to do. And I promised them back then, when we started the look at the goal of how we were going to look at our reduction for us, is that no benefits were going to be cut, no disability checks were going to be scaled back and that we would make improvements to help our healthcare for our veterans. I've kept my promises. Obviously they don't want to keep their promises because if they did, they would applaud what we're doing and they would help us instead of criticize us.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: And Secretary Collins, I know you tweeted out that the veterans waiting for benefits backlog has dropped nearly 30% since January. I mean, isn't that what it's about? About helping our veterans who have served our country, who are willing to put their lives on the line to protect us, to protect our freedoms, instead of how many employees the VA has?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Yeah, that's what you would send to think. I mean, if you want to help veterans, wouldn't that seem to be the right purpose is to help veterans? Well, that's what our purpose is doing. I'm proud of what we're doing. And yes, you know, they keep saying that we push people out. People took advantage of early retirement. People took advantage of, of the deferred proposition to leave. You know, this was a proposition that they had  And really what we've seen is, is as we've been through this transition, our numbers are getting better because we didn't allow just anybody to leave. We had 350,000 employees, job descriptions that were not allowed to take these. We kept the core constituency of what the VA is supposed to do, and that is help veterans in place. They don't want to talk about that. They would rather just get up there and lie. They would rather just get up there and deceive. And you know what bothers me? What bothers me is if they listen to him and somebody didn't know better,  A veteran who may have needed care at the VA, a VA who, a veteran who is maybe having some mental health issues, maybe even thinking suicidal thoughts, they hear something like that, they don't come to the VA for help. And then who's responsible at that point? They've got to get better at helping the VA instead of just complaining about it.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: That's such a great point. We also want to get your take on this secretary. So speaking of the trimming of the bloated bureaucracy, the AFL-CIO union has launched a nationwide bus tour to fight agency reductions and is planning to stop outside of VA offices. Here's how the tour is looking so far.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: We are going where the action is. We are going to get out where the veterans are who are struggling to access health care as hospitals are closing down.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: This is remarkable to me. And to the point that you just made, when you actually fix systems, you make them better, you make them stronger. When they scream and yell, Secretary Collins, they are making the problem worse. And that is actually what is very dangerous. But the Democrats still are in denial. They don't understand why they lost the election. And for some reason, even with six months, seven months passage of time, they can't really get their head around it. They're in a lot of trouble.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Oh, very much so. We have a saying for what we just witnessed there in the South, it's called bless your heart. You know, it's just sad to see that, you know, so we're going where the action is. We're going to have veterans who are struggling to get their healthcare. Where? Show me these veterans. Show me the,  because we're actually doing things to get their healthcare better. We're actually lowering wait times. We're getting them into community care by things like best medical interest, which let the doctor and the veteran decide if the care is quicker or better at the VA, or do we need to fund that through our community care doctors? This again, notice who's putting this on.  They're about the employees, which my employees are great by the way. I've got some wonderful employees that are doing great, great things. And they'll have a secretary that has their back as long as they're taking care of our veterans. But what I don't need is groups like this who are making money off of our employees to stay in business, going around and saying that things are bad. Come and see what we're doing. Help us if you think the veterans problem is there, but don't just tell me that the only way to do it is throw money and people at it because you've already proved that don't work.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Well, Secretary Collins, I went to the University of Tennessee, so I'm very familiar with what bless your heart means. So I had a laugh after you said that. Secretary Doug Collins, you have such an important job taking care of our veterans, so we so appreciate your time and the work that you're doing. Thank you, sir.

summary.SPEAKER_00: Criticises the VA's 30,000-employee cut, arguing it will decimate the agency's ability to provide healthcare to veterans. She claims that Secretary Collins is creating a toxic work environment, leading to voluntary departures.
summary.SPEAKER_01: Expresses frustration with Democratic opposition to government reforms, including at the VA. He argues that previous increases in personnel and budget at the VA did not address issues like long wait times and backlogged disability claims. Collins emphasises the importance of leadership prioritising veterans' needs and defends the reduction in force as a means to achieve this, noting that core VA functions have been protected.
summary.SPEAKER_02: Reports that the VA is scaling back layoffs due to successful early retirements, deferred resignations, and a federal hiring freeze. The initial plan was to downsize by 83,000 employees but has now been reduced to 30,000. Despite this positive outcome, the speaker notes that Democrats are criticising the changes.
summary.SPEAKER_04: Defends the VA's reductions in force, arguing that they are necessary for reform and to improve services for veterans. He highlights that wait times for patients have increased despite budget boosts in previous years. Collins emphasises that no benefits have been cut, and the backlog of disability claims has dropped nearly 30% since January. He criticises the AFL-CIO union's bus tour against agency reductions, arguing that they are prioritising employees over veterans.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) layoffs, reductions in force, and the subsequent political debates surrounding these changes.

video_title: This is why investors should own stocks for the long-term

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: All right, so this morning, Thorsten Slonka, he's the chief economist over at Apollo. He made this interesting statement talking about the extreme index concentration of the S&P 500 in tech. He says it was obviously not good for investors seeking to diversify their investments across 500 different companies.  Anyone invested in the S&P 500 index today is basically making a bet on the Magnificent Seven stocks propelling even higher. I will say this is odd, right? Because maybe it's a dilemma for Wall Street because they have a lot of products that they need to sell. And maybe one day it's going to be a dilemma for investors.  Most people who are investing are looking to make money. They're not necessarily seeking this sort of diversification. They like making this cash, and they're making a lot of it. I'm gonna bring it out. I'll be on a financial, their chief investment officer, Jason Ware, because Jason, you have been overweight in technology. Are your clients complaining right now that you're not more diversified? They like more consumer staples and real estate stocks?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Charles, always good to be with you. No, we have not heard that. I mean, diversification is important. You don't want to put all of your eggs in one basket, as we all know. But being overweight, the best companies in America, quite frankly, the best companies on planet Earth, I think has been great for our clients. It's been great for everyone who's had exposure. Even if you just have exposure to the S&P 500, about a third of your investments are in these top seven stocks. They've carried the S&P.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: They've carried the S&P. We're going to put a chart up here because right now, I can remember when not long ago there was a lot of complaints about them being 25% in the S&P, then 30% in the S&P, then 38%. We're almost 40% in the S&P. Is there a point where you do start to become worried and maybe say, hey, I want to ease out of these names a little bit?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Yeah, it's a great question. There's two ways that we look at that. One is valuation. When you have these stocks get to a point where valuation no longer makes sense, then we trim and rotate and we look for other areas. Second, we have to remember, we all focus on the concentration that these stocks carry within the index, but we have to remember their profits, the amount of profit and free cash flow that they contribute to the S&P 500 is equally as large as their weighting in the index. So I think as long as their profit contribution to the S&P 500 remains consistent with their  then I'm not too concerned about it.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: All right, I want to stay on this topic a little bit, taking profits, and I want to give you some props in the process. February 24th, you offered the audience 10 names. They're up huge. Seven of them are up really huge. Oracle, the biggest one, up 39%. Are you still holding all the names in green? Are you still holding all of those, or have you started to ease out of any of them?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: No, we still own all of them. We continue to be bullish on the companies. We have to remember Charles that when we own stocks going back to fundamentals of Ben Graham, Peter Lynch, etc. We own a share of the business and those businesses right there to your left. Continue to look good in valuations aren't too stretched, so we still own him for clients and we want to be in them long term on the downside.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: The Apple and the salesforce.com people starting to lose faith in those names.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Yeah, a little bit. I mean, Apple certainly has its headwinds. Mainly, it's trading at 30 times, and people are wondering where growth comes from. We're still bullish on Cupertino. We think the consumer AI experience is going to be experienced through iPhone. We think the services business is still intact, so we like that. And then as we look at Salesforce, we think agentic AI is going to be huge, and they're leading the way. It's always a good bet to bet on Mark Benioff, and we still like Salesforce. It's trading at the lowest valuation over the last 15 years. It's trading at mid-20s.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: I can't, you know, I can't believe it. The Apple first company to a trillion, two trillion, then three trillion valuation, not the first and fourth trillion. Not everyone's saying, let's get rid of Tim Cook. All right, before we go, I want to talk about names or some of these symbols that are primed to go. We don't necessarily have time to go into depth and to depth in all of them, but you know, some of these names are, maybe we haven't talked about on this show. Five serve, for instance, that's a name that many guests, it's the first time I've heard it in a long time on this show.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Yeah, it's been getting a lot of attention, not for the right reason. Their clover volume growth came in below expectations, just slightly, and the stock's been down. But it's trading at the lowest valuation since we've owned it, and we've owned it for over a decade. So Fiserv is a great growth at a reasonable price story, GARP story. As I look at the other ones, like Amphenol, we bought it in the mid-60s, literally on deep-seek day, and it's up 50%. So that one's stretched, but it's still got such a great business. So a lot of great names on your screen there.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: 30 seconds, Starbucks is another name you're looking at here. It's that fundamental technical.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Yeah. It's Brian Nickel. They brought him in to turn it around and he's got a great track record. We're going to stick with him.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: You know what? I tell people all the time. If you your big long term investments have to be based on management, management, management, management, management, and his track record to your point is phenomenal. Jason, congratulations, my man. Thank you very much. Appreciate you. Thank you. Appreciate the support.

summary.SPEAKER_00: The host questions the extreme index concentration of the S&P 500 in tech. He wonders if there is a point where this concentration becomes too risky, despite the current profitability of tech stocks. The host also highlights the previous performance recommendations of the guest and probes about potential future growth stocks and investor sentiment towards specific companies like Apple and Salesforce.
summary.SPEAKER_01: The guest defends the overweight position in technology stocks, arguing that they are among the best companies globally. He acknowledges the concentration risk but emphasises the importance of valuation and profit contribution. The guest remains bullish on several tech stocks, including Apple and Salesforce, citing strong fundamentals and long-term growth prospects. He also mentions other potential growth stocks trading at attractive valuations.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the concentration of the S&P 500 in tech stocks, particularly the "Magnificent Seven", and its impact on investors. Despite concerns about diversification, the strong performance of these tech giants has justified their overweight position in many portfolios. The discussion also touches on valuation, taking profits, and potential future growth stocks.

video_title: ‘BLOWN AWAY’: Mother speaks out after court approves son’s free speech settlement

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Christian's mother, Leah McGee, joins us now along with his attorney, Dean McGee, from the Liberty Justice Center. Leah, I want to start with you. I mean, you're 16. All he said was space aliens or illegal aliens who need green cards. I mean, that seems so innocuous to me. What was your reaction when the school reached out to you that he was hit with a three-day suspension?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Well, at first, you know, we could not believe that they  said that that was labeled under a term of racism when alien is not a race. But second, that they suspended him for three days and violated his process of learning, his due process, blew our mind. And to have such stubbornness going through this for a year and a half of them refusing to remove the racism and make it such a battle,  was just very telling of the character of the people that we were dealing with in this lawsuit. We were completely blown away when we were called to the school and to learn that they used a term that is found in our federal code and they told my son that he was not allowed to use that.  really blew our mind as parents.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Leah, kudos to you for standing up. And Dean, you helped her do it. Let me ask a little bit about the legal process, because we've seen parents stand up to school boards before. And they will be characterized as terrorists. And they will be browbeaten. They will not be allowed to win. So how did you make the case for this, leading to success?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Well, the case was really straightforward in terms of Christian's free speech rights and in terms of his due process rights. And, you know, we brought a very strong complaint in federal court. We filed for a preliminary injunction.  And then ultimately, this became the tale of two different school boards. The first one that doubled down, suspended our client, and actually slandered our client and Leah to the public, to the community. But the community rose up, elected a new school board, and that was one that we were able to work with and get this resolved with. So you have one example of government abuse of power, abusing this kid, and another of government working to make things right. And I'm glad we reached that point.  But we couldn't have gotten there without a lawsuit.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: You know, we had so many parents around the country and parents who are watching the show right now. They're concerned about the indoctrination that's taking place in our schools and you've lived it. Your family has lived it. So what's your message to them about what they should be on the lookout in their kids schools?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: My prayer is that this encourages other parents to get more involved in knowing who is on your school board, who's setting policy for your children. In just 14 months time, our family was able to speak in front of the board,  hire Dean McGee through Liberty Justice Center, who did everything pro bono for us. And in 14 months time, we removed five of the six board members who hurt our child. We introduced new legislation for the entire state of North Carolina,  With the help of Senator Steve Jarvis, which allows all short term appeals, the short term suspensions, the right to appeal, which is the we did not get that right with Christian and the woman who slandered our name ended up receiving her own DWI and having to resign from the school board after she put two children in the hospital with the DUI crash. So as a community we've come together.  And we said this will not happen in our county. Yeah, and I want to encourage other parents to do the same.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Kudos to standing up and leading by example, not only for your son, but for the community at large. I think we can all agree you don't mess with moms. No, it's great to see you, Leah and Dean. Thank you.

summary.SPEAKER_01: Leah McGee, the student's mother, was shocked and outraged when her son was suspended for three days for saying "space aliens" or "illegal aliens". She emphasised that "alien" is not a race and that the school violated his due process. Leah encourages other parents to get involved in their school boards, highlighting how they were able to remove five of the six board members who wronged their child, introduce new state legislation, and effect significant change in their community within 14 months.
summary.SPEAKER_02: The interviewer praised Leah for standing up and commended Dean McGee for his legal assistance. The interviewer highlighted the challenges parents face when standing up to school boards and noted the broader concerns about indoctrination in schools.
summary.SPEAKER_03: Dean McGee, the attorney, explained that the case centred around the student's free speech and due process rights. He noted the contrast between the two school boards they dealt with - the first one which doubled down on the suspension and slandered the family, and the second, newly elected board which was cooperative and helped resolve the issue. Dean emphasised the importance of the lawsuit in achieving justice.
summary.high_level_summary: A student was suspended for using the term "alien" which led to a legal battle over free speech and due process. The school board's actions were challenged, and the community elected a new board, ultimately resolving the issue in favour of the student and his family.

video_title: Playing tough with Canada is better for US amid Trump's tariff threat: Market expert

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: even as President Trump announced a new 35% tariff on select Canadian imports, taking effect August 1st. The president is pointing to Canada's lack of fentanyl enforcement and the unfair levies that the president says are put on American dairy farmers.  Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney posted this on X. The country is making progress on fentanyl. Ottawa remains committed to working with the United States, writes the Prime Minister. Joining me now is Pro-Chain Capital President David Towell. David, good to see you. Thank you so much for being here.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Good morning, Maria.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: So President Trump says the products coming out of Canada that are compliant with USMCA will be exempt from this new tariff, but other products will be facing a 35% tariff coming into America. Your reaction?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: It is great that Trump is able to play hardball on so many fronts, on so many different policies, on so many issues, all at once. Let me remind viewers, this is an absolutely stark contrast to the Biden administration. Canada is the US largest export partner and its second largest trade partner overall.  This is an incredibly important relationship from a dollars and cents perspective and it behooves our president to go ahead and get the best deal he can for the American people and for American industry. And so if that means that he needs to go through multiple rounds of negotiation and needs to play tough with them, well then that's better for us and we should applaud him for that.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Yeah, I think that's right. I agree with you, David. But then you've got this whole group of people that claim, oh, there's all this uncertainty. We don't know how much it's going to cost us. We don't want to put our money to work long term in terms of investing in things because we're not sure about the tariffs. What do you say to those CEOs who continue to claim they don't have clarity?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: I listen. I agree with that. Those CEOs themselves go through negotiations every day that are protracted and are multi-rounded. And therefore, they don't know exactly what the outcome is going to be, but they have a good sense. And so therefore, they take cautious steps on the basis of their intuition and what their expected outcome is. I expect them to do the same. And by the way, same thing for market participants.  You're not happy with the uncertainty potentially that there may be for the next couple of months? Okay, so take some of your money and put it on the sidelines. You don't need to be fully invested in this market. That's okay. That's an understandable position. But to say I'm totally out or I can't do business and I'm fully debilitated because of the uncertainty, I'm sorry. That's not an appropriate level of leadership.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Yeah, and little by little, we are getting the clarity. President Trump is getting—is being tough. And that's the bottom line. If there are non-tariff deadlines, expect the president to take notice and react. Meanwhile, David, you've been spot on on crypto. Bitcoin skyrocketing to an all-time high this morning, above $118,000. Spot Bitcoin ETF taking in over a billion dollars in net inflows as of yesterday. And, of course, next week, we're looking at something called Crypto Week.  Congress is going to be moving to pass lots of legislation, the stablecoin legislation, market structure bills. You've predicted on this program that Bitcoin is going to $250,000 by the end of the year. That's only six or five months away, David. Are you still sticking with that?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: I'm sticking with it, Maria. I mean, we've seen a pretty good rally over the last 48 hours. As you just said, the market's taking a breather this morning, but crypto is not. It is charging higher. I expect that crypto week in the House of Representatives next week will go ahead and bring a bunch of legitimacy to the asset class, the genius build, the genius bill, which is going to go ahead and put stable coin legislation in place. It looks like it's going to go ahead and get passed and turn into law, the clarity  Which gives market structure is also going forward as well, and there's a real strong push Starting from both sides of the aisle now To go ahead and get crypto to be front and center we have a number of states in the United States adding Bitcoin to their balance sheet most notably recently, Texas and  And I think that that's going to go ahead and continue. We're going to see the same out of sovereigns around the world and out of corporations which have been adding Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies to their balance sheet. Maria, I also have to add, Ethereum, above $3,000 this morning, also charging much higher.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Yeah, you're right, and I guess that's what happens when you have an administration that is supportive of Bitcoin and of crypto, and a Congress that's moving so aggressively to come up with the framework in terms of legislation. Let's talk about the backdrop. This macro story in the U.S. Interest rates this morning are  below 4.4%, at 4.38% on the 10-year, up 3.5 basis points. You've got Fed Governor Christopher Waller saying that the Fed is shrinking its $6.7 trillion balance sheet, looking at a hypothetical decline to $5.8 trillion. That would be a big deal.  He says ongoing quantitative tightening could see reserves falling to just below $3 trillion. Waller is also signaling that he's open to a rate cut at this month's meeting, happens at the end of the month, July 29th. White House Budget Chief Russell Vought, meanwhile, joining the list of Trump officials, blasting Jay Powell. Now he's being accused of misleading Congress and moving forward with a $2.5 billion renovation of the Fed headquarters.  Vote accusing Powell of mismanaging the central bank budget, ignoring OMB guidelines and wasting taxpayer money. David, it sure feels like we're going to get a new chairman of the Fed before his term is up. What do you think?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Yeah, we definitely will. I think the drama is interesting. Certainly it's something that we need to follow. But the real story here is two things. First of all, we haven't seen inflation out of tariffs. And the question is, is whether we will, because tariffs haven't really  bear down yet. They haven't really gone into full effect. We've been in negotiation until now. We've been on and off again in a bunch of countries. When the rates are finally set, will that lead to inflation? Or worse, will it lead to demand destruction? And we need to keep our eye on that, separate and apart from that.  Regardless of what the Fed will do with whoever leads the Fed, with respect to the short end of the curve, we need to keep our eye on the long end of the curve. The 30-year, the 10-year and the 30-year are really the most important. 30-year, because it finances and sets the price for so many important assets, including real estate of all kinds, commercial, housing, and so on, private equity buyouts.  Yeah, long term debt for corporations. And so we need to watch whether the curve steepens. I'm not necessarily so concerned about the absolute rate, which frankly, hopefully will not bust beyond 5 percent on the 30 year. But I'm concerned about the steepness, because once the steepness gets to a serious level,  Countries around the world and lenders to the United States will start to take notice that the short-term rates are so low versus the very long-term rates. That indicates trouble on the long-term horizon. So we need to go ahead and start beating that down with good growth in this country. That is what this presidential administration is hoping for, as well as the American people should be rooting for, that we have growth that beats down the long end of the curve.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Yeah, I mean, look, that's why President Trump is trying to get Jay Powell to cut interest rates, because the cost of our debt is a trillion dollars more than we spend on defense. We've got $9 trillion in debt that's rolling over this year. He doesn't want to pay long-term, you know, debt that's more expensive than he should. Meanwhile, we've got a macro story that's showing zero inflation, 1 percent inflation, John. We'll get the CPI and the PPI out next week, as well as the start to earnings season.  Those will be market movers, John Lonsky.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: CPI and PPI will probably be somewhat higher than they were in the month of May, but I don't think that's going to upset the credit market to any extent. The story going forward is the degree to which these higher tariffs boost price inflation  As David said, there's no evidence where tariffs have even lifted import price inflation. This may sound crazy, but in the month of May, the annual rate of import price inflation, according to the Import Price Index, was 0.2%, two-tenths of a percent. If we take out petroleum products, it goes up to a very tolerable 1.8%. It very well might be that tariffs do more to squeeze profit margins than to add to  consumer price inflation.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: And don't forget all of the efforts to get prices in the oil market down with the president's policy sending gasoline and crude oil lower. That's the main issue with inflation. So that was incredibly effective. David, great to see you. Thank you, sir. David Towle joining us. We'll see you soon.

summary.SPEAKER_00: David Towell supports Trump's tough negotiation tactics with Canada, arguing they are beneficial for the American people and industry. He dismisses concerns about uncertainty, believing CEOs can navigate it. Towell also predicts Bitcoin will reach $250,000 by the end of the year due to increasing legitimacy and regulatory clarity. He emphasises the importance of watching the long-end of the interest rate curve and potential inflationary pressures from tariffs.
summary.SPEAKER_02: The host generally agrees with Towell's views on Trump's tariff strategy. She highlights the uncertainty faced by CEOs but suggests they should adapt. The host also discusses the positive performance of Bitcoin and the upcoming Crypto Week in Congress, which could further legitimise the asset class. She touches on the broader macroeconomic story, including interest rates, Fed Governor Waller's comments on rate cuts and balance sheet reduction, and criticism of Fed Chair Powell by Trump officials.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the new 35% tariff on select Canadian imports imposed by President Trump, its potential impact, and broader economic issues including interest rates, Fed policies, and cryptocurrency.

video_title: Trump admin announces end of taxpayer-funded benefits going to illegal migrants

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: And we kick it off with the hot topic of the hour. The Trump administration takes the next step in preserving taxpayer money for American citizens only, announcing changes to five departments that end benefits going to illegal aliens. The Department of Health and Human Services is restricting illegals from 13 public programs, including the popular Head Start early childhood education and nutrition program.  that aimed at low-income families. HHS Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. says this. For too long, the government has diverted hardworking American tax dollars to incentivize illegal immigration. Today's action changes that. It restores integrity to federal social programs, enforces the rule of law, and protects vital resources for the American citizenry.  Other departments include education, agriculture, labor and justice, the administration restricting access to things like free tuition, federally funded food programs, workforce development grants and other federal loopholes, all giving illegal migrants and illegal immigrants taxpayer-funded benefits. John, the issue here is not that you don't want to be good to everybody, but it's taking away resources from American citizens.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: You know, that's right. And let's not forget, we do have sanctuary cities, and I believe that if the sanctuary cities or even sanctuary states are upset about this, well, they should go ahead and take over the funding of these various social welfare programs. And moreover, you had a lot of, you know, high-income people that thought this was a great idea, illegal immigration. These would be high-income people who normally vote Democratic.  Well, they could go ahead and lend more support to those charities that supply funds to illegal aliens.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Yeah, exactly. And your thoughts, Tiana? Maria, I know we're still taking a victory lap over the big, beautiful bill, but Republicans and President Trump have expressed openness to taking a second stab. An obvious case would be welfare to non-citizens.  Right? The Cato Foundation, which is obviously very pro-open borders, they concede that building a wall around the welfare state, banning non-citizens from federally funded welfare, would generate over a trillion dollars of revenue over the decade. And we know that these things are fungible. It's why Gavin Newsom is apoplectic about the big, beautiful bill. Because they use those federal funds to offset the fact that they blew a three billion dollar hole in California's budget in order to give  Medi-Cal, Medicaid to illegal aliens. Kudos to President Trump.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Good point. Meanwhile this, Tiana, a federal judge in New Hampshire, issued a preliminary injunction to block the president's ban on birthright citizenship by certifying a class action lawsuit.  The order includes a seven-day stay to allow for appeal. The White House is slamming the move, saying that this judge's decision disregards the rule of law by abusing class action certification procedures. The Trump administration will be fighting vigorously against the attempts of these rogue district court judges to impede the policies President Trump was elected to implement. I mean, Tiana, didn't we just have the ruling on these injunctions and not being able to have this apply nationally?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Yeah, I wouldn't be surprised if SCOTUS weighs in quickly. Look, Maria, the lawfare hasn't ended. It's just changed jurisdictions and methods. The fact is, if the federal judiciary wants to make itself irrelevant, this is a pretty fast way of doing it. Yeah, what do you think, John?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Well, you know, I think, let's face it, a lot of these aliens were not supposed to be here in the first place. Lawless entry into the United States and now they want to go ahead and get the benefit of citizenship for the children that are born in this country. Give me a break. If you don't stand up and put a stop to this, this will never end.

summary.SPEAKER_00: Supports the Trump administration's actions, arguing that sanctuary cities should fund social welfare programs for non-citizens if they disagree with the new policies. He also criticises high-income individuals who support illegal immigration and suggests they should fund charities instead. He believes lawless entry into the country should not be rewarded with citizenship benefits for children born here.
summary.SPEAKER_01: Supports the Trump administration's efforts to restrict welfare benefits to non-citizens. He argues that this could generate substantial revenue and that states like California misuse federal funds to support non-citizens. He criticises the judiciary for issuing injunctions against the administration's policies, suggesting it is a form of "lawfare" and that SCOTUS may need to weigh in.
summary.SPEAKER_02: Introduces the topic, highlighting the Trump administration's changes to five departments, restricting benefits for non-citizens. She agrees with the rationale behind these actions, stating they protect American citizenry and resources. She also mentions the federal judge's injunction blocking the President's ban on birthright citizenship, noting the White House's opposition to this decision.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the Trump administration's recent actions to restrict access to federal benefits for non-citizens. The speakers generally support these moves, arguing they prioritise American citizens and conserve taxpayer money. They also criticise sanctuary cities and the judiciary for opposing these policies.

video_title: Marijuana facility ICE raid tells you everything about Gov. Newsom: McLaughlin

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Joining me now is Department of Homeland Security Public Affairs Assistant Secretary Tricia McLaughlin. Tricia, good to see you. Thanks for being here. What is the administration doing about all of these new attacks on ICE agents?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Maria, our ICE enforcement officers are seeing a 700 percent increase in assaults against them. But it's even more than that. We're also seeing the doxing of their family members, their spouses where they work, their children where they go to school, so they're being targeted. If you lay a single hand on a law enforcement officer, you will be prosecuted.  to the fullest extent of the law under Secretary Nome and President Trump's leadership. But it's more than that as well, Maria, because these politicians, whether it be Gavin Newsom, Karen Bass or AOC, continue to vilify our ICE enforcement officers, as they just carry out the law and try to make American streets safer.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: I mean, it's unbelievable. ICE agents were fighting off a masked mob outside of a San Francisco immigration court yesterday as Democrats are ramping up their fight to make sure that ICE agents conduct their duties unmasked. Senate Democrats even proposing a bill to do that. So, Tricia, you've got, on the one hand, these mobs trying to take down our ICE agents, but then you've got Democrats seeming to condone it.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: It is despicable. And keep in mind, Maria, these Homeland Security investigators and our ICE enforcement officers, they're going after the worst, the worst. MS-13 gang members, Trende Aragua, highly sophisticated criminal gangs and criminal rings that can easily target our ICE enforcement officers.  that the Democrats want to hand on a silver platter. Intelligence about our ICE enforcement officers and information tells you everything you need to know. But I do want to mention that marijuana facility raid. And that tells you everything about Gavin Newsom, the fact that he continues to vilify and demonize and attack our law enforcement officers,  when they actually went out and found that there were 10 children at that marijuana facility likely being exploited, potentially even being trafficked, because eight of them were unaccompanied. We are trying to figure out how they got there. Were they smuggled? Were they human trafficked? And the fact that Gavin Newsom is trying to obstruct that is disgusting. Yeah. Tiana, jump in here.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: We know that the Open Borders Brigade, they really care about the children when you can get these photo ops. But under Biden's Open Borders policy, they lost, Tricia, was it a quarter million children? And I know that a large part of that, his own labor secretary was warning that these kids might indeed, as we saw with this marijuana raid, might be working as illegal child slave labor. Is there any update on finding those children? And in what cases have you been tracking these kids being forced to work underage and in violation of labor law?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Tiana, you're absolutely right. Under the Biden administration, it was about 300,000 unaccompanied children who were lost in the system. I think it's an untold story that needs to be shared widely. Under Secretary Noem and HHS, we are working diligently to find these children. So far, about 5,000 unaccompanied children have been  found and reunited with a safeguardian or relative, but we're working hard to make sure that number is pumped up and we get these children to safety. It's so wrong what's happened. And it is our top priority, whether it be in L.A., Chicago, New York or otherwise, to make sure we are stopping any sort of exploitation of children.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Yeah, but then there's this, the Salvadoran national, Kilmar Abrego-Garcia, set to return to court today with his lawyers, a judge planning to grill ice over where it plans to release Abrego-Garcia when he leaves federal custody. Then there's the anti-Israel activist, Mahmoud Khalil, bringing a $20 million suit against the Trump administration, claiming he was falsely imprisoned. He faced malicious prosecution, Tricia. What are the plans here?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: I would like to remind viewers who Mahomet Khalil is. He was the ringleader of these Colombia protests, riots, really, where they defaced buildings. They took them over. They harassed Jewish students. They were posting pro-Hamas propaganda. It is a privilege, not a right, to live and study in this country. And Khalil took it to another level, where he started spouting and pushing anti-American propaganda. He shouldn't be in this country. In fact, he should self-deport. He shouldn't be here in the first place.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Yeah. We are watching all of these efforts to stop President Trump's deportation program. But we all know, Tricia, that President Trump wants a diverse population and wants to have immigrants here, but he wants it done in a legal way, a legal structure, as opposed to all these illegals coming in under Joe Biden that were unvetted. Why is it that the Democrats are not getting behind something that's so commonsensical?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: I think they're rudderless, Maria, because it really is nonsensical. I think that there's a degree of Trump derangement syndrome, because the facts remain. We've arrested, under this administration, 2,700 members of Tren de Aragua, a vicious gang that maims, rapes and kills Americans for sport. We've arrested almost 600  known or suspected terrorists. These are the worst, the worst individuals that the left really should be cheering us on to get out of this country. And yet, they continue to defend the likes of Kilmar Abrago-Garcia, that MS-13 gang member that you mentioned before, and these other really horrendous criminal illegal aliens.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Let me ask you, Tricia, about the Big Beautiful bill and there was increasing money for the border. How will that money be allocated in terms of the priorities right now based on what just happened in the Big Beautiful bill?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: It's going to really turbocharge our arrests and deportations, Maria. We're going to be doubling our bed space. And bed space and detention space is really an operational key, as far as getting those arrest numbers up and getting these criminal legal aliens out of our country. And, further, our ICE enforcement officers, we're going to almost double the amount of who are on the ground, more than 10,000 added and funded for. And, as well, our Border Patrol agents and our ICE enforcement agents.  are going to get the bonuses that they need. They work so incredibly hard to keep American streets safe. As well, we're seeing a vast increase in demonization against them, as I mentioned before, a 700 percent increase in assaults. And they deserve to be paid a fair amount and get those bonuses as they carry out the American people's mandate. All right, we will leave it there. And we'll be watching your work. Thanks very much, Trisha. Good to see you.

summary.SPEAKER_00: SPEAKER_00 condemns the assaults on ICE agents and accuses Democrats of vilifying them. They emphasise ICE's role in targeting violent criminal gangs like MS-13 and Trende Aragua. SPEAKER_00 also criticises the Biden administration's handling of unaccompanied children at the border, claims that many have been lost in the system and exploited, and highlights a marijuana facility raid where children were found. They defend the Trump administration's deportation policies, stating they have arrested many dangerous individuals and argue that Democrats should support legal immigration. SPEAKER_00 also mentions plans to allocate increased funding to the border for more arrests, deportations, detention space, and bonuses for agents.
summary.SPEAKER_01: SPEAKER_01 builds on SPEAKER_00's points, criticising the Biden administration's 'Open Borders policy' for allegedly leading to the loss of 300,000 unaccompanied children, some of whom may be exploited as illegal child labour. They question the efforts to find these children.
summary.SPEAKER_02: SPEAKER_02 introduces the topic of the attacks on ICE agents and the doxing of their families. They express disbelief at the situation and suggest that Democrats are condoning it through their rhetoric and proposals, such as the bill to require ICE agents to conduct duties unmasked. SPEAKER_02 also raises specific cases, like the Salvadoran national set to return to court and the anti-Israel activist suing the Trump administration, and questions the plans for releasing certain individuals from custody.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the increasing attacks on ICE agents and the perceived vilification of law enforcement by Democrats. It also highlights several immigration-related issues, including the safety of unaccompanied children, the role of ICE in combating criminal gangs, and legal challenges faced by the Trump administration.

video_title: Iran claims it could strike US, Israel every day for two years, report says

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Welcome back. Israel and Hamas moving closer to a ceasefire. The White House is pushing for an end to this war. Now, the current proposals on the table, which I discussed with the prime minister of Israel this week, would include a 60-day pause in fighting the release of some hostages and increased aid into Gaza.  Who's delivering that aid is under discussion. Now, Hamas claims it will release 10 hostages in a bid to reach the deal, but it is also demanding many things, including that Israeli troops withdraw entirely from Gaza. Israel says that will not happen. The troops will stay put.  Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu was at the Blair House when I spoke with him as he visited Washington this week to meet with President Trump. I spoke with the prime minister after his meetings with the president about the progress. Watch.  Let me start with one of the reasons that you're here. And you have been meeting with President Trump about a potential cease-fire with Hamas. Where does that stand? Will you agree to some of these new recent demands of Hamas?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Well, look, we are talking about a 60-day cease-fire in which half the live hostages and half of the deceased hostages would be returned to Israel by these  Hamas monsters, you know. And, yes, I think we're getting closer to a deal. I think we're—there's a good chance that we'll have it. To get our hostages out, we're going to take out Hamas, and we're going to make sure that Gaza no longer poses a threat to Israel or to anyone else.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Judy Minnaf from Jerusalem is U.N. Watch executive director Hillel Neuer. Hillel, what are your thoughts on a potential ceasefire? Do you think this could happen?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: I think it could happen, but let's recall that Hamas is a terrorist organization with a history of exploiting ceasefires to rearm and regroup. They're demanding an IDF withdrawal, a complete withdrawal from Gaza, and unrestricted aid flows, which are really tactical ploys for Hamas.  to maintain control over the captive population in the Gaza Strip and divert resources to their own war machine. So, Israel has a moral priority to get out as many hostages as they can, to bring all the hostages back as soon as they can. They're under brutal conditions. But Hamas's demand that they maintain power to rearm, regroup and attack Israel again cannot be accepted.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Yeah, I mean, so what are your thoughts on whether or not they hid some enriched uranium, if they still have some power? I mean, both President Trump and Prime Minister Netanyahu have told me that they have obliterated Iran's capacity. But Iran is claiming that it has enough missile capacity to strike the United States and Israel daily for two full years. The White House is disputing this.  One of the goals, in addition to knock out its nuclear capacity, was also to knock out its capacity to build ballistic missiles. The administration is also rebuffing a New York Times report which claims some of Iran's enriched uranium did survive. Operation Midnight Hammer, according to a senior Israeli official.  The White House says, quote, as President Trump has said many times, Operation Midnight Hammer totally obliterated Iran's nuclear facilities. The entire world is safer thanks to his decisive leadership. Here's the president and the prime minister about that enriched uranium during my conversations with them. Watch.  President Trump told me that he does not believe that the Iranian regime moved any enriched uranium before the U.S. struck those three facilities. Do you agree with that? Do you believe that Iran has hidden any enriched uranium?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Well, we think we know where it is. It's sort of buried underground. And we don't have contrary information. That's our intelligence, too.  You know, it's like we had two lobs of cancer. You know, one was the—that could kill you. One was the nuclear cancer, and they were rushing to weaponize their enriched uranium. You know, when they did that, after we crushed  Hezbollah, and after we got rid of Nasrallah, they were—you know, the axis, the Iranian axis in the Middle East was broken. So what did they have left? Well, they rushed to nuclear weapons and to—that was one cancerous growth that could have killed us.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Do you think that the Iranian regime hid some of the enriched uranium before the strikes? No. You mean, did they take it out of the deep one? Because you were pretty clear you can't have a weapon, you're going to have to come to the talks, something's going to happen.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: I don't think they did, no. We didn't give much notice because they didn't know we were coming until just, you know, then. And nobody thought we'd go after that site because everybody said that site is impenetrable. No, they didn't. But I do believe they had people there because you had cars, you know, they were saying cars. And those were masons. Those were people working with concrete. They were trying to seal up the entrance to where the bomb would most likely go in. And they did that. They were working on that.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: I saw reports that there were 400  kilograms, 800 pounds that they moved. But I wonder if it's traceable. I mean, if they were to have— They didn't move anything. They didn't move anything.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: You know, they moved themselves. They were all trying to live. They didn't move anything. They didn't think it was going to be actually doable.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: So, Hillel, I guess my question is, why is it that the Iranian regime can actually, you know, get as obliterated as it did in terms of their capacity, as the president told us, but then come back days later and say they're going to put a fatwa on the back of President Trump, and they're going to make a call to Muslims across the world to take down the president?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Look, Iran, their claims are clearly exaggerated propaganda. There is buster coming from the Islamic regime. They're trying to project strength after devastating U.S.-Israeli strikes on their nuclear sites, the Israeli  elimination of IRGC terrorist generals. And their weakened position since the attacks by the U.S. and Israel demonstrate that they're on the defensive. And a lot of this is bluster meant for internal, as well as for their neighbors, for their consumption. But at the same time,  Clearly, the intelligence is imperfect. I don't think we know exactly what happened to the enriched uranium that may be at those sites. As Netanyahu said, it might be buried deep. This only underscores the need for vigilance, follow-up action. We need to make sure that Iran is prevented from rebuilding its nuclear program. We need maximum pressure. I mean, sanctions, military readiness, intelligence sharing, maximum pressure on the Iranian regime.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Well, that's exactly what President Trump is doing, and his relationship with Netanyahu is critical to that. And that's what many of the Democrats miss. President Trump has personal relationships with a number of these people, and that's how he gets his deals done so quickly.  You've also got Secretary of State Marco Rubio quite effective. He's sanctioning a top official at the U.N. Human Rights Council. That person has been critical of Israel's offensive in Gaza. Francesca Albanese is claiming that Israel is profiting from the war with Hamas, accusing them of genocide nearly 70 times in this new report, Hilal.  And even as they are actually putting Netanyahu on trial in Israel, something President Trump said is a witch hunt and is ridiculous, you rebutted these points to her face last week at a meeting of the Human Rights Council. Let's take a look at that first. Watch.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Israel has been fighting a just war against a terrorist army, which cynically embeds itself among civilians. Ms. Albanese, war is not genocide. But in your report, there's no war at all. It's only about Israel. We ask, why does your report never mention once the October 7th invasion and massacre, or even the word Hamas?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Hello. What was her reaction, and were you pleased with how she responded?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Well, she did not verbally respond, but throughout the speech, I could see her going into a kind of meltdown. At the end of my speech, her head tilted back in a kind of whiplash. She shut her eyes to imagine it wasn't happening, because I challenged the fact that a U.N. investigation confirmed that she received funding from pro-Hamas groups.  Look, this is someone who is a racist demagogue. She's been condemned by France, Germany, and Canada for anti-Semitism and Holocaust inversion. She blamed the CIA and the Mossad for the ISIS terrorist attack in Paris. So she's really a dangerous nutcase. She's an enemy of America. I want to commend Secretary Rubio for taking the bold and historic  step to sanction her. It's a message to the world. It's a message to the UN. If you appoint terrorist supporters and racists as so-called human rights experts, America, at least America, will say no.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Yeah, don't forget the strategy that the Trump administration has used in terms of pulling Syria into the fold of the good guys, continuing to put a wall around Iran, which was very strategic as well. Helal, always great to get your perspective. Thank you.

summary.SPEAKER_00: Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu discusses a potential 60-day ceasefire with Hamas, involving the release of hostages. He emphasises Israel's goal of eliminating Hamas and ensuring Gaza no longer poses a threat. Netanyahu also mentions Israel's intelligence on Iran's enriched uranium and their previous military operations against Iran and its allies.
summary.SPEAKER_01: Hillel Neuer, U.N. Watch Executive Director, expresses scepticism about Hamas's intentions during ceasefires, noting they often use them to rearm. He criticises the U.N. Human Rights Council, specifically Francesca Albanese, for anti-Semitism and bias against Israel. Neuer supports U.S. sanctions on Albanese and advocates for maximum pressure on Iran to prevent it from rebuilding its nuclear program.
summary.SPEAKER_04: The host facilitates the discussion, asking questions about the ceasefire proposal, Iran's nuclear capabilities, and the U.N.'s role. The host also highlights the Trump administration's strategies, such as personal relationships with leaders, sanctions, and pulling Syria into the fold of allies, and mentions the criticism faced by Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu in Israel.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the Israel-Hamas conflict, a potential ceasefire, and Iran's nuclear capabilities. It also touches on the role of the UN and the US administration's strategies in the region.

video_title: Trump's assassination plot: Shooter questions emerge nearly a year later

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: President Trump says he is, quote, satisfied with the investigation into his assassination attempt. Listen.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: So they briefed me numerous times, the FBI, the Secret Service, sort of everybody, DOJ. Pamela's doing a fantastic — I think she's doing a fantastic job. But they briefed me, and I'm satisfied with it. I'm satisfied with it. They should have had somebody in the building.  That was a mistake. They should have had communications with the local police. But I was satisfied in terms of the bigger plot, the larger plot.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Former FBI agent Nicole Parker joins me now. Nicole, far be it from me to disagree with the president. I don't necessarily, but I do have a lot of questions. And one is more answers about the shooter. Who was he? What were his connections? All those encrypted emails that he had. Is that the sort of stuff that bothers you as well?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Well, that's the sort of thing that the FBI actually investigates, right? Because there's obviously the Secret Service investigation into the actual employees who failed that day. And then there's the investigation into the actual shooter. I think one thing that Americans are accustomed to getting is we want to know the motive. We want to understand the purpose. Why did this person do this? What was the precipitating stressor? And I'll just tell you straight up, there are certain investigations where there is no clear motive.  We'll see what comes out in additional information that the FBI is able to get. But one thing I do feel confident in is that, under this new administration, the new FBI leadership, the new leadership at DOJ, they're all about trying to give as much information as possible to the American people. There's nothing more that Kash Patel would like to do than to set Americans' minds at ease because of that awful tragedy that occurred on July 13. We are so lucky and blessed  that President Trump is still with us. And I do believe it is by the grace of God, because that could have ended very differently. And I have seen shootings where it ends very differently. And, tragically, we lost a hero, Corey Comperatore. And, like he said, his wife, she deserves better. She deserves more answers. And under the new Secret Service director, Sean Curran, she's going to get those answers.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: And of course, we should remember that the deputy FBI director Dan Bongino is a former Secret Service agent himself, so he's he's very well placed to ask the right kind of questions. Next one to call the Senate Appropriations Committee has voted to block Donald Trump from relocating the FBI headquarters to any location other.  than Greenbelt Maryland. I think it's kind of interesting that a court could order him to keep it where it is. Where do you think the new FBI headquarters should be?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: I have many thoughts on this. First of all, it should not be in Greenbelt, Maryland, in my opinion. That process of selecting that location was not impartial, shall we say. And even Christopher Wray came out when he was the director and said, I have some concerns about lack of impartiality in this decision-making process. And that was let the employees knew about that at the FBI. It was very clearly known. I think one thing that Director Cash Patel is doing, though, that I really strongly support, is he's downsizing FBI headquarters and the number of individuals that are there.  That is absolutely necessary. Put those agents back on the street, back in the field, so they can actually work cases and put bad people behind bars. Just recently, he has sent those that were doing 18-month TDYs, temporary assignments to headquarters, they're all now being sent back to the field to do casework, and that's where they should be. So you don't need this large  you know, brand-new building in Maryland for FBI headquarters. I think his approach is very wise. Use taxpayer dollars in a more efficient way. Use an existing building that had been used for USAID, the Ronald Reagan building right there in D.C. Move FBI headquarters there. You don't need this new elaborate building in Maryland.  And don't forget also the FBI does have a strong FBI headquarters presence in Alabama. And that's been ongoing for several years. And so I agree that they do not need a big FBI headquarters in DC, but you do need a headquarters in DC, not in Maryland. And the process should have been fair, but again, downsize that headquarters and streamline it.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Nicole, you make far too much sense for decisions being made inside the Belway, but thank you very much for your common sense. Good to have you here.

summary.SPEAKER_00: Former FBI agent Nicole Parker. She emphasises the FBI's investigation into the shooter's motives and highlights the challenges in finding clear motives in some cases. She defends the new FBI and DOJ leadership's commitment to transparency. Parker also opposes the relocation to Greenbelt, Maryland, suggesting instead using an existing building in DC or downsizing the headquarters.
summary.SPEAKER_01: Expresses satisfaction with the investigation into the assassination attempt but criticises the lack of security measures at the event.
summary.SPEAKER_02: Asks questions about the shooter's identity, connections, and encrypted emails. She also discusses the motive behind the attack and the need for transparency from the FBI. Later, she shifts the topic to the FBI headquarters relocation, arguing that the process was impartial and suggesting alternative locations.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation covers President Trump's satisfaction with the investigation into his assassination attempt, the ongoing inquiry into the shooter's motives, and the political debate surrounding the relocation of the FBI headquarters.

video_title: 'CATASTROPHIC': NYC's financial elite scramble to build anti-Mamdani war chest

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: The impacts of this law, unfortunately, are going to be felt almost immediately. But there is opportunity here because some of those aspects of the one big ugly bill that have been delayed from formally taking effect until after the midterm elections. But I'm convinced the American people will not be fooled by this trickery.  and will hold accountable who we need to hold accountable. This is the largest cut to health care in American history, on top of the largest cut to nutritional assistance in American history. They are literally ripping food from the mouths of children, veterans, and seniors.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: And that's House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries sounding off on the big, beautiful bill during a town hall in Louisiana last night. This is a preview of how Democrats are going to be using this bill ahead of the midterm campaigning, which is just about ramping up right now. Joining me now is New York Congressman Mike Lawler, a member of the House Financial and Foreign Affairs Committees. Congressman, great to see you. Thank you so much for being here. Thanks for having me. What do you make of Hakeem Jeffries?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, it's typical. This is the Democrats' ploy to say that the social safety net is being gutted while we're providing tax cuts for billionaires. And it's just not true. Number one, this is the single largest middle class tax cut in American history.  And next year, when Americans go file their taxes, they will see a huge tax benefit to their families, putting more money back in their pockets. You look at the senior tax deduction, for instance.  $6,000 for every qualified senior. That is massive. That provides more money for our seniors to be able to live, especially on a fixed income. You look at the enhanced child tax credit, no tax on tips, no tax on overtime, the enhanced standard deduction. And then, of course, lifting the cap on SALT, which is a huge win for  hard-working middle-class taxpayers in high tax areas, whether it's high property taxes, high state income taxes, or in the case of New York, both. And so that is a massive win, a 4x increase to $40,000, which is the single largest tax cut in the whole bill.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Yeah, and, you know, Congressman, you fought hard for that. You came on this program repeatedly, tried to make the case that, look, Democrats almost won the reelection in Congress, but it was thanks to people like yourself and other candidates in these blue states that actually, you know, won the election, brought in Democrats, brought in independents, and you wanted to make sure to fight for those people.  Tell me about that $40,000 cap on salt. It goes away after five years. What are the details that we need to understand that was in that big, beautiful bill, Congressman?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: So this was a hard-fought, good-faith negotiation with the White House, with Secretary Besant, myself, the other colleagues from the SALT caucus, and House leadership. And we landed on a $40,000 SALT cap with a $500,000 income cap. Again, this is not helping the billionaires or the millionaires. The irony is my Democratic colleagues from New York are attacking us that we didn't get unlimited SALT. The only people that would benefit from that are the billionaires.  So I don't know why they're advocating for that at the same time they're decrying tax cuts for billionaires, quote unquote. But the fact is, this has a $500,000 income cap, 1% growth for five years. But we were also able to protect pass-through entities, which is critical for our small businesses. And that was the trade-off on time.  to make sure that the pass-through entities were protected as well. As you well know, Maria, in any tax bill, there's always going to be provisions that expire and you come back, you renegotiate. So that will be something that will be on the table five years from now. But for the next five years, this is a massive win for taxpayers. And when you look at the fact that the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act was made permanent,  Moving forward, the tax rates were made permanent. That is a huge win. Now, when Democrats talk about the social safety net, here's what actually happened on Medicaid. Number one, eligibility verification, making sure that those who are not eligible do not remain on the program. Number two, citizenship verification, making sure that illegal immigrants do not collect Medicaid benefits.  Number three, work requirements, making sure that able-bodied adults without dependent children actually try to participate in the workforce for up to 80 hours a month, whether it's working, going to school, or volunteering.  The two big changes were the provider tax and the state-directed payments. And let's be clear about it.
