Provider tax is nothing more than a way for states to take more federal dollars without matching state dollars towards Medicaid. And so we are reducing the provider tax rate from 6% to 3.5. It won't start until 2028. And New York, for instance, won't be affected until 2031.  because New York is at 4.7%. The state-directed payments were changed under the Biden administration to allow Medicaid reimbursements to be paid out at private insurance rates, exploding the cost of the program. And so what we're saying is it should go back to what it was just two years ago, a one-to-one match with Medicare reimbursements, and therefore it is at parity.  That is going to take effect starting in 28 and go down 10% per year until it is back at parity. That is not a huge change. That is something that is common sense to make sure that these programs are available for the people who need them and that the funding is there to support our seniors, our IDD community, children, single mothers, et cetera.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Now that you have had this big success, the Republicans getting this across the finish line, what does the legislative agenda look like for the rest of the year? Do you focus on the second reconciliation package later in the year? Do you focus now on campaigning for the reelection in 26? What is the focus?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, this bill obviously had a lot in it, including border security, strengthening our military, increasing domestic production of energy. I think a lot of the focus moving forward, we have a lot to do on financial services, especially putting a regulatory framework in place for digital assets, crypto.  I think there's going to be a big focus on deregulation and capital formation and making sure that our small businesses have access to capital. Obviously, we want to continue to focus on energy production and permitting reform. And I think, you know, I serve on foreign affairs. There's going to be a lot of focus on what is happening around the globe as well and the impacts that has on America domestically.  We want to bring these conflicts to an end. I think the president has done a very good job, especially in the Middle East, with the destruction of Iran's nuclear facilities and really forcing them to the table. How this proceeds forward, obviously, is going to be paramount. But there's a lot of work ahead, and I look forward to continuing that process.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Congresswoman, I want to ask you two questions, from Beijing to New York. First of all, I was the first to report how weak Xi Jinping is and has been. When I first got back from Davos, I had reporting on the fact that the Politburo actually took away the military oversight.  from Xi Jinping, gave it to his, quote-unquote, brother. But ever since then, there's been other indications that Xi Jinping is not the leader and the Iron Man that a lot of people thought that he was. In fact, he's in a weakened position right now. Other media is starting to catch up with my reporting. What do you want to say about that, as he faces off against President Trump in the face of tariffs and other non-tariff barriers, as Beijing has been among the worst  in terms of trying to undermine the United States?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: No question about it. And when you look at the challenges facing the world, China, Russia, Iran have been at the center of it. They've been engaged in this on the Holy Alliance. They've sought to undermine and destabilize the U.S., Israel, Europe and the free world.  And you see, obviously, a weakened Iran. If Xi Jinping is in a weakened position, that is good news. It certainly will give the president greater leverage in negotiations on trade, but also in how we conduct operations in the Indo-Pacific. You have seen, no question, China has made advancements in the Indo-Pacific and the South China Sea.  They've used economic coercion to seize control of ports and waterways. 60% of international trade comes through the Strait of Taiwan. We do not want a situation where China invades Taiwan or creates a blockade. So a weakened Xi Jinping is good news. Obviously, we see Vladimir Putin continuing to rear his ugly head.  There are real challenges around the globe. I think President Trump is continuing to put maximum pressure on our adversaries, which is a positive thing as we move forward.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Let me move on to New York, because New York's wealthiest residents right now are scrambling to come up and build a financial war chest to defeat the Democrat-Socialist mayoral candidate.  Zoran Mamdani this November. The Wall Street Journal writes this, those considering funding or raising money include some of the biggest names in politics, including Pershing Square CEO Bill Ackman and former Trump adviser and New York City Mayor Rudy Giuliani. Congressman, you were at the Whitestone Republican Club's event. The Republican contender Curtis Sliwa was there. Are you endorsing Curtis Sliwa for mayor?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: I support Curtis. He is the Republican nominee. I think ultimately here, we'll see what the polling shows in the next couple of weeks. I think everybody is going to have to unify behind one candidate. You cannot allow an avowed socialist  who is engaged in communist speak, talking about seizing the means of production. He's against capitalism despite being a trust fund baby. His mommy is a producer in Hollywood. His daddy is teaching communism at Columbia University. The fact is you have somebody who, if he becomes mayor of New York City, it will be the most destructive,  force for New York, the financial capital of the world. I mean, I remind everybody every day, those tall buildings didn't get built by socialism. They got built by capitalism and capital formation and access to capital here in the United States. And the reality is the U.S. and our economic system has been the greatest force for good, the greatest force for lifting people out of poverty.  and in lifting people into the middle class. And he would destroy that in one fell swoop. You will see a mass exodus out of New York like you've never seen. It will make Bill de Blasio look like Margaret Thatcher.  That is how catastrophic this will be if Zoran Mondami becomes mayor of New York City. And so this is incumbent on everybody to take a deep breath, put egos aside, and ultimately recognize who is in the best position to win and do what's right by the people.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Can he do that, or does he need the governor to really make decisions? Can he make all those tax plans that he's planning, or is it really up to the governor?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: The governor of New York has immense control over New York City. Sadly, Kathy Hochul is too feckless, inept, and incompetent to understand how to do it. And that's why we need a new governor come 2026.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Is that going to be you? I mean, where does your campaign stand right now?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: We're going to be making a decision in short order. You know, there's been a lot going on with the big, beautiful bill and what's going on in the Middle East, but we're coming to a decision point. But bottom line, we need a Republican governor. That will be the backstop against any insanity coming out of New York City.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Congressman, good to see you this morning. Thank you, sir.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Thanks, Maria.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: All right. Mike Lawler joining us. We'll be right back.

summary.SPEAKER_01: The host introduces the topic, summarising House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries' criticism of the recent Republican bill. She frames the discussion around how Democrats will portray the bill in the midterm campaigns and invites Congressman Mike Lawler to provide the Republican perspective. The host also asks questions about the legislative agenda, foreign policy issues, and the New York City mayoral election, highlighting the economic implications and the potential consequences for the city.
summary.SPEAKER_02: Congressman Mike Lawler defends the Republican bill, emphasising its substantial tax cuts for middle-class families, seniors, and small businesses. He argues that Democrats are exaggerating the negative impacts and that the bill includes provisions to strengthen the social safety net through eligibility verification, citizenship verification, and work requirements for Medicaid. Lawler discusses the negotiations and trade-offs made in the bill, particularly regarding the SALT cap and Medicaid funding. He also outlines the Republican party's broader legislative agenda, including financial services regulation, deregulation, energy production, and foreign policy priorities. Furthermore, Lawler expresses his views on the weakened position of Xi Jinping, the potential consequences for trade negotiations, and his support for the Republican nominee for New York City mayor, Curtis Sliwa, warning against the potential dangers of a socialist mayor.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses a recent significant bill passed by the Republican-led House. Democrats criticise the bill for being the largest cut to healthcare and nutritional assistance in American history, harming vulnerable populations. Republicans defend the bill as the single largest middle-class tax cut, providing substantial benefits for families, seniors, and small businesses. They argue that Democrats misrepresent the bill and are using it for political gains ahead of the midterm elections. The discussion also touches upon the changes made to Medicaid eligibility, verification, and work requirements. Additionally, it briefly touches upon the broader legislative agenda, foreign policy concerns, and the upcoming New York City mayoral election.

video_title: China expert warns if the US does this, we risk global conflict

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: A new report from a foreign policy think tank is calling for the administration to take on a more defensive posture with China. In doing so, they say we have to drastically reduce the number of troops on China's doorstep. China expert Gordon Chang joins me now. Gordon, they're known as the restrainers. That's kind of the shorthand. They want us to pull back troops from Japan and Korea, South Korea. What do you make of that? What do you think of their suggestion?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: In general, they get one thing right and a lot of things wrong. In the moments before a war, it would be good if U.S. forces were dispersed throughout the region because that would make it harder for China to destroy them in the first half hour. And so, for instance, I don't think that the George Washington strike group, which is  Our group of ships centered around the George Washington and aircraft carrier. I don't think it should be in Yokosuka, Japan. I think it should be pulled back to at least Pearl Harbor. But the thing that is wrong about this report is that it believes that U.S. troops in the region cause tension with China. And that's absolutely wrong. U.S. troops and U.S. forces in the region create deterrence, which means they reduce tension.  and they drastically reduce the chance of war. And the symbolism of taking troops out of South Korea would be horrible right now after South Korea has just elected a leftist as president. Taking troops out of South Korea to the extent that they want could tip that country into China's hands. And so that's just wrong on all counts.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Now, as you well know, I mean, there are people in Congress like Rand Paul and others who who think that we are just spending too much of our own, not only money, but more importantly, human capital, sending all those troops.  over the keeping those troops there in such large numbers. I mean, there is a legitimate argument that perhaps just on the basis of humanity alone and our own troops, we pull some of the numbers back. But you would say what to that?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Well we do that. We risk global conflict. Right now there is a war in Ukraine. There was a war in Iran and Israel a war in Pakistan and India. And we've got insurgencies in North Africa that look like wars. One more war and it is global conflict.  And so what we need is the US forces to maintain presence and stability throughout the world. And we would be spending a lot more money and Rand Paul would be much more upset if we were involved in World War Three.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Alright, next one. Gordon Republicans are calling on the administration now to expedite a review of Chinese made drones. And of course we've seen these Chinese drones all over the world. They want the director of national intelligence, Tulsi Gabbard, to assess security risks  that they pose, do these drones pose a serious threat, not only to us, but to the whole world?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Well, of course they do. They're Chinese made and they send information back to China unless a user prohibits that. The other thing is that merely by buying drones from DJI, which makes 70% of the world's drones, a Chinese company based in Shenzhen,  What we're doing is we're enriching that company and we're helping a Chinese defense contractor. We should be stimulating domestic drone production in the U.S. as a matter of high priority. So yeah of course we shouldn't be buying Chinese drones. And when China talks about going to war and is mobilizing all of society to go to war  The fact that we even have to study this really says something's wrong in the Pentagon. They should be making decisions on the basis that we are on the edge of catastrophe because it looks like we are.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: That sounds sensible to me. Gordon, thank you very much. Gordon Chang, appreciate you being here.

summary.SPEAKER_00: Gordon Chang opposes reducing U.S. troops in Asia, arguing it would increase tension and the risk of war. He believes U.S. forces create deterrence. Chang also asserts that Chinese-made drones pose significant security risks due to data transmission back to China and support for Chinese defence contractors, advocating for a ban and domestic production.
summary.SPEAKER_01: The interviewer introduces the topics of U.S. troop presence in Asia and Chinese-made drones, seeking Chang's expert analysis on the suggestions made by a foreign policy think tank and Republicans in Congress.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses U.S. foreign policy towards China, focusing on military presence and the use of Chinese-made drones. Gordon Chang argues that maintaining a strong U.S. military presence in Asia is crucial for deterrence and global stability, while criticising a report that suggests reducing troops. He also emphasises the security risks posed by Chinese-made drones and advocates for domestic drone production.

video_title: 'BURIED': Who knew what kind of benefits illegal migrants were getting, Brenberg asks

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, not giving non-citizens access to benefits designed for Americans. Seems like common sense? Well, you'd be surprised. Because the White House is officially cutting off taxpayer-funded benefits from immigrants in the country illegally, saving Americans an estimated $40 billion.  The Trump administration says this has been going on for years, and this move isn't just welfare reform. It's a full-scale rollback of what the president calls decades of bureaucratic defiance. Brian, I'll come to you first. We're talking about Head Start. We're talking about technical education programs, free tuition, SNAP. What's the right thing to do?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Well, it's this. I mean, the crazy thing about these stories is who even knew what kind of benefits illegals were getting? I mean, it's all buried. It's all in the bureaucratic mess. And this is why people say that you've got a huge magnet in the United States. Because when you give away basically unlimited welfare benefits, it's a huge incentive for people to come here. So it's sort of obvious that we should end this. You have to be a citizen of the United States.  My view is we should reduce these benefits at the same time, which I think is what the big, beautiful bill, in a way, was starting to do across the board, get fraud out of this. But this is just a duh moment. Most Americans would look at this and say, yeah, why would we be giving those benefits?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Thank you for doing it. And the Democrats are playing fast and loose with the facts on the big, beautiful bill as it relates to this. What they're trying to say is those cuts in the big, beautiful bill were cutting Medicaid.  This is part of the cuts. Cutting it out for illegal immigrants and people that don't deserve to get the benefits. I mean, it just, it's... And people are gonna die, Charlie. I don't care. Yeah, I mean, that's the other thing. You know, I don't care what they say about Doge. Like, oh, he didn't do enough. The fact that we know what USAID does... The awareness was priceless. The awareness of funding transgender dance festivals in Bangladesh on my dime is crazy.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: What do you say, and I'm not saying I agree with this, but the pushback, Jerry, has always been, well, these kids were brought in by their parents. Why are we punishing them? They didn't do this, and yet you're taking benefits away from them. How do you solve the cries from the left about you're so mean, you don't believe in humanitarian issues, how dare you when they didn't choose this?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: And on top of that, just to continue your theory here, you know, a lot of people on the streets in this country, you know, some of them are here illegally. Do you just let that go on? Do you let it fester? These are the programs.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Yes.  All right, so there was a great clip that was circulating with a guy that goes to the board on CNN. And he had a diverse set of polls. And the question was, do you want to see illegals deported from this country? Not just the criminals. People who are illegal that don't belong here, do you want to see them out? And I believe down across the board, more than half. It was numbers higher than 50% saying, yes, get them out of here. And this brings us back to the heart of the birthright citizenship case.  President Trump's executive order on that matter, the lower courts trying to stall the project. I mean, at the end of the day, it's about constitutional interpretation. I can't wait until the Supreme Court takes it up because these people have been sucking up benefits that should be given to Americans for years and years and years.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: We put them up in luxury hotels.  I mean, whoever heard of this, you come here illegally, we're going to give you a debit card, we're going to put you up in a luxury hotel. By the way, we'll give you an app to tell you how to tap into these benefits. How to game the system. I mean, it really is kind of a joke. And we have a lot of poor people in this country. We have a lot of problems in this country. We've got a lot of poor vets in this country. Homeless people, people with mental illness. By the way, those people that are homeless, as much as we get enraged when we see them and they're violent.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: They need help.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: They need help. They need taxpayer money to get them off the streets and to take and to get treatment get mental And that's the type that's where we should be spending our money I think this is common-sense stuff, and I think when most people they say well you're depriving the kids of first off We're not starving the kids right we're depriving of the head start, and we're saying well, maybe  The parents got to go back.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Yeah, or you shouldn't be here.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Well, that's where the Democrats love to take the locus of responsibility from parents and put it on the state. So they're saying if you cut state benefits, you're hurting the children. I think the conservative answer is  Those children are in the care of their parents. The parents have to make a better choice. If they make an illegal choice, they need to undo that choice.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: I agree with you, but let's play devil's advocate. I'm eight months pregnant, and I'm desperate for my child to be an American citizen because I'm so sick of my horrible country and the American dream, and I run across the border for the sake of my child.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Well, I would argue that the 14th amendment doesn't actually provide birthright citizenship the way the Democrats read it You know what?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: I would say I would have a constitutional conversation about that in your own country and do it the legal way And by the way, look at what's going on in california. I mean one of the biggest clowns in politics has to be Gavin Newsom I mean, this is a guy that leads with his chin I mean, this is a state where if you took out like three big industry three big businesses, I guess isn't the video located in  in Silicon Valley. So that helps, right? That helps their economy. When you take that out, this is a state that's losing population, that is running on deficit mode without Silicon Valley. There's something called Medi-Cal, I think. It's their version of Medicare.  They put all the illegals on it every the illegal immigrants are sucking that dry And average people can't live in the state and they have a homeless problem in LA in San Francisco So Gavin Newsom, you know, the only the second best spokesman the second best gift for Republicans is After Mondami's number one Is that clown? Yeah, and I know and I'm by the way, he's a clown.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: I don't care what he thinks of me Well, you know, you're right to bring up the exceptions because that is the argument but exceptions make terrible policy Yeah  And I think Democrats know that, which is why they always want to talk exception so that you can get terrible policy. And then they've won. You've got to make policy on what's substantially actually happening.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: When they do that, then they say, oh, well, we've set precedent. We've been doing it for years and years and years and years. So if you've been breaking the rules or misreading the 14th Amendment for years and years and years, that means we can't ever stop doing it. I mean, that's essentially what they say in every aspect. It's like, well, we've been doing it. We can't stop now. Yes, you can.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: You know, that's my root causes.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Yes.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: I'm only kidding.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: I mean, what's interesting to me, and Charlie brought this up, is that I feel like the wool's been removed from our eyes. You know, we've seen so many things in the last couple of years that we've never seen before, and we're still all recovering from that. Charlie, thanks for being with us for the hour.

summary.SPEAKER_00: Plays devil's advocate, raising questions about the humanitarian impact of the policy, such as the consequences for children brought into the country illegally by their parents. Also, asks about a hypothetical scenario of a desperate parent seeking citizenship for their child.
summary.SPEAKER_01: Strongly supports the benefit cuts and argues that most Americans agree with deportation of illegal immigrants, not just criminals. He believes birthright citizenship is misconstrued under the 14th Amendment and argues that illegal immigrants are a burden on American resources. He criticizes Democratic policies and politicians, particularly Gavin Newsom, and suggests that exceptions to the rule make for terrible policy.
summary.SPEAKER_02: Introduces the topic and agrees with the benefit cuts, portraying them as a necessary step to stop perceived abuse of the system. Suggests that the cuts are part of a larger effort to address bureaucratic inefficiencies and reduce fraud.
summary.SPEAKER_03: Supports the benefit cuts, arguing they are a common-sense measure to reduce incentives for illegal immigration. He believes benefits should be prioritized for citizens and suggests that the system has been exploited. Criticizes Democrats for their stance on immigration and welfare.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the Trump administration's decision to cut off taxpayer-funded benefits to illegal immigrants. The speakers generally support this move, arguing it is a matter of common sense, fiscal responsibility, and ensuring benefits are prioritized for American citizens. They criticize Democrats for allegedly misrepresenting the cuts and for being too lenient on immigration. The discussion also touches on birthright citizenship, the perceived burden on states like California, and the broader implications of immigration policy on American society and welfare programs.

video_title: Trump EPA chief cuts millions in gov't waste earmarked for Biden's 'left-wing friends'

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: At the Trump EPA, the one big beautiful bill was filled with many big beautiful wins for the taxpayer. It delivered a sledgehammer to the Green New Scam. Billions of dollars rescinded. We want to give it back to the taxpayer. This is about us being good stewards of American tax dollars without any apology or regret.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: And that was EPA Administrator Lee Zeldin speaking at President Trump's sixth Cabinet meeting in his second term, happening this week. Lee Zeldin touting the progress made on the Trump agenda since the big, beautiful bill passed last week. And joining me now is the man himself, EPA Administrator Lee Zeldin. Lee, it's great to see you. Thank you so much for being here. And, you know, congratulations to you. You went into this job with a big agenda.  And you are knocking all of those jiu-jitsus off your list. Tell me about the momentum made so far in the Trump administration in his agenda.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: The Trump mandate at the EPA is on both the operational side and the policy side. On the operational side, ending COVID-19 remote work, getting people back into the office, going through reorganization to right-size the agency. We don't want one more or one less person than we need to fulfill our statutory obligations and empower the great American comeback.  a lot of funding, tens of billions of dollars pushed through EPA that we had to get a handle over. I've canceled now over $22 billion worth of grants, which is over twice the size of our annual operating budget.  That's an important part of it. Now, on the policy side, a lot of President Trump's deregulatory agenda is inside of EPA. President Trump talks about a need to ensure Americans have access to clean air, land and water. It gets to our core mission of EPA. It gets to our first pillar of powering the great American comeback. The Trump mandate that the American people voted for last November also includes unleashing energy dominance, permitting reform,  Advancing cooperative federalism, making America the AI capital of the world, bringing back, protecting American auto jobs. EPA has a lot that we could do on all these fronts in order to both protect the environment and grow the economy. While we're at it, that means that we will have more deregulation in one agency.  Then, the entire federal governments across all agencies, across entire presidencies, when you look back in history, that's how much of a mess it was that we inherited from the Biden administration with all of their rules and regulations, seeking to strangulate entire industries with new rules in 2023 and 2024.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: And you've been able to really cut a lot of that out, right, Lee? I mean, you went in there trying to understand specifically where the wasteful spending is, and you started cutting aggressively. Where are you in that process, in terms of cuts?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: The grants, over $22 billion, are canceled. Huge. The biggest pot of money was from the Greenhouse Gas Reduction Fund. It was part of the Inflation Reduction Act. $20 billion were parked at an outside bank towards the end of the Biden administration, given through eight pass-throughs, in many cases going through additional pass-throughs, self-dealing in conflicts of interest with former Obama, Biden officials, Democratic donors getting access to money.  Unqualified recipients, reduced agency oversight, those grants are canceled. Right now, the plaintiffs, the recipients, are now litigants. So we're in court in the D.C. Circuit with regards to the Greenhouse Gas Reduction Fund.  And we're confident that we made the right decision. We're very confident that we made the right decision on behalf of the American taxpayer. There was no alternative. This was a responsibility of ours to be a good steward of tax dollars, to institute a zero-tolerance policy towards waste and abuse, and not to be paying off all these well-connected left-wing friends of the Biden administration.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Yeah, and these were career professionals in some regard at the EPA. Do you believe that you've made these cuts lawsuit-proof? Can you give us your expectation on the timeline of being in court with all of this stuff as, you know, the critics and the friends of the Biden administration try to stop you in this?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Well, the Supreme Court made it clear that where there is a contract that the government is choosing, in this case, to terminate grants, if the recipient has a complaint, it's something that goes to the Court of Federal Claims to debate, to argue, to litigate a  alleged breach of contract claim. The problem is, is that what the plaintiffs have been doing across this country with different cases is that they seek out activist judges at the district court level, instead of going to the court of federal claims.  And they don't care what the Supreme Court has previously ruled in that Department of Education case. So we're confident that we made the right decision, that we should not allow waste and abuse. We should not be lighting billions of dollars on fire. What the Democrats did when they had one-party rule to allow billions of dollars to go out the door like this is something that I believe that the American public, the will of the American people,  after they spoke last November, requires us to stop it, and that's something that we are fully prepared to litigate in any courtroom in America.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, there's also such an egregious way about doing some of it, because they were trying to send out all that money, like, weeks before President Trump's inauguration.  I mean, they were trying to get, you know, whatever money they had left, they wanted to send it to all their, you know, quote-unquote philanthropies before President Trump got in there and put you to work and others to work to actually get rid of this stuff, right?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Yeah, they were amending account control agreements one week before Inauguration Day, January 13th of 2025. They're still amending the agreement for the purpose of reducing agency oversight. That's right. And in their own words, they were caught on camera, Biden EPA officials talking about how they're tossing gold bars off the Titanic. Yeah, that's right. The gold bars are tax dollars off the Titanic means they know they were wasting it.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: So, the EPA releasing new resources giving Americans total transparency on questions surrounding geoengineering and contrails, the line-shaped clouds seen coming out of airplane exhaust systems, Lee. What do you want to tell us about this? You say Americans are going to have access to all the information that you have.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Correct. I want the public to know whatever EPA knows. I want the public to know whatever information I come in contact with. Yesterday, we put websites up at epa.gov slash contrails and epa.gov slash geoengineering. And all I care about is facts.  And this is what happened when I started these meetings over the course of these last few months, sitting down with people, whether they're inside of our agency or it's meetings, conversations, gathering information at other agencies. I just want facts, truth. There are questions that are out there. What are the answers? No bias. Just truth.  put out to the American public answers to their questions. And here's one of the problems is, over the course of years, on so many different topics, the American public will ask questions, and then government just won't dedicate any time or energy towards answering the American public's questions. And as a result, there's a distrust of government that ends up forming. We're here as representatives of the people. This is a republic.  And whether you're serving an elected office or you're coming and working at a federal agency, it is our duty every single day, all day long, to make the American people proud in doing our jobs, fulfilling our oath, fulfilling our statutory obligations. And in this case, questions are asked. It's our duty to find answers. I want the American public to know whatever I know, whatever the agency knows.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Let me ask you about A.I. The administration is definitely putting a focus on A.I., as well as a focus on nuclear power, all hands on deck. You and Doug Burgum and Chris Wright have talked about nuclear power. But the A.I. angle here is important because A.I. has become so efficient.  Managers and CEOs have told me that AI efficiency is, of course, going to cut out jobs. So, what do we do to ensure that those people losing a job as a result of AI efficiency can find another job where you're actually prioritizing, like nuclear and like other opportunities within this government?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Well, first off, we have no choice but to win this A.I. race to make America the A.I. capital of the world. There is no alternative. We have to do everything in our power to increase baseload power. That creates jobs. That brings down energy costs. That improves us economically, national security. I would argue it helps our environment, too, because we produce energy better than so many other countries around the world and more economic prosperity in our country.  means more jobs in other sectors, more people here spending money. A more prosperous country helps Americans everywhere. So we have to win this race.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Yeah, and I love all the executive orders that President Trump has signed with regard to nuclear. I know you're working hard on that as well. Lee, it's great to see you this morning. Thank you, sir.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Thanks, Maria.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: All right, Lee Zeldin joining us. We'll be right back.

summary.SPEAKER_01: Lee Zeldin, EPA Administrator, outlines his achievements in cancelling grants, prioritising deregulation, and enhancing transparency. He emphasises the need to be good stewards of tax dollars, protect the environment while growing the economy, and unleashing energy dominance. Zeldin discusses legal battles over grant cancellations, the importance of facts and truth in government communication, and the administration's focus on AI and nuclear power to create jobs and improve economic prosperity.
summary.SPEAKER_02: The interviewer, Maria, congratulates Zeldin on his progress and asks questions about the specific grants cancelled, the legal challenges faced, and the administration's broader priorities such as AI, nuclear power, and transparency. She also expresses support for the executive orders signed regarding nuclear power.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses EPA Administrator Lee Zeldin's efforts to implement the Trump administration's agenda at the EPA, focusing on deregulation, waste reduction, and transparency. Zeldin highlights the cancellation of over $22 billion in grants, particularly from the Greenhouse Gas Reduction Fund, and emphasises the need for energy dominance, permitting reform, and advancing cooperative federalism. He also touches on the release of resources on geoengineering and contrails and the administration's focus on AI and nuclear power.

video_title: America's Firefighters Support President Trump's One Big Beautiful Bill

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: We believe that this bill is going to impact the lives of working families all throughout the United States. In particular, our seniors with tax breaks on Social Security, as well as our hard-working firefighters throughout the United States that are putting in excess overtime.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: President Trump's plan on the SALT reduction will provide immediate assistance and relief to our members, preventing them from being forced out of the communities that we live in, take pride in, and we serve in moments of crisis.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: President Trump's plan to stop taxing overtime will be a great benefit to our firefighters, where they can keep more money that they've actually earned.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: President Trump has offered up to $8,000 in tax credit for childcare and in-home service, easing the burden on working firefighters.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: President Trump would like to give us an extra $4,000 tax break. That is huge for a lot of our citizens, our seniors, and our firefighters. That can mean the difference of paying your mortgage, your rent, and food on the table.

summary.SPEAKER_00: Supports the tax plan, highlighting potential benefits such as an extra $4000 tax break for citizens, seniors, and firefighters, which could help pay essential bills.
summary.SPEAKER_01: Emphasises the positive impact of the plan on firefighters, particularly the proposal to stop taxing overtime, allowing them to retain more of their hard-earned money.
summary.SPEAKER_02: Supports the bill, noting its benefits for working families, including seniors with tax breaks on Social Security, and firefighters who often work excessive overtime.
summary.SPEAKER_03: Highlights another aspect of the tax plan, which offers up to $8000 in tax credit for childcare and in-home services, specifically aimed at easing the burden on working firefighters.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses a proposed tax plan by President Trump which aims to provide tax relief to specific working-class groups in the U.S., including seniors, firefighters, and working families.

video_title: NOW That’s What I Call Freedom 2025: The One Big Beautiful Bill

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Are you ready? For now. All of today's hottest issues taken care of in One Big Beautiful Bill. Move into a new dimension with the year's biggest topics taken care of. Smash hits from no tax on tips, no tax on overtime, strengthening social security, border security, and more. The One Big Beautiful Bill delivers the biggest results you crave. But you must call members of Congress to vote yes today. There's never been One Big Beautiful Bill like this until now. Now that's what I call freedom.

summary.SPEAKER_00: The speaker is promoting a comprehensive bill called "One Big Beautiful Bill" that addresses several key political and social issues such as no tax on tips, no tax on overtime, strengthening social security, and border security. The speaker emphasizes the urgency of calling members of Congress to vote yes on the bill today.
summary.high_level_summary: The speaker is promoting a comprehensive bill that addresses several key political and social issues.

video_title: Vote YES on the One Big Beautiful Bill — OR GET OUT THE WAY.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Did you vote today?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Yep. And I got my sticker to prove it.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: I'm going at lunch. I can't wait.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Only time I vote is for American Idol. And you know what I'm doing at lunch today? Updating my Facebook profile. You guys on Facebook? Didn't think so. Besides, one vote means diddly-squat.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Whoa! You can't talk that smack and not get knocked back, Gabby! Vote is your voice! That's how it counts in Constitutional, baby! You better vote or your shoes will roll! Whoa! Sucka!

summary.SPEAKER_00: Speaker_00 asks if others voted and plans to vote at lunch.
summary.SPEAKER_01: Speaker_01 confirms they voted and shows their sticker.
summary.SPEAKER_02: Speaker_02 states they only vote for American Idol, dismisses regular voting as insignificant, and plans to update Facebook at lunch.
summary.SPEAKER_03: Speaker_03 strongly criticises SPEAKER_02 for not voting, asserting that voting is a fundamental right and responsibility, and playfully warns of consequences.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses voting. SPEAKER_01 and SPEAKER_00 encourage voting while SPEAKER_02 expresses disinterest and cynicism. SPEAKER_03 then passionately defends the importance of voting.

video_title: JACKPOT! With The One Big Beautiful Bill, American Workers WIN BIG
President Trump Gaggles with Press Before Departing the White House, July 1, 2025

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Good morning. We're going out to Alligator Alcatraz. It's the East Coast version. And it should be very exciting, very good. Worked very hard on it with Ron and everybody. And I think it's going to be great. And then I'll be back here fighting for the bill. And I hear it's going okay. We're moving along. But we'll be back here pretty early.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: We're going to have to see the final version.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: I don't want to go too crazy with cuts. I don't like cuts. There are certain things that have been cut, which is good. I think we're doing well. We're going to have to see some very complicated stuff. Great enthusiasm, as you know. And I think, in the end, we're going to have it. What do you think, Caroline?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: What do you make about Sohran Mamdani having such a hard time condemning the phrase, globalize the intifada?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: I think he's terrible. He's a communist. The last thing we need is a communist. I said there will never be socialism in the United States. Now we have a communist. I think it's bad news. And I think I'm going to have a lot of fun with him, watching him, because he has to come right to this building to get his money.  And don't worry, he's not going to run away with anything. I think he's a — frankly, I've heard he's a total nutjob. I think the people of New York are crazy. If they go this route, I think they're crazy. We will have a communist in the — for the first time, really, a pure, true communist. He wants to operate the grocery stores, the department stores. What about the people over there? I think it's crazy.  What happened to Elon Musk? Nothing. No, he's upset that he's losing his EV mandate. He's upset. He's very upset about things. But, you know, he could lose a lot more than that. I can tell you right now. Elon can lose a lot more than that.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Do you expect a ceasefire in Gaza to be agreed to before Prime Minister Netanyahu comes next week?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: We hope it's going to happen, and we're looking forward to it happening sometime next week. Would that have to include the release of all of the hostages?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: We want to get our hostages out. We want to get the hostages out. What if the big, beautiful bill doesn't pass? Do you have to go through item by item by item and pass this stuff one at a time, or are you just going to try again?  I think we're going to get there. It's tough.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: We're trying to break it down — break it down so it's really good for the country. We're trying to get a lot for everybody. And it's a big bill.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: And smaller bills would have been easy, but they wouldn't have been as good. I think it's going to be okay. And with the alligator, Alcatraz, it's the idea that if some illegal immigrant escapes, they just get eaten by an alligator or a snake or something? I guess that's the concept.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: This is not a nice business. I guess that's the concept. If you — you know, the snakes are fast, but alligators — we're going to teach them how to run.  away from an alligator, okay? If they escape prison. How to run away. Don't run in a straight line. Run like this. And you know what? Your chances go up about 1 percent. Okay?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: It's not a good thing.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: The Press What do you got to talk about right now, Mr. President? The President Well, he's got me here. We're going to talk about a lot of things. We're going to talk about the great success we had. I mean, we had an incredible — in Iran, we had an incredible success.  Like, really, nobody has had in many, many years. That was a precision war strike. And the word obliteration can now be used because the Atomic Energy Commission said, You can't even get into the place. It was demolished. It was really demolished. It was a great, brilliant strike. And how did it go forward?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: We're also going to talk about Gaza. We want to get the rest. We've got a lot of hostages back, but we're going to talk about that. The Press.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: I don't know. I think we have to take a look. We might have to put Doge on Elon. You know what Doge is? Doge is the monster that might have to go back and eat Elon. Wouldn't that be terrible? He gets a lot of subsidies, Peter. But Elon is very upset that the EV mandate  It's going to be terminated. And you know what? When you look at it, who wants — not everybody wants an electric car. I don't want an electric car. I want to have maybe gasoline, maybe electric, maybe a hybrid, maybe someday a hydrogen. If you have a hydrogen car, it has one problem — it blows up, you know? So I'm going to give that one to Peter.  And when they blow up in Syria, they find you five blocks away. The Press. The Press. The Press.  The Republicans have their heart in it. The Democrats want to — they just want to destroy our country. A Democrat wants to destroy the country. They won't vote on it. They don't vote on anything. This is the biggest tax cut in history. The biggest — everything. Everything is the biggest in history. It's the best bill we've ever had. We can't get one Democrat vote.  When do you think you'll get final passes? Very nice guy. When do you think you'll get final passes to the bill? Hopefully soon. Hopefully today. We can. Final passes. When I say final, final is let's take Senate at a time, okay? But I think Senate should be today, and we owe that. And what about Sugar Murkowski? Is there any way to pay pay her? Who knows? You tell me. You tell me. Is there?  Alaska has done so well with me. There's never been a president better to Alaska than me.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: But it doesn't mean people appreciate it. Support your bill from the point of view that it keeps  tax dollars and funding abortion. They really support that. But Catholic bishops are worried that it will hurt immigrant families and children who have strong ties to American communities. What do you tell the Catholic bishops, sir?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: I think we're going to have a good relationship with the Catholic bishops. As you know, I won the Catholic vote by a lot. Not by a little, by a lot. And we have very good relationships, and we'll see what happens. We deal with them, and we deal with them well. But I won the Catholic population by a lot.  What's your message to Republicans that are not yet on board? The President I think it would be very wise for them to get on board. I really do. I think it's a great bill. Nothing is easy because we've made it great big. We added everything in there for everybody. And it's also a beautiful economic development bill. Great for the border. Great for low taxes.  And I would say that they have to go, really.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: I would say that. And if they don't do it, we'll go and shuffle the guns again.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: The Press And on the timeline, are you hoping to move it back to the timeline, Mr. President? Or do you want to keep it to the July 4th? You're open on that. The President I'd love to do July 4th, but I think it's very hard to do July 4th. It was two months ago.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: I would make maybe July 4th, but somewhere around there. The Press Mr. President, what did you make of that? That Republicans that vote for this bill should hang their head in shame?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: What did you make of that? The President Look, Elon is not getting his mandate.  He wanted an election mandate. And you should have known I wouldn't do that. I couldn't do that. I campaigned on this thing for three years. I never understand why he did what he did. But he's not going to get his mandate.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: And he better be careful, because he might not get anything else.

summary.SPEAKER_00: SPEAKER_00 focusses on the final version of the bill, its potential impacts, and the challenges in getting it passed. They also inquire about the timeline for the ceasefire in Gaza and the implications of not passing the bill.
summary.SPEAKER_01: SPEAKER_01 raises questions about the bill, its support from different groups like Catholic bishops, and the potential consequences for Republicans who do not support it. They also discuss the concept of "Alligator Alcatraz" and its implications.
summary.SPEAKER_02: SPEAKER_02, likely Donald Trump, promotes "Alligator Alcatraz" and defends the bill. He criticises Sohran Mamdani, labels him a communist, and expresses confidence in getting the bill passed. He also discusses the situation in Iran and Gaza, his relationship with Catholic bishops, and takes issue with Elon Musk over the EV mandate.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses various political and policy matters including a new project called "Alligator Alcatraz", a complex bill, international relations with Iran and Gaza, criticism of public figures like Sohran Mamdani and Elon Musk, and challenges in passing the bill through Congress.

video_title: President Trump Arrives Dade - Collier Training and Transition Airport, July 01, 2025

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Hello, everybody. The trip was nice, and the job they've done is fantastic. And this is what you need. And Ron worked beautifully with Christy and all of the people at Homeland Security and got it done in how many days, Ron?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Eight days, a new facility was up and running, so.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Is this a model going forward, Mr. President?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: It can be. I mean, you don't always have land so beautiful and so secure. We have a lot of bodyguards and a lot of cops that are in the form of alligators. You don't have to pay them so much. But I wouldn't want to run through the Everglades for long. We'll keep people where they're supposed to be. This is a very important thing. We're setting records at the board. You know, we had no people come through last month. Zero. No people.  But we're going to keep it that way. So Ron did great. And I want to thank you.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Well, look, we thank you, Mr. President. Thanks for your leadership. The border, you did that quicker than we knew you'd do it, but you did it so quick, which is great. But Biden let in how many millions  And you got to take care of them. And so this is one example of state operating this. The feds are approving it, supporting it. We're also going to have 2,000 more at Camp Blanding, which is our National Guard site. And we're the only state in the country that mandates our state and locals, law enforcement, to cooperate with ICE. And it's made a huge difference. On any given day, Florida constitutes about 20% of all immigration arrests nationwide. And that's just because of the partnership that we have.  So I think it's great that the president's here. What I would just say is don't let Florida be the only state. We've got very red states that should be doing this just as much as Florida is doing. That will increase their numbers. And then what happens is you'll have a lot of people that will deport on their own because they don't want to end up in an alligator alcatraz or some of those other places. So I think this is a model, but we need other states to step up.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: I was going to ask you, would this be enticing for other states to come up with their own model?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: They are doing it. We have Louisiana doing it big. Alabama is doing it. We have a lot of states. They seem to be red states, not too many blue states, for whatever reason. But the red states, Republican-run states are doing it. The blue states don't do very well at security.  policing, unfortunately. What would you say, Chris?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: You know, I would say that exactly right. The governor here has been fantastic in forming this partnership with the Department of Homeland Security. We were looking at different contracts with different vendors and thought, why not go straight to our governors and ask them to help us solve this problem? Florida was unique in what they presented to us, and I would ask every other governor to do the exact same thing. This is unique because we can hold individuals here. They can have their hearings.  to get due process and then immediately be flown back home to their home countries. And their home countries are welcoming them. They're setting up loans for houses. They've got food assistance. They're helping to facilitate welcoming them home. I just got home from Panama, Costa Rica, Guatemala, Honduras, and they're all excited about getting their individuals back home from the United States.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: And there is a lot of self-deporting. There is. That's one thing I was actually surprised. But a lot of self-deporting. And when you have something like this, even more so. So, I'd ask Ron one question. I flew over the Everglades. We did a little circle. I said, let me see. That's a big piece of land. I think it's 25 minutes to fly around. Is there potential for  enlargement or additional facilities out there?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: There may be. I mean, I think what we're doing is, because this is an important part of Florida, we're using the existing footprint of this airport. So when you guys go over there, you'll see all the beds, the medical, the galley, everything is on the concrete. We're not using any of the other stuff. Now, as you'll see, there's a lot of concrete, so there very well may be. I know Secretary Noem and her team have said, as soon as the president departs,  We'll be open to start receiving folks and so we'll see what the tempo is. We do have the 2000 in Northeast Florida that will open very soon. So it is possible to do. One of the things I think that is exciting about this is we're offering up our National Guard and other folks in Florida  to be deputized to be immigration judges. We're working with the Department of Justice for the approvals. I'm sure Pam will approve. But then you have, I'll have a National Guard judge advocate here. Someone has a notice to appear. Biden would tell him to come back in three years and appear.  Now you'll be able to appear in like a day or two, so they're not going to be detained hopefully for all that long. We'll have people here in this facility that can make, you know, it's a bureaucracy. The president's got to deal with the bureaucracy. Now that Supreme Court ruling was good because that's going to allow him to be able to exercise Article 2 the way founders intended, but you still have bureaucracy. So we want to cut through that so that we have an efficient operation between Florida and DHS to get the removal of these illegals done.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Are you going after the worst of the worst, or are you now arresting anyone who is here?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: We're doing the worst of the worst, always first. And I think it's great government, what we've done. And nobody can ever forget what this group of people, Biden or whoever it was, because it probably wasn't even Biden, I don't think he knew what that was.  Biden, whoever it was, what this group of people, a small group that circled the Resolute Desk, what they did to this country. Think of it, what your time, all the time you have to waste doing this. It's an unforced error. We had nothing. We had no problem with this. There was never anything like this. We had great borders. It was bad when I came in. Within three months, I fixed them. This is in 2016. Now I come in, the difference is this was 20 times worse.  Their open border policy did so much damage to our country, and we're fixing it. But the effort and the money and all the things that it takes to do it is just like an unforced error. Yes.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Mr. President, in 2018, you suggested putting alligators in the Rio Grande.  to prevent crossings in Texas. Is this a dream come true for you, sir?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Well, I was thinking about that, I must say. It was meant more as a joke, but the more I thought of it, the more I liked it, if you want to know the truth. And they were seriously — they were actually crocodiles. They were crocodiles from Africa. They are a step beyond. A step beyond. No, that was really meant as a joke, but a lot of people liked it, and a lot of people think we should do it, frankly.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: The Senate, it appears, is about to vote on your big, beautiful bill.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: I hear we're doing well, Ron.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: I hear we're doing well. Are you confident this can get done by the 4th of July?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: I don't know what does confident mean when you have one vote and you have 100 people going to vote. I think so. I think it's going to be the greatest bill ever passed, even for you as an example. Tremendous amount of Homeland Security money. Tremendous amount.  It's going to keep the border secure. Because, you know, we have them secure now, but we need to build more wall. I built almost 600 miles of wall. We need more wall. And all of that's covered in this bill. This bill is amazing for everybody. It's an amazing bill for Florida, too. Really great for Florida.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: No, no, we're not going to be playing with Medicaid.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Only waste, fraud and abuse. Yeah, the Democrats have it wrong. Yeah. Waste, fraud and abuse. In fact, if you look at what's gone on, we've gone way back. We take care of Medicaid. We take care of Medicare.  They will blow Medicare and Medicaid because they have no idea what they're doing. Just like they don't have any idea what they did on the border, they have no idea. Medicaid is in big trouble with the Democrats. The Press The President? The Press The President? The Press The President? The Press The President? The Press The President?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: The Press The President? The Press The President? The Press The President? The Press The President? The Press The President? The Press The President?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: The Press The President? The Press The President? The Press The President? The Press The President? The Press The President? The Press The President? The Press The President?

The Press The President? The Press The President? The Press The President? The Press The President? The Press The President? The Press The President? The Press The President? The Press The President? The Press The President?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: The Press The President? The Press The President  I'm watching it very closely. The Press.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Mr. President, about Prime Minister Netanyahu's visit next week, what are you hoping to get out of that? Do you think there'll be any progress?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Well, it's going to be a very quick celebration. We had a great hit. It was an obliteration. Okay, now it turns out it was an obliteration.  You know, they demean CNN mostly and the New York Times, fake New York Times. They demean these great soldiers. They went over there 17 hours flying, and they hit bullseye after bullseye after bullseye. It all blew up. Everybody saw it. Then they get back, and CNN said, well, they did okay, but maybe it wasn't. Let me tell you, it was beyond obliteration.  They can't — nobody can even get down there. The tunnels are busted. Everything fell into the well. It was a total and complete obliteration. And we should celebrate these heroes. And what I'm doing is I'm bringing them, Ron. We're bringing them to Florida or to the White House.  I gave them their choice. I think they're going to take the White House. Probably. I shouldn't tell you this.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Mr. President, there's going to be a new bill called Make American Elections Great Again. I love it. Forcing the U.S. Census Bureau to redo the census to actually get an account of how many Americans with proof of citizenship are in our area, in our country, redistricting some of the House districts. Your thoughts on that?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Well, I'll speak for both of us. We love it. You're going to like this one. I know all about it.  We want to bring our elections back. The election in 2020 was rigged. Millions and millions of votes. It had to do with COVID and a lot of things. But it really had to do with the crooked people. The Democrats are very good at cheating on elections. And that's why I said, too big to rig. They tried this one, too. But after about 902, they gave up too many votes. You know, too big to rig.  Ron would love it. I would love it. Christie would love it. That's what they have to do. They have to bring it back. And we have to look. You know, Ron, they include anybody that happens to be in your state.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: or California, that California would lose like five seats if they did a fair census. And even beyond that, the Biden census gypped Florida of at least one seat. We only got one seat in the last census. Are you trying to tell me that Florida only had one seat in that? We should have had at least two. Texas should have had another one. That could be the difference in the House of Representatives  the majority. So I would love for them to redo the census for 26. My legislature will redistrict those lines. We'll get it to where it's fair. But as it's right now, this country is not fairly apportioned. I've got so many more millions of people in Florida that have representation because of that flawed census.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: I think it's going to do very well. A lot of people, I don't know if you've heard, but it's like  It's captivated the country. Everybody wants it. It's going to get in. It's going to pass. And we're going to be very happy. The Press.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Mr. President, Tom Musk is ripping into this bill again. Are you concerned that Republicans are going to be swayed by Musk and his money?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: No, I don't think so. I think what's going to happen is Doge is going to look at Musk. And if Doge looks at Musk, we're going to save a fortune. Thank you very much, everybody. I don't think you should be playing that game with me. Mr. President, July 9th tariff guidelines. Thank you very much, everybody. Thank you, Mr. President.

summary.SPEAKER_01: Praises the rapid establishment of the new immigration facility in Florida. Highlights Florida's efforts in immigration enforcement, including cooperation with ICE and the construction of additional facilities. Emphasises the need for other red states to follow Florida's lead and advocates for a fair census that accurately accounts for citizens.
summary.SPEAKER_02: Inquires about the potential enticement of the new model for other states and the involvement of red states in similar initiatives.
summary.SPEAKER_03: Expresses satisfaction with the Florida facility and its role in securing the border. Criticises the previous administration's border policies and emphasises the need for more border wall construction. Supports a proposed federal bill that allocates funds to Homeland Security and border security. Discusses other political topics such as the treatment of veterans, the 2020 election results, and a potential census redo.
summary.SPEAKER_04: Acknowledgements the collaboration with Florida in establishing the immigration facility. Highlights the efficiency of the process and the cooperation between federal and state authorities. Discusses the support from home countries for the repatriation of individuals and the potential for self-deportation. Mentions the upcoming Senate vote on the federal bill and the importance of addressing waste, fraud, and abuse in Medicaid.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses a new immigration facility in Florida and its potential as a model for other states. It also touches on border security, a proposed federal bill, and other political topics.

video_title: President Trump Participates in a Guided Walking Tour of Alligator Alcatraz - Part 1

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: So, I thought this was so professional and so well done that you should come and look at it, as opposed to standing around and not knowing where we are. And we're just taking tours through the areas where they stay and the areas where the medical is and all. And they've really done, between Christy and Ron and the whole group,  It's really government working together. And congratulations to all of you. But I wanted you to see it, as opposed to waiting for us and then say, how was it? Right? It really is pretty amazing. Did they take the vote yet?  How's the vote going? I would normally be home waiting for the vote. Yes, we would. Or be in Congress. But I want to come down. I hear the vote's going to be good. You'll let me know. You'll let me know. Have they taken it yet? What's that? They're taking it now.  It's not concluded with the article. Boy, wouldn't that be an upset, huh?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Yeah. Are you confident that you can get through the House today?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Yeah. It's a great — it's the greatest tax cut in the history of our country. And if it doesn't pass, it's the biggest tax increase in the history of our country. That alone — 68 percent increase, as opposed to a massive cut. It's the biggest tax cut in the history of our country, and everybody gets it.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: The President and Madam Secretary, CNN yesterday pushed an app that lets you track where ICE agents are. Tom Homan was saying that perhaps CNN should be prosecuted for that.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: We're working with the Department of Justice to see if we can prosecute them for that because what they're doing is actively  encouraging people to avoid law enforcement activities, operations. And we're going to actually go after them and prosecute them with the partnership of PAM, if we can, because what they're doing, we believe, is illegal.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
