The agency is suddenly trying to save face by announcing it suspended six agents back in February, but no firings, just unpaid leave ranging from 10 to 42 days.  I want to be clear, unpaid leave is not accountability. The Secret Service tells Fox no one was fired because it wasn't just one person that failed here, but the entire agency. Secret Service failed more than President Trump, though, that day. Cori Comparatore's widow believes that if agents had done their job correctly, her husband would be alive today.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: I want to know what the hell they were thinking that day.  Where were they? Why weren't they paying attention? Why did they think that that roof didn't need covering? I can see it. You can see it from the farm show. Why wouldn't they? Why would they let the president come out? Why weren't they watching? We were all sitting ducks that day.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Former Secret Service agent Richard Staropoli is here. Richard, six short, unpaid suspensions. What's going on here?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: That's a pure smokescreen, Laura, right? What a waste of time. Secret Service waits a year, and this is the best they can come up with? They talk about six suspended agents that was done six months ago? Those suspensions are over and done with. If this was a private sector business, they would have fired every one of those people  and the additional people who are still in place, the senior leadership of the Secret Service. These people are directly responsible for an epic failure that was carried on live TV throughout the world. And if anyone doesn't think that every member of the Mujahideen, Hamas, Hezbollah, every adversary, everyone sitting in a cave with a tablecloth on his head, wasn't watching what went on and how unprotected the US Secret Service left

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: I still can't believe what happened.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: This is unacceptable.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: We still talk about it as a family, because we were in the car coming back from an event, and I heard it on radio. I said the president was just shot. I could just tell from the way everything stopped.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: And let's look at the bigger picture. There were 20,000 people there. The Secret Service left all of those people to what, their own devices? We've had another person shot, and Cory Comparatore gets shot on live TV in front of his family.  All Mrs. Comparatore wants is someone from the Secret Service to pay her a visit and sit down with this lady. Yet the big, bad Secret Service can't find the time to send somebody out to see her in Butler? Hell, I'll go do it, and I don't even know where Butler is, and I have no association with the Secret Service.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: I haven't had it for 10 years. The president was asked about this by Lara Trump over the weekend. Watch.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: They should have had somebody in the building. That was a mistake. They should have had communications with the local police. They weren't tied in. There were mistakes made, and that shouldn't have happened.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: He went on to say, basically, he loves the Secret Service. And he always has. They're very talented, very capable people. He said they had a bad day, and I think they'll admit that they had a rough day. But he has great confidence in these people.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Yeah, unfortunately, as a Secret Service agent, you can't have a bad day, right? Because the epic failure has such a huge cascading effect, I don't even know where to begin. People get killed when the Secret Service has a bad day. And the problem is other people see this, and that leads to additional attempts.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: We still don't know anything about Thomas Crooks, do we?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: I don't know. I mean, who was this guy? The reason we know so little about the investigation is because so little investigation was done. The FBI said they interviewed 1,000 people. Where are those interviews?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: How about the parents?  Well, what about the parents? They have no nothing about what their son was up to? How about the guy who tried to kill him at the golf course? I mean, we know almost nothing about him. He was over in Ukraine, I guess. He seems like a whack job. But that's also an odd. But thank God that one agent saw the barrel of the gun coming through the bush. Otherwise, we wouldn't have President Trump today. That's exactly right. And I like Sean Curran a lot. I think he was amazing that day, the new head of the Secret Service.  But there was so much that day that was wrong, it's kind of hard to think it just ends up in a bunch of suspensions. And I love all the people who served the president. I mean, it's a very hard job to do. But, you know, it's got to be someone. It's got to be you're fired here. Someone's got to hear that.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: But when the day rolls around where the actual shift agents, in this case led by detail leader Sean Curran, have to take action and physically jump on top of the president to shield him from gunfire, things have gone cataclysmically bad, right? This was a bad day for the Secret Service. If they just get back to the basics, the basics of what made them great and cover the bases, they can reinstill or at least begin to reinstill the public's confidence in their ability.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: saw him be ushered off the stage. But again, I worked for President Reagan, so I remember they got him out really fast. They threw him into the car. It took a while. I mean, it seemed like an eternity to get him off the stage. That was one of the things they pointed to, correct?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Yeah, that's a huge problem, right? Since you mentioned Reagan, the Reagan attempt is used by every law enforcement agency in the world as an example of how things should work.  Right. This event is used for the opposite reasons. This could be textbook reviewed by things that should never have happened.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: When someone's crawling on a roof, perhaps when someone's trying to bring a range finder into an event, perhaps not let them in. I mean, all of this is very, very disturbing. Richard, it's always great to have you on. Thank you very much. We think of the comparatory family tonight.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Hey, Sean Hannity here. Hey, click here to subscribe to Fox News' YouTube page and catch our hottest interviews and most compelling analysis. You will not get it anywhere else.

summary.SPEAKER_00: (Presumably former President Trump) Acknowledges that mistakes were made but emphasises his love and confidence in the Secret Service. He states that they had a bad day but downplays the severity of the failures.
summary.SPEAKER_02: Is shocked and appalled by the Secret Service's failures, questioning their basic competence and attention to detail. Feels that everyone present was at risk and demands answers.
summary.SPEAKER_03: Former Secret Service agent, calls the suspensions a smokescreen. Argues that in a private sector business, there would have been immediate firings. Emphasises the gravity of the situation, stating that Secret Service agents cannot afford bad days as they can lead to loss of life. Criticises the leadership and the lack of investigation into the shooter.
summary.SPEAKER_04: Expresses outrage over the Secret Service's handling of the situation, emphasising the need for accountability and highlighting the widow's grief. Criticises the lack of firings and questions the agency's actions and decision-making.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation criticises the Secret Service for inadequate accountability following a security failure. They discuss the lenient suspensions given to agents, the lack of transparency in the investigation, and the broader implications of the incident on public safety and national security.

video_title: Trump admin pushes to ban China from buying US farmland: ‘Farm security is national security’

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Welcome back to this special edition of Hannity. While Democrats continue their performative politics, Republicans are getting important work done. This morning, Senator Josh Hawley introduced legislation aimed at ending — at blocking Chinese corporations and CCP-linked individuals from buying farmland in the U.S.  This comes just two days after Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins unveiled the National Farm Security Action Plan meant to address threats from foreign governments like China. Secretary Rollins is here now with the latest. Thank you so much for joining us, Madam Secretary. So, first of all, tell us about what this plan involves.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, thanks for having me on. It's a beautiful night here at the White House, so really, really an honor to be on with you. Listen, two days ago, we took unprecedented action, unlike anything in American history to date. We had four cabinet secretaries, Defense Secretary Hegseth, Homeland Security Secretary Noem, Attorney General Bondi, White House Counselor Peter Navarro, three of our best governors, multiple leaders from the Hill.  And together, we said that farm security is national security. We cannot be the world's superpower if, in fact, our foreign adversaries are buying up all of our farmland, especially in strategic places around a lot of our military bases.  So we moved out a plan to start getting ahead of that right away. As you have mentioned, Senator Hawley was earlier on your show talking about what he's hoping to accomplish in Congress. We are working alongside all of our partners at the national, state, and local level to get our arms around this, to stop it from happening in the future, and to look at clawing it back as well.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Why do you think China is trying to buy up all this land?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: You know, China plays a long game. They are extremely smart about the way they approach this. They're looking to be the world's superpower. And here's what I do know. Guess how much land America owns in China? Zero. Guess how much land America has around Chinese military bases? Zero.  So, this president, President Trump, has been so resolute and so visionary in putting America first. But to do that, it isn't just a strong defense. It isn't just a strong economy. It isn't just a strong border. We have to protect our farms and our agriculture. If we can't feed ourselves, we are no longer the world's superpower. And that is what he's working to do. And he's got the right team on the field to do it. And we're making big progress.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: That is certainly true. Can you explain to us in very simple terms what exactly the plan that you're proffering now would actually do to prevent it? Absolutely.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: It's a seven-point plan. The first is what we talked about. The first of the seven is the farmland specifically. Working with Congress to move legislation through. We've got an executive order coming out soon. Working with the governors. 20 states have already passed legislation to ban the sale of China farmland.  Often, I say this a lot, the 10th Amendment, the Constitution, the states are the guardians at the gate. They're already moving forward and we're working alongside them. But it also includes, for example, today we fired at USDA 70 contractors that USDA, the American government, funds in these foreign adversarial countries who are doing research.  Now, nothing nefarious to report, but why are we using American taxpayer dollars to do that? Locking down our animal and plant disease, the agro-terrorism piece. Our great Attorney General, Pam Bondi, just two weeks ago went after a couple of Chinese researchers who were sneaking in seeds that would have really compromised our food supply system.  ensuring that animal disease isn't coming across the border. So it is an all-encompassing plan at usda.gov. We've released a lot of information on it. We're really excited about deploying immediately.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Real quickly, because we don't have a whole lot of time left yet, can you tell us who is it that you are running up against inside the government that is opposed to your efforts to kick China out of the United States?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, listen, all the Republicans are 100 percent aligned. I mean, this is and the people of America are as well. It's interesting. The blue states have not been leading on this. I am still trying to figure out why the 20 states that have passed laws, Governor Sanders, Governor Lee. I mean, all of our great red states are all the ones who've been leading. Kristi Noem is governor of South Dakota, was one of the real pioneers on this effort over the last few years. But my hope and vision and working alongside our president in this White House  This is not a red or blue issue. This is not a Democrat or Republican issue. This is national security. So I look forward to finding those additional allies out there and getting this done.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Well, it certainly shouldn't be. If you ever do run up against anybody who is lobbying on behalf of China in our government, I hope you'll be, we'll be the first people you come to to tell about it.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: You will.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: You have my commitment, Charlie.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Thank you. Thank you, Secretary Rollins.

summary.SPEAKER_01: The host introduces the topic, highlights Senator Hawley's legislation, and emphasizes the importance of the issue. He also expresses support for Secretary Rollins' efforts and invites her to expose any lobbying against the cause.
summary.SPEAKER_02: Secretary Rollins outlines the National Farm Security Action Plan, a seven-point strategy involving working with Congress, states, and executive orders to ban Chinese farmland purchases. She emphasizes the long-term strategic threat posed by China, highlights the need to protect U.S. food security, and notes that 20 states have already passed similar legislation.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the U.S. government's efforts to restrict Chinese corporations and CCP-linked individuals from purchasing farmland in the U.S. due to national security concerns.

video_title: Butler widow demands answers one year later: 'Our blood is all over their hands'

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: So this Sunday marks one year since then-candidate Donald Trump was shot on stage during a rally in Butler, Pennsylvania. It was a Saturday afternoon at one of many stunning moments in the campaign of 2024. I want to really see something that said, take a look at what happened.  So a firefighter, Corey Compitore, was in that crowd. He died from gunshot wounds. This morning, Corey's wife is questioning how that gunman was able to get so close to the future US president. Alexis McAdams reporting live when Trump was shot that day. She returns to Butler for us. And Alexis, what does Corey's wife have to say now?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Hi Bill, well we all remember where we were right on July 13th of last year and for the compoteur family they were right there in that field behind us. They lost everything that day. Corey was a firefighter, a dad and a husband and a friend of so many people here in Butler County. A year later, if you can believe it, after that gunman climbed on that building right behind me, the family says where are the answers about Thomas Crooks? Why don't we know more about him? But one thing they do believe is the Secret Service made major mistakes that day.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: We were all sitting ducks that day. Their blood, our blood is all over their hands. I'm angry.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: I lost the love of my life. The Secret Service admitting to multiple failures after a 20 year old gunman climbed onto a rooftop at a Trump rally in Butler, PA on July 13th of last year and fired off eight rounds.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Why weren't they paying attention?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Why did they think that that roof didn't need cover? Those gunshots nearly taking the life of President Trump. Critically injuring two men and killing Corey Comparatore, a husband, father and fireman. His wife Helen tells me she thinks about him every day.  year later doesn't get any easier.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: No. Sometimes I still just pretend he's at work and he's going to come home at the end of the day.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Police say Thomas Crooks fired those gunshots. Investigators say the once shy college kid planned this attack for days. Do you think Thomas Crooks did this all by himself? Honestly, I believe that  He could. I do believe I mean, kids can do those things when they're mentally not right. Did you think at this point there would be more answers?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Yes, especially about the shooter, which we still don't know.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Butler County Sheriff Mike Sloop says people are still grieving.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: They remember it like it was yesterday because in our minds.  And yours probably too. It was yesterday.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: I think everybody here is so shaken up and confused on what's even going on. We heard several gunshots. If you could sit down with the Secret Service, what would you tell them?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Why Butler? Why Butler? Why was that such a failure? I want to sit down and talk to them. I have the right to. They need to listen to me.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: So the Secret Service bill says they have made major changes since that day. This weekend, the family is having a cruise, a motorcycle ride for Cory Bill.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Remarkable stuff. Even one year later, our best to her. Thanks for being there, Alexis. That's right.

lines.speaker: Unidentified SPEAKER
lines.text: Thanks.

summary.SPEAKER_00: Introduces the topic of the anniversary of the Trump rally shooting in Butler, Pennsylvania, and highlights the questions raised by Corey Compitore's wife about the Secret Service's security lapses.
summary.SPEAKER_01: Expresses anger and grief, blaming the Secret Service for their negligence, stating they felt like sitting ducks. She demands answers about why the Secret Service did not adequately secure the area, specifically why the rooftop did not have cover.
summary.SPEAKER_03: Reports on the one-year anniversary of the shooting, providing details about Corey Compitore and his family. She summarises the wife's demands for answers from the Secret Service and highlights the Secret Service's admission of multiple failures. She also mentions the community's ongoing grief and the family's planned memorial events.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the anniversary of a shooting at a Trump rally in Butler, Pennsylvania, where a firefighter, Corey Compitore, was killed. His wife questions the Secret Service's failures that allowed the gunman to get so close, seeking answers and accountability. The family is still grieving and demands more transparency about the incident.

video_title: Former Biden staffer sheds light on 'bunker mentality' surrounding president

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Today, the next witness will testify in the House Oversight Committee's investigation into former President Joe Biden's decline. Ashley Williams, his former special assistant, will face questions on what she knew while working in the White House, but it still remains to be seen if she'll in fact answer any of those questions.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Michael LaRosa was press secretary for First Lady Jill Biden joins us now. Michael, great to have you here in studio. You know the inner workings of the Biden White House better than almost anyone. How crucial will Ashley Williams be to this investigation?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Ashley is an unflinching, loyal aide to the Bidens. She's part of a group that I think, she's been with them for a long time, first of all, but part of that group that I say is very emotionally and personally invested in the Bidens, her, Anthony, Annie, Tomasini, they were all given a lot of latitude and authority, so she knows  everything in terms of whatever accommodations that they're looking to discuss with Ashley. She would know a lot. She's smart. She's a lawyer in her own right. But hopefully, she takes a different approach than some of my other teammates have taken.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Dr. Kevin O'Connor's attorneys are urging House investigators to pause this probe. It's an interesting strategy. We've been watching this, obviously, for the last several days. And he seems to be saying this is a tactic, frankly, to avoid just managing the country.  And there are those, however, on the right who are saying this is a stalling tactic being rolled out by a guy who should have known better. What do you think of that?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: I think it's sort of reflective of my experience when I was there. There is a culture of evasiveness when it comes to transparency. I said to your colleague, Rachel Kamba-Stuffy, a couple weeks ago that they were allergic to transparency. And if you weren't stonewalling, if you weren't hiding the ball, it was usually a sign of betrayal or disloyalty to the Bidens. But I just don't think that this bunker mentality approach  is helpful to reputationally to the Bidens, to Dr. B and to the president. They should be full disclosure, full transparency, showing that they have nothing to hide. This bunker mentality is sort of a way that people approached politics in the 90s. And it's just not sustainable in the media environment we live in.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: I understand what you're saying about the media. And yes, we all want transparency. I think we can all agree that there wasn't any or wasn't much, I should say, with the Biden administration. But this is a hearing in front of Congress.  Transparency is a nice word, but when you're in front of Congress, you legally need to abide by the questions that you are asked, and you need to answer them truthfully.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: And so far, my colleagues, my former colleagues, are escalating a situation. They should be taking the air or the wind out of the sails of this story. I agree.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: It shouldn't be a story, but instead... So to that point, though, Michael, can Ashley Williams or any of these witnesses credibly deny that they did not see Joe Biden's mental decline?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: if they saw, I don't see how that's possible, given how close they, proximity and access they had. They had access to the residents. They had special badges. They were in charge of manifests and determined who was around Biden and when and how often and how frequent and for how long. They really were gatekeepers in the true sense of the word.  But again, like I said, because they were much more, they crossed that Rubicon from staff to family, which clouded a lot of their judgment as advisors. So when you have that close relationship to principals, you are  in the bubble in a way that others aren't and see, observe more than anybody.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: So you're in D.C., I'm in D.C., and that's always the real challenge. You don't want to get too close to the principal because then it can cloud your judgment. Michael, great to see you, my friend. Appreciate your time today.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: You too. Great to see you. Thanks for having me. You bet.

lines.speaker: Unidentified SPEAKER
lines.text: Tom.

summary.SPEAKER_01: The host introduces the topic, highlighting Ashley Williams' testimony and the potential impact it could have on the investigation. They also mention Dr. Kevin O'Connor's attorneys' urging to pause the probe and the differing viewpoints on this strategy.
summary.SPEAKER_02: Michael LaRosa, the former press secretary for First Lady Jill Biden, is interviewed. He emphasises Williams' knowledge but suggests she might take an evasive approach. LaRosa criticises the Biden White House for its alleged lack of transparency, arguing for full disclosure. He also implies that witnesses, due to their close proximity to the President, would have observed any potential decline in his mental health.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the House Oversight Committee's investigation into former President Joe Biden. The focus is on the testimony of Ashley Williams, a former special assistant, and the perceived culture of evasiveness within the Biden White House.

video_title: Pete Hegseth unleashes US drone production: 'This is the future!'

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: But in Washington, Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth is making efforts to streamline and modernize our military by employing more modern drones. Watch this.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: While our adversaries have produced millions of cheap drones, before us, we were mired in bureaucratic red tape. Not anymore. We're going to bolster the U.S. drone manufacturing base by producing thousands of American-made products. We'll arm combat units with a variety of low-cost, American-crafted drones. We're going to train as we've spec'd to fight. Senior officers, well, I'll grab this.  So this is the memo. Senior officers must overcome bureaucratic risk aversion in budgeting, weaponing, weaponeering, and training. So here's the memo we're signing today, delivered via drones. This is the future. We're in the fight. We're in the fight to win it. I'm never gonna back down.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: That's amazing. So, you know, it's interesting, you know, the degree to which drones have changed the entire landscape of war. And it's not easy to be a superpower when any country anywhere in the world can deploy tens of thousands of these cheap drones. This is an effort to balance that battlefield and win back the battlefield. And I think it's probably a very, very important overdue thing that we do.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Well, we saw the two parties so crystal clear during Hegseth's confirmation hearing, because you had the Democrats being like, well, what about women in the military, your personal life, yada, yada, yada. And then you had our secretary, Pete Hegseth, there talking about, no, we need to modernize the way we fight wars. ISIS doesn't follow the rules of engagement. We need to be smarter about what we do on the battlefield. And then also, by the way, we need to increase our recruiting numbers as well. So he was focused on the right things.  And this is so smart because you've got China is the leading producer and exporter of drones. You've also got China along with the China Cambodia Golden Dragon exercises in 2024 using robot dogs equipped with automatic rifles. So I think it's smart of us to catch up and make sure that we are the world's world's leader on all of this stuff and that we're up to date with how the new battlefield is going to look like.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Yeah, and you know, it's not just catching up. I mean, every senior military commander watched that video and did a fist pump in the air because you're talking about the bureaucratic process from weaponing, weaponeering, costs, getting things through the federal bureaucratic process is why he's cutting all through that red tape so that they can quickly get these American drones and get them on the battlefield  in lightning speed time because that's what's needed in the threat environment that he's putting his war fighters in the environment of. And by the way, let's not forget, you're talking about the confirmation hearings, he's being attacked about women in the military. Every service is 100% or more up in recruiting.

summary.SPEAKER_01: Speaker 01 highlights Hegseth's efforts to cut through bureaucratic red tape, bolster the US drone manufacturing base, and arm combat units with low-cost American-crafted drones. He symbolically signs a memo delivered via drones to underscore the future of warfare.
summary.SPEAKER_02: Speaker 02 supports Hegseth's initiative, noting that senior military commanders are eager to eliminate the bureaucratic hurdles that slow down the acquisition of weapons and equipment. He emphasises the urgent need to respond swiftly to the current threat environment.
summary.SPEAKER_03: Speaker 03 acknowledges the transformative impact of drones on warfare and the importance of the US balancing the battlefield against adversaries that can deploy cheap drones in large numbers. He views Hegseth's efforts as overdue and crucial.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses Defence Secretary Pete Hegseth's initiative to modernise the US military's drone usage. The speakers emphasise the need to streamline bureaucratic processes, increase American-made drone production, and counter the threat posed by cheap drones deployed by adversaries, particularly China.

video_title: Mahmoud Khalil files $20 million claim against Trump admin

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Anti-Israel activist Mahmoud Khalil bringing a $20 million claim against the Trump administration. He says he was falsely imprisoned and faced malicious prosecution after taking part in campus protests while being here on a green card. Former Deputy Assistant DHS Secretary and former Acting ICE Director Jonathan Fahey joins me now. Jonathan, I don't know much about the law, but I know this much. If you're going to sue the federal government, good luck with that. What say you?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Yeah, it's generally very difficult to successfully sue the federal government. And in this case, I think it's even particularly difficult because remember the case with Muhammad Khalil? He's released on bond, but the Trump administration is still appealing that decision and appealing the decision of the district court and also seeking to deport him because the secretary of state, Marco Rubio, determined his presence.  is adverse to American foreign policy, which is within the INA. So I think his problems are still going on with possibly being deported and also suing the federal government on things like false imprisonment, malicious prosecutions, a very heavy lift.  I think one of the most important points here, though, is it really just shows the difference between the Trump administration and the prior administration, meaning the Trump administration is removing people that they believe are a danger to the community or putting people in danger or adverse to our national interest, while the Biden administration did just the opposite and never even cared if somebody was adverse to our  national interest or national security, but I do agree with you. I think it's a heavy lift for him on that, but his problems are not over with on the deportation issue, and I think that's still his biggest issue that he may still very well be removed from the country.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Yeah, no question about that. By the way, I think it's important to point this out. He also says he will accept an apology.  He is justifying his claim by saying that the government is abusing its power because they think they're untouchable. And unless they feel there's some sort of accountability, this sort of abuse will continue to go unchecked. It's an interesting perspective on that. And I'm not so sure, even though he says he would take an apology, I'm not so sure how much water he's going to be able to tread with that. Meantime, a new New Hampshire, that is, federal judge  Jonathan is issuing a new nationwide block against President Trump's order seeking to end birthright citizenship. This is a district Judge Joseph LaPlante. He says the rapid adoption by executive order without legislation and the attending national debate of a new government policy of highly questionable constitutionality that would deny citizenship to many thousands of individuals previously granted citizenship under an indisputably longstanding policy.  constitutes irreparable harm, and that all class representatives could suffer irreparable harm absent an injunction. It's interesting because didn't we just tread this ground here? Didn't the Supreme Court weigh in on this, Jonathan?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Yeah, we sort of are in this world of like, here we go again. I think what this judge is doing that makes it a little bit different is in Amy Comey Barrett's decision, they talked about, well, if you're a member of a class action, it's different than just simply a nationwide injunction where they say, there's an issue before me and now my decision will apply to the entire country. To be a member of a class action, it's sort of a lengthy process where a judge has to determine that  There is a class that all the class has similar interests and other things like that. So, presumably, that's being done, and that's why he's doing this. But I think he might have been able to thread that needle, or he tried to. But I think one of the important points is, this will all become moot probably after the October argument, where the Supreme Court is going to actually weigh in on the merits of the birthright citizenship issue.  And there's a couple of ways it could go. It could go with Donald Trump entirely. It could go entirely against him. But there could be a middle ground where it says it's the role of Congress to determine what does it mean to be within the jurisdiction of the United States, because that's a core issue here. It's not just being born here. It's being born and being under the jurisdiction of the United States.  So ultimately, the Supreme Court will weigh in on this issue, but it does seem like we're going back to the same world that the Supreme Court just ruled on two weeks ago about these nationwide injunctions.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Yeah, recalcitrance in the judiciary, or so it would seem. Jonathan Fahey, thank you, my friend. Appreciate you joining us this morning. Have a good weekend.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: You too. Thank you. Thank you.

summary.SPEAKER_00: Fahey agrees that Khalil's lawsuit faces significant hurdles. He explains that the Trump administration is still appealing Khalil's release on bond and seeking his deportation. Fahey also discusses the birthright citizenship case, noting the recent nationwide block by a New Hampshire judge. He highlights the technical differences in this injunction compared to previous ones and suggests that the issue will ultimately be decided by the Supreme Court, which could rule in favour of Trump, against him, or remand the case to Congress.
summary.SPEAKER_01: The host finds it challenging for Khalil to win his lawsuit due to his ongoing deportation proceedings. He also notes the perceived difference in immigration enforcement between the Trump and Biden administrations and suggests Khalil's claim is politically motivated. Additionally, he expresses frustration with the repeated issuance of nationwide injunctions against presidential actions.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses two legal cases involving the Trump administration. The first case is about Mahmoud Khalil, an anti-Israel activist suing the Trump administration for false imprisonment and malicious prosecution after campus protests. The second case is about a new nationwide block against President Trump's order seeking to end birthright citizenship.

video_title: Protesters CLASH with ICE during raid; Homan responds

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: to a Fox News alert. The FBI is ordering a $50,000 reward for information on a masked protester who appeared to fire a gun at federal agents during a major California immigration raid yesterday.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Doug Luzader joins us now with the very latest. Good morning, Doug.  Hey, good morning, guys. Another rough day for federal immigration agents in California after facing off with violent protesters yesterday. Dozens of people were taken into custody during immigration sweeps at two farming sites, including a marijuana facility, tear gas, smoke bombs deployed.  Agents were pelted with rocks, and federal authorities are now on the lookout for a suspect who appeared to fire a gun at them. And now this from the U.S. Attorney for the Central District of California, who posted on X, the FBI has issued a $50,000 award for information leading to the conviction of an unknown subject who appeared to fire a pistol at federal law enforcement officers near Camarillo. And here is another shocking detail. According to Customs and Border Protection,  Eight unaccompanied minors, all here illegally, were found. There is now an investigation underway for possible child labor violations, they say. All of this as we await a decision from a federal judge in California who seems inclined now to severely limit immigration enforcement efforts by the Trump administration.  This Biden appointee indicating that she may issue a temporary restraining order today, essentially siding with litigants who argue that ICE agents are violating constitutional rights. So far, she says she has only reached a tentative decision, writing, it is truly a tentative. It is not final. My intention coming into this hearing, given the urgency and the weight of the matters at issue, is to issue my ruling tomorrow. But she has also said  that she does not want to burden what she calls lawful law enforcement activities. And again, that decision should come down later today. Back to you guys.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Thanks, Doug. Thank you, Errol.  You know, this is also strange, and maybe the strangest part of that ruling right there is the idea that when did federal judges begin giving alerts to what they're going to, how they're going to rule tomorrow, which at some point it starts to make you think that it's all kind of a coordinated effort to give people time to, you know, the ACLU to have a press conference, for example.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Yeah, it's unbelievable. You know, this judge, if this judge does go forward and issues this temporary restraining order, this is the equivalent of a judge making a ruling that the DEA can't go search individuals for drugs and narcotics on Skid Row in LA. It makes no sense. They're carrying out federal immigration law.  One of the groups in this lawsuit, CHIRLA, the Coalition for Immigration Rights, L.A., has been tied to the Alvarado, Texas, attack that, you know, where the 10 individuals, and we're going to talk more about that a little bit later. But, you know, connect these dots, and you see what is literally a federal judge now stepping in to say that the federal government can't carry out its duty for federal immigration law.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Well, because the judges are the new face of the resistance for the liberal left. And when they started doing it, Charlie, was when President Trump won office. They did it during his first term with all these nationwide injunctions that were issued. Now they're doing it again during his second term. But we need to be honest about what Democrats are doing. Their desire is to protect criminals.  You look at the deportations of these illegal aliens that have taken place under President Trump, 70% have been criminals or individuals pending charges. These aren't moms and kids that the Trump administration are trying to deport. They're illegal aliens, they're gang members, they're terrorists as well.  And you talked about the Alvarado attack, the ambush against the ICE agents there. They were outfitted in black military-style clothing, 12 sets of body armor, 14 guns, fireworks, spray paint, two-way radios, and anti-government propaganda. What do you think that sounds like they're preparing for?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Look at the video just from last night, from yesterday in Camarillo, Texas. It's unbelievable. The one news agency caught on camera would appear to be, and you can see the protesters pelting federal immigration vehicles with rocks. That is assaulting. That is textbook assaulting federal immigration, trying to deal with illegal aliens, 10 of which are minors. Now we're talking about child labor violations.  at this pot farm out in Camarillo. Look at him just pounding that. And then the one news organization capturing video of what appeared to be an individual firing a pistol at ICE, at federal law enforcement. And that, you know, those are fireworks, by the way. This has gotten out of hand.  This is a point that when you see this sort of response, and again, remember, this is a warrant that was being carried out. The federal immigration authorities got word that there were these two farms, one of them a marijuana farm, that was employing illegal aliens. They went in to carry out federal law enforcement and round people up in it. They found out that there were these 10 underage minors, eight of which were unaccompanied minors.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Which is kind of interesting, and then to have a federal judge then say that, no, you're rounding people up because they're brown, or because the color of their skin, or because of the language they speak. No, the whole point of a warrant is that you're not doing those things, that you're doing it with actual cause for. And of course, we've been talking about this all week with all of this crazy stuff going on, that at some point, somebody's going to get hurt.  And somebody, and then you have video of a protester firing a gun. Exactly.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: And that's what the borders are, you know, Tom Holman has been saying, he's saying, look, this is going to end with someone dying. This is going to end with ICE agents dying. And then what are Democrats doing? You only have Senator Fetterman who is saying, look, this is wrong. We should be calling this out. We should be saying that this is disgusting. No other Democrats are doing that. But what are they doing? What are senators like Cory Booker doing?  Not trying to remove the masks of ice agents, which further puts their lives at danger at a time when assaults are up by 700% on ice agents. Griff.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Yeah. And Charlie, I think you really hit the nail on the head. And that is imagine the week. Let me show you the week we've had in just the first.  10 days of July, an unprecedented number of attacks on ICE and federal law enforcement. Let's start on July 1st. In Buffalo, an individual named Matthew White posts on X, kill them all. The ICE is the new Gestapo stop, then he is facing federal charges for threatening ICE agents. Let's go to  Fourth of July, the Alvarado assault that we were talking about, Lisa was pointing out, they had AR-style rifles, they had body armor, they had two-way radios, they had Faraday bags that was trying to conceal cell phone, coordinated  planned premeditated attack, and of the 10 individuals now facing first-degree attempted murder of federal immigration officers, there is an 11th individual, Benjamin Song, on the run, allegedly provided those weapons to the 10 protesters. Then let's go down to McAllen, Texas. An absolute barrage of bullets from an assailant on a Border Patrol annex facility in McAllen, Texas, that housed a Special Operations Division  of border patrol, that individual deceased, but it's causing all BP facilities in Texas to get heightened security. Let's go to Tuesday, July 8th, the next day. That's when, as you're mentioning, Lisa, the Democrats, led by Cory Booker and Senator Padilla, wanting to unmask agents, while the agents, ICE, federal law enforcement, has said that they are wearing  identification of ICE and HSI on them, but they're covering their faces because there are individuals trying to publicly dox these agents, putting them, their families, their spouses, their children at heightened risk. Same day, you've got four arrested out in Van Nuys, California, for placing allegedly tire spikes in the road, puncturing the holes of ICE vehicles, trying to stop that raid.  By the way, that raid, a legal raid being carried out by Warren, and the same day you've got up in San Francisco agitators confronting ICE outside of immigration court. We have seen that in sanctuary cities like San Francisco, where the authorities will not turn over criminal, illegal aliens,  that have deportation orders. They just turn them loose on the streets. ICE trying to pick them up, but they're getting resistance and being assaulted there. And then finally, as we've been talking out in Camarillo, California, the unbelievable, there's a $50,000 reward. The U.S. attorney out there, Bill Isolay, saying that they want to capture that individual that appeared to fire  a weapon, fire a pistol at ICE agents who are carrying out a lawful warrant. This is the first 10 days of July. If we stay on this trajectory, Lisa, that's why Tom Homan is saying that he is, and we're going to talk to him in just a little bit. You know, yesterday on this couch, we asked Secretary Christy Noem, DHS Secretary, I said, are you worried that you're going to attend the funeral of one of your agents? And she said she thinks about it every day.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: I mean, it's just disgusting. And again, you're going to want to tune in for Tom Homan at 630 AM here.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Fox News Alert. Chaos in California. Federal agents deploying tear gas while protesters hurled rocks during an ice raid at a marijuana farm allegedly staffed by illegal immigrants.  the scene escalating when a protester seen here appears to fire a gun at the feds. The FBI now offering a $50,000 reward for info on the suspect. All of this comes as we await a ruling by a Biden-appointed federal judge who's expected to curb all federal immigration operations in Southern California.  Borders are Tom Homan joining us now. Tom, I watched that video out of Camarillo, California yesterday and was just mortified. What happened there and what is your reaction?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: My reaction is the same as it's been from day one. People are welcome to protest. They have their First Amendment rights, but they can't cross that line. They can't impede us from doing our job. That's a felony. They certainly can't put hands on an agent. That's a felony. So what happened in California is just another example of protesters becoming criminals.  And they've been emboldened by even members of Congress who compare ICE to Nazis and racists and terrorists. I mean, the rhetoric is so high. And I said two months ago, it's going to end up with a loss of life. And we had one the other day in Texas. And it's not over. I mean, the rhetoric has to end. ICE agents are simply enforcing law that members of Congress enacted.  that they wrote, they created, and was signed by a president. If people want to complain about the job ICE is doing, then go complain to Congress, because we're enforcing the laws they enacted. We're doing our job.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Hey Tom, can I just take you back? You just said you had a loss of life in Texas?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Yeah, he had a person attack a border patrol facility, firing at the facility, and border attack agents took him out.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Right, right, the individual that assaulted him lost his life. Okay, I was just clarifying, making sure you weren't making news there that an agent had lost his life, and that is of course the fear, but you talk about those politicians and the rhetoric that  clearly seems to be fueling much of this. But you've also got some distortion of the facts. This was a post that California Governor Gavin Newsom put up yesterday. Kids running from tear gas, crying on the phone because their mother was just taken from the fields. Trump calls me new scum, but he's the real scum. We later find out there were 10 juveniles in that operation, eight of which were unaccompanied minors.  What do you say?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: I see this every day. And I said from day one, when President Trump became president, that they're going to vilify the men and women of ICE. They'll vilify the men and women of Borbidgell. They did it during the last administration, except this time, the Reddits are at an all-time high. Every day, I get up and I read the media posts at the White House, and 90% of the stories are just fake. They're lies.  So, and people say, well, the polls are kind of turning against Donald Trump a little bit on immigration. First of all, I don't believe it. If the polls turn it off, it's because all the fake news out there, they're lying about what President Trump is doing. They're lying about what the men and women of ICE are doing. And that kind of turns, you know, the tide against us a little bit. But that's why, you know, members of the administration are out there every day setting the facts straight.  The fact is, I read the paper the other day, the majority of people who are arrested are not criminals. Wrong. Look at the data. Go to ICE.gov and look at the data. But we've got some media saying, well, it's just a misdemeanor. It's not a felony. They're not really criminal. Oh, they're not convicted. They're just charged. Oh, they're not criminals. No. We're prioritizing public safety threats and national security threats, and that's a fact.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: But Tom, it strikes me unbelievable that the Democrats are not on board. When you look at this raid, there were 10 juveniles that were illegally brought across the border. You and I covered this under the Biden administration. I was down in Texas. We encountered a eight  10-year-old, 12-year-olds coming across with just a name and an address and a phone number on their necks, the cartel ruthlessly sending them across. And yet now we know that 10 of them, eight of which were unaccompanied minors, working illegally in a marijuana farm. And your agents go in and rescue them, essentially. And yet there is violent resistance to that. Does that upset you?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: It certainly upsets me. And like I said, the work men and women of ICE are doing is incredible. Look, we're looking for over 300,000 missing children. We've already found 10,000. Have you heard that anywhere? No. The media is simply not covering it. And look, this should be a nonpartisan issue.  Public safety threats and national security threats, everybody be all the same page on that. Rescuing children, I mean, it should be a nonpartisan issue. Everybody should be in lockstep on that, but they're not. The media is lying. The Democrats are, they don't want President Trump to be successful. I got news for him. We are being successful. Every illegal alien public safety threat we arrest makes this country safer. Every national security threat we take off the street and deport makes us safer.  And we're rescuing thousands of children. The lives saved every day by ICE, the lives saved every day by Border Patrol are in the hundreds. The only thing I can think of, Griff, if they hate President Trump more than they love their community. They hate President Trump more than they want safe communities. There's just no other excuse why this has become a partisan issue to take public safety threats off the street.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: And before I run out of time, Tom, I've got to get your reaction to this Biden appointed federal judge out in Los Angeles, apparently expected today to issue a temporary restraining order halting your lawful operations. She says, I think it's important for the court not to burden otherwise lawful law enforcement activities. Your reaction there.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Look, people need to understand, ICE officers and border patrol, they don't need probable cause to walk up to somebody, briefly detain them and question them. They just need to tally the circumstances, right? They just got through their observation, you know, get articulable facts based on their location, their occupation, their physical appearance, their actions. A uniformed border patrol walks up to them at, for instance, a Home Depot.  And they've got all these articulable facts, plus the person walks away or runs away. Agents are trained what they need to detain somebody temporarily and question them. It's not probable cause, it's reasonable suspicion. We're trained on that. Every agent, every six months, gets Fourth Amendment training over and over again. These officers are really good at what they do. And if the judge is making a decision,  that's against what these officers are trained, what the law is based upon, then they're going to shut down operations. I think that's your endgame. They want ICE to stop doing this. But if they base it on the rule of law, they're going to find out. Borbatto and ICE are doing exactly what they're going to do in accordance with law.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: And you're not going to stop coming. Tom Homan, thank you for getting up with us this morning.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: You got it.

summary.SPEAKER_00: Reports on the FBI's $50,000 reward for information on the masked protester who fired at federal agents during the California immigration raid. Discusses the violent confrontation between agents and protesters, including the use of tear gas, smoke bombs, and rock-throwing. Mentions the discovery of eight unaccompanied minors at the raid site and the ongoing investigation for child labour violations. Also touches on the pending judicial decision that could restrict immigration enforcement.
summary.SPEAKER_01: Expresses concern about the escalating violence against federal immigration agents and the inflammatory rhetoric from some politicians that emboldens protesters. Emphasises that ICE agents are enforcing laws enacted by Congress and highlights the dangers they face. Criticises the media for spreading misinformation about ICE's activities and the criminality of the individuals they arrest. Points out that ICE has rescued many missing children and prioritises public safety and national security threats.
summary.SPEAKER_02: Comments on the judge's tentative decision to issue a temporary restraining order against immigration enforcement, suggesting it might be politically motivated. Expresses concern about the potential consequences of such a ruling on public safety. Questions the timing and transparency of the judge's announcement. Discusses the broader issue of how political discourse influences public behaviour and the safety of law enforcement officers.
summary.SPEAKER_03: Condemns the violence against ICE agents and criticises Democratic leaders for not adequately condemning such attacks. Highlights the specific incidents of violence, including the coordinated assault in Alvarado, Texas, and the attack on a Border Patrol facility. Argues that protesters are crossing a line into criminality and that many of the individuals arrested by ICE are criminals. Points out the hypocrisy in some politicians' statements about immigration and child welfare.
summary.SPEAKER_04: Agrees with the condemnation of violence against ICE agents and emphasises the need for stronger support from the Democratic Party. Criticises efforts to unmask ICE agents, arguing it puts their lives and families at risk. Discusses the broader political implications of immigration policies and the need for a more balanced approach. Highlights the safety concerns faced by law enforcement and the importance of enforcing immigration laws.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses a violent immigration raid in California where federal agents faced protesters, including one who allegedly fired a gun at them. The FBI is offering a reward for information on the suspect. The discussion also touches on a potential ruling by a Biden-appointed federal judge to limit immigration enforcement efforts, and the broader political and safety implications of immigration policies and protests.

video_title: BREAKING: FBI hunts for man who appeared to shoot at ICE agents

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: We'll start with this Fox News alert. The FBI is offering a big reward for information regarding a protester who appeared to fire a gun at federal agents during a California immigration raid yesterday.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Jackie Heiner joins us live from the White House. Good morning, Jackie.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Good morning to you guys. The FBI is offering 50 grand to anyone who helps them identify and convict a protester who allegedly fired a gun at federal immigration officers. That moment was captured by local news cameras. Federal immigration officers were carrying out a raid with a search warrant at a Southern California marijuana facility. Hundreds of protesters swarmed that area despite warnings from the U.S. attorney.  who told them not to interfere or they'd be charged with a federal offense. There were no reports of any injuries, but the video appears to show that man shooting a pistol at law enforcement agents. California Governor Gavin Newsom tried to politicize the moment, posting, Trump calls me new scum, but he's the real scum.  The CBP commissioner, Rodney Scott, replied to that, saying, here's some breaking news. Ten juveniles were found at this marijuana facility, all illegal aliens, eight of them unaccompanied. It's now under investigation for child labor violations. This is Newsom's California.  Authorities are sounding the alarm that escalating anti-ICE rhetoric could carry deadly consequences. But California Democratic Senator Alex Padilla is defending his proposal that would mandate ICE wear visible identification and ban them from concealing their faces during most operations, posting to X, in a democracy, no one should have to guess if they're being handcuffed by real law enforcement or armed imposters. My bill defends against unchecked power and unconstitutional overreach.  Acting ICE Director Todd Lyons tells Fox he doesn't love the masks, but they're necessary right now.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: If you looked at the beginning of this administration, you looked even in December, November of last year, we weren't wearing masks. ICE agents weren't wearing masks because they weren't afraid of their information being doxed, their photos taken, addresses posted. While I'm not a fan of the masks, I think we could do better, but we need to protect our agents and officers, and I fully support them in that.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: DHS says ICE agents have faced a near 700 percent increase in assaults recently, Griff.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: All right, Jackie, thank you very much. And let's just put this in perspective for our viewers. The first 10 days of July have been an absolutely unprecedented assault on federal immigration officers in a way we've never really seen before. As we know, those assaults are up 700 percent. Let's start on July 1st.  Matthew White, an individual in Buffalo, arrested and charged with threatening to kill an ice officer, writing on social media, kill them all. Ice is the New Age Gestapo. Get us to July 4th in Alvarado, TX. 10 individuals facing.  First degree murder charges of a federal immigration officer. While one in 11th individual is on the run, a manhunt is out for him. A $25,000 reward because that attack involved AR style rifles, body armor and two way radios. An officer was shot in the neck recovering. Thankfully you got Monday, July 7th down in McAllen, TX. The Border Patrol annex an individual, a barrage of bullets fired from an AR style rifle.  Border Patrol fortunately able to neutralize that and killed the individual but raising security concerns at all Texas Border Patrol facilities. July 8th, the next day, Senate Democrats don't read the room on the threats to federal immigration officers and you have Senator Cory Booker and Alex Padilla dropping legislation to force ICE agents to take their masks off, putting them and their families at greater risk of being doxed.  Same day, four arrested in Van Nuys, California, literally putting tire spikes down to disable ICE vehicles because they oppose a lawful federal immigration operation. Also on the same day in San Francisco, you've got protesters violently confronting ICE officials and officers trying to take into custody the criminal illegal aliens that had been marked  for deportation, just carrying out the laws Washington passed, but yet they violently are getting in the way. And then, of course, what we've all been watching all morning long out in Camarillo, California, a major raid. Those agents were being pelted with rocks, assaulted fireworks, and the one individual that appears to fire a handgun at ICE officers. And guys, the part of this story that's just heart-wrenching is that there were eight  unaccompanied minors that had somehow been trafficked into this situation. A total of 10 juveniles, eight unaccompanied, that were apprehended in this raid out in California.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: I mean, this makes me so mad. I don't know how anyone could take in what you just walked us through. And especially looking at, you know, potential labor, you know, what they did with these children, the eight unaccompanied minors, the 10 children that were found on this marijuana farm, and conclude that law enforcement  is  You had Attorney General Pam Bondi at the end of last month announced that federal authorities had arrested 2,700 Trinidad and Tobago gang members. I'm sorry, the people who are out there arresting and deporting those people, they are the heroes, not the villains. Yet the Democrats see them as the villains, not the heroes.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: And Borders are Tom Homan was with us the last hour and he talked about those unaccompanied minors found at the farm at the weed farm.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: It certainly upsets me. And like I said, the work men and women of ICE are doing is incredible. Look, we're looking for over 300,000 missing children. We've already found 10,000. Have you heard that anywhere? No. The media is simply not covering it. And look, this should be a nonpartisan issue. Arresting  Public safety threats and national security threats, everybody be on the same page on that. Rescuing children, I mean, it should be a nonpartisan issue. Everybody should be in lockstep on that, but they're not. The media is lying. The Democrats are taking, they don't want President Trump to be successful. I got news for him.  We are being successful. Every illegal alien public safety threat we arrest makes this country safer. Every national security threat we take off the street and deport makes us safer. And we're rescuing thousands of children. The lives saved every day by ICE, the lives saved every day by Border Patrol are in the hundreds. So the only thing I can think of, Griff, if they hate President Trump more than they love their community.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: So you're talking about a situation where you have these ICE officials trying to solve a human catastrophe that was entirely caused by Democrat politicians over the past four or five years. You have an investigation into child slavery, and then you have actual, as you went through,  violence being committed against officers who are sworn to uphold the law and enforce the laws, including ICE agents being fired at. And you have Gavin Newsom, the governor of California, who many Democrats view as the top person who could potentially run against, you know, get the party's nomination in 2028.  condemning the officers and condemning those trying to enforce the law. That's the situation where, you know, the rest of the country has moved on to trying to enforce the law, but that's where the Democrat Party is stuck. And you can't underscore the part about where Tom Hone was talking about rescuing these children. Gavin Newsom and all the Democrats need to remember. We can show you back a couple years ago in McAllen, by the way, the same city where we had that attack on the Border Patrol.  these children that were trafficked across the border unaccompanied. You can see here, I'm with Texas DPS, that boy was six years old with nothing but a little card around his neck with a name and a phone number of someone to contact. He was literally, we found him in the early hours just walking across  You know, the rescue of the eight unaccompanied minors in Camarillo, California, these are the most vulnerable individuals that were caught up in a chaos of the Biden administration and now out there. How many more are out there as ICE tries to carry out immigration?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Because it's not about the kids. It's about protecting criminals. That's what the Democrat Party is about.  I mean, that's exactly what's happening. That's what it's about. It's about protecting criminals. It's about going to El Salvador for people like Gilmour, Obrego, Garcia, and for shielding Trinidad and Tobago, not about protecting American citizens.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: It's all about them maintaining their power. I'm Steve Doocy. I'm Brian Kilmeade.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: And I'm Ainsley Earhart. And click here to subscribe to the Fox News YouTube page to catch our hottest interviews and most compelling analysis.

summary.SPEAKER_01: Defends the use of masks by ICE agents due to safety concerns related to doxing and harassment. Acknowledges that agents weren't wearing masks earlier but emphasises the need to protect them now. Highlights the nearly 700% increase in assaults on DHS agents.
summary.SPEAKER_02: Reports on the FBI's reward offer and the details of the California immigration raid. Mentions the warnings from the U.S. attorney to protesters and the subsequent confrontation. Introduces statements from California Governor Gavin Newsom, the CBP commissioner, and Senator Alex Padilla on the incident and related immigration policies.
summary.SPEAKER_03: Expresses outrage at the violence against ICE officers and the exploitation of children found at the marijuana facility. Emphasises the heroic work of ICE in arresting criminals and rescuing children, criticising the media and Democrats for portraying them as villains.
summary.SPEAKER_04: Introduces the topic and provides details about the FBI reward and the California immigration raid. Highlights the increasing assaults on federal immigration officers in July and the political responses from both sides. Discusses the discovery of unaccompanied minors at the farm and the broader implications for immigration policies and public safety.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses an FBI alert offering a reward for information on a protester who fired a gun at federal agents during a California immigration raid. The incident highlights escalating anti-ICE rhetoric and violence against federal immigration officers. The raid led to the discovery of ten juveniles, eight unaccompanied, at a marijuana facility, sparking discussions on child labour violations and immigration policies. The conversation also touches on political polarisation, with differing views on ICE's role and the treatment of immigration officers.

video_title: 'THAT'S A FELONY': Homan sounds off on violence against ICE agents

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Fox News alert chaos in California federal agents deploying tear gas while protesters hurled rocks during an ice raid at a marijuana farm allegedly staffed by illegal immigrants. The scene escalating when a protester seen here appears to fire a gun  at the Feds. The FBI now offering a $50,000 reward for info on the suspect. All of this comes as we await a ruling by a Biden-appointed federal judge who's expected to curb all federal immigration operations in Southern California. Borders are Tom Homan joining us now. Tom, I watched that video out of Camarillo, California yesterday and was just mortified. What happened there and what is your reaction?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: My reaction is the same as it's been from day one. People are welcome to protest. They have their First Amendment rights, correct, but they can't cross that line. They can't impede us from doing our job. That's a felony. They certainly can't put hands on an agent. That's a felony. So what happened in California is just another example of protesters becoming criminals.  And they've been emboldened by even members of Congress who compare ICE to Nazis and racists and terrorists. I mean, the rhetoric is so high. And I said two months ago, it's going to end up with a loss of life. And we had one the other day in Texas. And it's not over. I mean, the rhetoric has to end. ICE agents are simply enforcing law that members of Congress enacted.  that they wrote, they created, and was signed by a president. If people want to complain about the job ICE is doing, then go complain to Congress, because we're enforcing the laws they enacted. We're doing our job.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Hey, Tom, can I just take you back? You just said you had a loss of life in Texas?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Yeah, he had a person attack a Border Patrol facility, firing at the facility, and Border Patrol agents took him home.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Right, right, the individual that assaulted him lost his life. Okay, I was just clarifying, making sure you weren't making news there that an agent had lost his life, and that is of course a fear.  about those politicians and the rhetoric that clearly seems to be fueling much of this, but you've also got some distortion of the facts. This was a post that California Governor Gavin Newsom put up yesterday. Kids running from tear gas, crying on the phone because their mother was just taken from the fields. Trump calls me new scum, but he's the real scum. We later find out there were 10 juveniles in that  operation, eight of which were unaccompanied minors. What do you say?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: I see this every day, and I said from day one, when President Trump became president, that they're going to vilify the men and women of ICE. They'll vilify the men and women of Borbidgell. They did it during the last administration, except this time, the rhetoric's at an all-time high. Every day, I get up and I read the media posts at the White House, and 90% of the stories are just fake. They're lies.  So, and people say, well, the polls are kind of turning against Donald Trump a little bit on immigration. First of all, I don't believe it. If the polls turn it off, because all the fake news out there, they're lying about what President Trump is doing. They're lying about what the men and women of ICE are doing. And that kind of turns, you know, the tide against us a little bit. But that's why, you know, members of the administration are out there every day setting the facts straight.  The fact is, I read the paper the other day, the majority of people who are arrested are not criminals. Wrong. Look at the data. Go to ICE.gov and look at the data. But we've got some media saying, well, it's just a misdemeanor. It's not a felony. They're not really criminal. Oh, they're not convicted. They're just charged. Oh, they're not criminals. No. We're prioritizing public safety threats and national security threats, and that's a fact.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: But, Tom, it strikes me unbelievable that the Democrats are not on board. When you look at this raid, there were 10 juveniles that were illegally brought across the border. You and I covered this under the Biden administration. I was down in Texas. We encountered a 8-, 10-year-old, 12-year-olds coming across with just a name and an address and a phone number on their necks, the cartel ruthlessly sending them across. And yet now we know  that ten of them, eight of which were unaccompanied minors, working illegally in a marijuana farm, and your agents go in and rescue them, essentially, and yet there is violent resistance to that. Does that upset you?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: It certainly upsets me. And like I said, the work men and women of ICE are doing is incredible. Look, we're looking for over 300,000 missing children. We've already found 10,000. Have you heard that anywhere? No. The media is simply not covering it. And look, this should be a nonpartisan issue. Arresting  Public safety threats and national security threats, everybody be all the same page on that. Rescuing children, I mean, it should be a nonpartisan issue. Everybody should be in lockstep on that, but they're not. The media is lying. The Democrats are, they don't want President Trump to be successful. I got news for him. We are being successful. Every, every illegal alien public safety threat we arrest makes this country safer. Every national security threat we take off the street and deport makes us safer.  And we're rescuing thousands of children. The lives saved every day by ICE, the lives saved every day by Border Patrol, you know, are in the hundreds. So it's, the only thing I can think of, Griff, if they hate President Trump more than they love their community. They hate President Trump more than they want, you know, safe communities. There's just no other excuse why this is not, why this has become a partisan issue to take public safety threats off the street.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: And before I run out of time, Tom, I've got to get your reaction to this. Biden appointed federal judge out in Los Angeles apparently expected today to issue a temporary restraining order halting your lawful operations. She says. I think it's important for the court not to burden otherwise lawful law enforcement activities. Your reaction there.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Look, people need to understand, ICE officers and Border Patrol, they don't need probable cause to walk up to somebody, briefly detain them and question them. They just need, so to tally the circumstances, right? They just got through their observation, you know, get articulable facts based on their location, their occupation, their physical appearance, their actions, like a uniformed Border Patrol walks up to them at, for instance, a Home Depot.  And they got all these articulable facts, plus the person walks away or runs away. Agents are trained what they need to detain somebody temporarily and question them. It's not probable cause, it's reasonable suspicion. We're trained on that. Every agent, every six months, gets Fourth Amendment training over and over again. These officers are really good at what they do. And if the judge is making a decision,  that's against what these officers are trained, what the law is based upon, then they're going to shut down operation. I think that's your endgame. They want ICE to stop doing this, but if they base it on the rule of law, they're going to find out. Border Patrol and ICE are doing exactly what they're going to do in accordance with law.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: And you're not going to stop coming. Tom Homan, thank you for getting up with us this morning.  You got it. I'm Steve Doocy. I'm Brian Kilmeade. And I'm Ainsley Earhart. And click here to subscribe to the Fox News YouTube page to catch our hottest interviews and most compelling analysis.

summary.SPEAKER_00: Tom Homan, a former ICE acting director, defends ICE agents' actions, stating that they are enforcing the laws enacted by Congress. He condemns the violence from protesters, arguing that it is illegal and emboldened by negative rhetoric from some politicians and the media. Homan emphasises that ICE prioritises public safety threats and national security threats and highlights the agency's efforts to rescue children, including finding over 10,000 missing children. He criticises the media for not covering these successes and argues that immigration enforcement should be a non-partisan issue.
summary.SPEAKER_01: The host expresses concern about the violence at the ICE raid and the rhetoric that fuels it. They question why Democrats are not more supportive of ICE, especially when they rescue unaccompanied minors. The host also highlights the distortion of facts by the media and the potential impact of a Biden-appointed federal judge's ruling to curb federal immigration operations.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses a violent ICE raid at a marijuana farm in California and the broader implications for immigration enforcement. The raid escalated when protesters clashed with federal agents, leading to the use of tear gas and the alleged firing of a gun at the Feds. The speakers condemn the violence but criticise the rhetoric from some members of Congress and the media, which they argue emboldens protesters and distorts the truth about immigration enforcement. They also highlight the presence of unaccompanied minors working illegally on the farm and the broader challenges faced by ICE and Border Patrol.

video_title: Fetterman RIPS Mamdani's socialist agenda: 'Not helpful' for Democrats

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Our police force should not be assisting. ICE will create a network of city-owned grocery stores. It's like a public option for produce. I'll freeze the rent for millions of tenants, make buses fast and free, and deliver universal child care. And before you ask, I'll pay for it by taxing the rich.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04

So that, just for starters, on the big list for Zoran Mamdani, touching on some of his socialist policy proposals as he runs for mayor of New York City. My next guest, a Democrat, doesn't appear to be a very big fan. Democratic Senator John Fetterman out of Pennsylvania is back with me today. And sir, good morning to you. Thank you, Senator, for joining us.  for your time here today. I want to play a clip from this week, okay? Ken Martin is the head of the DNC. This is on PBS on Wednesday. Here is the question and the answer about Mamdani's record about Israel. Just watch here.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
