We win by bringing people into that coalition. And at the end of the day, for me, that's the type of party we're going to lead. We are a big tent party.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Well, that was kind of mushy, I think. Even in politics, it's kind of a mushy answer. He did not condemn the question as it was posed. What do you see as the problem with Mamdani as it may affect the Democratic Party?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Well, I mean, for me, clearly, the GOP are now going to use him as their tentpole of messaging for the new upcoming elections for that. So for me, I mean, now, he is a socialist, I mean, a proud socialist. I mean, he's not, I guess, a technical Democrat. I mean, I'm close friends with many very, very left  Democrats in the Senate. But again, we don't have those kinds of views as well. So we have different views. And whoever New York City chooses, that's really up to them. But I'm just saying I don't really agree with the vast majority of the things, parts of his platform.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: OK, so there were many Democrats who did not immediately come out and congratulate him after he won that Democratic primary last month. But we can put the endorsements that have come on for Mamdani, and I can tell you after living here in New York, you just get the sense, Senator, over the last couple of weeks  that like the grease on that wheel is turning, you know, very slowly, but it is turning. And my sense is by the time we roll into November, you're going to have a lot of Democrats in your party who do endorse him. Is that a problem?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Well, for me, again, I don't have a dog in that fight. Obviously, I don't live in New York City. All I'm saying, though, it's very clear that the GOP are going to use him as their tent pole on their messaging. And there was just a recent poll just emerged from a Democratic  super PAC. And now we still have our own issues with our image and some of the things that our party views ourselves. And I don't think that's helpful at this point to have that be someone that's been identified as one of the emerging faces of our party.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: He's taking some positions on ICE, many Democrats have. They're not happy with him watching in places like California that we talked about about 30 minutes ago. You said this, though, on X, when you sent out, ICE performs an important job for our country. Any calls to abolish ICE are 100 inappropriate, 100% inappropriate and outrageous. You want to go ahead and just expand on that as to where that might go?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01

And I don't wanna go after hard working workers in a lot of our different industries now. President Trump is not even talking about developing some kind of a program to allow that things. I'm saying we should round up and deport all the criminals.  Absolutely. I support that. You know, I'm a Democrat. I also want to secure our border. And then I think it's, there are two things that must be true, a secure border. And now let's, we have to deport all of the criminals. And I don't believe, and I, we should be going after otherwise law abiding, hardworking migrants that are very important part of our economy.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Have you seen the video of California that's on screen now? So that video clearly shows, it was in Texas a few days ago, it's now in California. What do you think about those who are trying to obstruct ICE and the operations now?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Again, of course, I'm not a part of that, and I would never support if anyone is trying to block things like that. And that's actually dangerous for everybody involved on those things. And again, for me, as a Democrat pro-immigration, it's like, absolutely, we should just be  focusing on rounding up all the criminals and deport them. And we need to make sure our border is secure. And I do believe, and I've consistently believed that we should also protect the DREAMers and workers that are in very important parts.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: I understand your position. Just one last question on that. How nasty do you think this could get?  Now that in the big beautiful bill, you're going from 5000 ice agents to 15,000 and those on the far left are going to be ready for those raids even more so than they have been already.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: All I'm saying is, I mean, I don't really know that, but for me, my views on immigration really haven't changed. But now I don't think our party did a great job on the border before. And then I think making it more secure and deport all the criminals and to find the appropriate balance between acknowledging the important contributions that our migrant workers contribute. And now I think that's what's entirely appropriate. And now I'd like to remind everybody,  Calling for to abolish ice is is insane and politically that's just that's ridiculous. You know, ice is necessary and as long as they continue to round up all of the criminals. I mean, they're doing an important job if that's what they're doing.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Got it. Senator, thank you for coming back. John Fennerman, the Democrat from Pennsylvania. An independent voice, we will say. Have a good weekend, Sir. Thank you.  Thank you. I'm Steve Doocy. I'm Brian Kilmeade.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: And I'm Ainsley Earhart. And click here to subscribe to the Fox News YouTube page to catch our hottest interviews and most compelling analysis.

summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the political views of Zoran Mamdani, a socialist candidate running for mayor of New York City, and their potential impact on the Democratic Party. Senator John Fetterman, a Democrat, expresses his disagreements with Mamdani's platform and emphasises the need for the Democratic Party to strike a balance.

video_title: 'A DARK TIME': Trump to meet Texas flood rescue team, inspect damage

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Joining us now is Texas Lieutenant Governor Dan Patrick, and I'm sure this visit means a lot for all sorts of reasons to lots of people. I mean, there's a lot that you guys are all dealing with there. What is the most important thing for you, if you had to pick two or three, the top things that you want the president to see, know, or that you're going to ask him for?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: A lot of important things. And the president will bring everything we need, as he always does, to Texas and other states, red or blue, because he cares about people in stress. He cares about our citizens and their safety. And I know I talked to him, I guess it was two days ago, and his heart's breaking, like everyone else's, for these children and all the adults who are lost.  You know, the biggest thing we need, Dana and Bill, is I say prayer, but I mean that in a very strong way, not just thoughts and prayers. You know, John 11, 26 says, faith in eternal life brings comfort to many others. And I've been through this now for... I'm sorry, can you hear me fine?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: I can hear you, yes.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Okay, I'm sorry, I heard your director of my ear. John 1126 says, faith in eternal life brings comfort to believers. And Dana, for my 10 years as Lieutenant Governor, we've seen a lot of tragedies, hurricanes and tornadoes and floods and domestic shootings. And every time when I'm around people who have suffered great loss, tragic loss, it's always the rock of their faith that they stand on.  And the President honored me by appointing me Chair of the Commission on Religious Liberty to look at religious rights in this country. It always fascinates me in times like this, no one objects to us praying in the public square. No one objects to people and their outpouring of prayer.  I've gotten to meet many of these families. I gave them my cell number, called me about their children or the adults that they've lost. In fact, I'm going to a funeral on Monday. And what I see is, in every situation, Dana and Bill, every situation of tragedy, people stand on their faith.  We're here for a short time. They'll be rejoined in heaven with their loved ones they've lost, and it's painful now. But it's faith that gets us through first and foremost, like it did for the president a year ago, Sunday when he was shot. It is faith that America stands on. It is God that America looks to when we're in trouble. We'll get the money from the federal government. We'll supply the money from the state. We'll install sirens. We'll improve our warning systems. We'll take care of all of those issues.  But it's faith that will get us through this. And I'm I'm always inspired by the strength of the people I know.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Here's President Trump to NBC about the alarm system that you mentioned.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Yes.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: I'm sorry, I thought he said it. It'd be easy to blame them. I wouldn't blame them. I think from the standpoint of the future, you have to have some kind of an alarm and lighting system where alarms would go up if they see any large amounts of water or whatever it is. You know, two days, or the weekend before the flooding, they passed an inspection at the camp. Yes. And I just wonder what you think about that. I mean, obviously I hear you on the faith point.  Then there's the practicalities of what we can do here on Earth to make sure that these campers or others are alerted. And I strongly believe that we've spent way too much money dealing with fantasies about dealing with climate change and not enough on dealing with increased severe weather.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: that will  We had a flood very close to this in 1932, but it was during the day, so there weren't campers bleeding along the banks of the river. And so we're going to fix all of those issues. We're going to clean up the debris. We'll restore people. But right now, they're standing on the rock of their faith. And I get a text every hour or so from another family that says, Dan, my loved one has been found. We are getting closure.  And they're getting through this. These are brave people. And those responders out there, those searchers walking through the water, the snakes, all the debris under it, they're not standing on the rocks of the banks of the river. They're standing on the rocks of the bank of their fate. And that's what gets America through every time we find darkness in our lives.  And it's a dark time right now in Texas, but we're looking forward, we're looking upward, and we are going to move forward with the president's help and with the state of Texas and the people at the local level and all the people around the world who have sent money in by the truckloads to help restore these lives. I've just never seen such an outpouring of strength as I've seen during this time. It's just remarkable.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: All right, thank you so much. Lieutenant Governor Dan Patrick, as the president gets ready to leave to join you in Texas.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Thank you.

summary.SPEAKER_00: Lieutenant Governor Dan Patrick emphasises the significance of faith in helping people cope with the tragedy. He highlights the outpouring of prayer and support from the community and notes that faith is a common source of comfort for victims and their families in times of crisis. Patrick also mentions the need for practical measures like improving warning systems and infrastructure but underscores that faith is the foundation upon which people rebuild their lives.
summary.SPEAKER_02: The interviewer (SPEAKER_02) acknowledges the importance of faith but also shifts the focus to practical discussions. They inquire about the alarm system at the site of the tragedy and suggest that more needs to be done to prevent similar incidents in the future. The interviewer also touches upon the topic of climate change and its impact on severe weather events but does not delve deeply into this aspect.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the aftermath of a tragedy in Texas, likely a flooding event. The focus is on the importance of faith in providing comfort to the victims and their families during this difficult time. While practical measures such as improving warning systems and infrastructure are acknowledged, faith is emphasised as the primary source of strength and resilience.

video_title: ‘No place in public life’: Ex-Dem councilman blasts Mamdani

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: In New York City, mayoral candidate Zoran Mamdani still won't condemn the anti-Semitic slogan, Globalize the Intifada. But the DNC chairman doesn't seem to think there's anything wrong with that.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: There's no candidate in this party that I agree 100% of the time with, to be honest with you. There's things that I don't agree with Mamdani that he said. We are a big tent party. Yes, it leads to dissent and debate, and there's differences of opinions on a whole host of issues.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Former New York City Councilman and former vice chair of the state Democratic Party Rory Lansman joins me now to react. Rory, how do you respond to what you just heard the DNC chair say right there?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Well, good morning. Unfortunately, there's been an explosion of anti-Semitism in this country since October 7th on college campuses, in K through 12 schools, in the workplace, especially here in New York City. And the formula is simple. You demonize the state of Israel, and then you demonize the Jewish people who support Israel, which is most Jewish people. And so a public official like Zoran Mamdani,  who, the day after the October 7th attacks, put out a statement attacking Israel, who refuses to recognize the right of Israel to exist as a Jewish state, who supports the boycott, divestment, sanction movement against Israel, who refuses to condemn a phrase like globalize the Intifada. He is directly contributing to the anti-Semitism that we're experiencing here in New York, and he has no place in public life, and certainly not in the Democratic Party, in my view.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: And there are a number of Jewish Democrats who agree with that, prominent ones. These are House Democrats that are Jewish, sounding the alarm on Mamdani. Congresswoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz saying, to not be willing to condemn the term globalize the intifada, it just demonstrates his callous disregard for anti-Semitism, terrorist activity. It's really terribly disturbing and potentially dangerous.  Congressman Josh Gottheimer across the river there in Jersey says, as Democrats, there should be no room in our party for anti-Semitism or hate speech. And Congressman Greg Landsman writing, it's a huge problem. It's definitely something that we're worried about. So take that and contrast that with a movement literally called Jews for Zoran. I hate to abuse this phrase. It's often abused, but it is appropriate here. Isn't that like chickens for KFC?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: It's really hard to explain and hard to understand. It's important for people who are not Jewish, people who are not in New York City, to understand that that represents a small minority of the Jewish community, and they're entitled to their views. It's inexplicable to me how a Jew  could not believe that Jews have the right to self-determination in their historic homeland, and that Jews who believe in that should not be demonized on a college campus or in the workplace. But I think that the majority of Jews expect both parties and all of our public officials, regardless of the party that they're in, to respect the basic  human rights and civil rights of Jewish people, and that includes the right to have anti-Semitism taken seriously, to not suffer demonization because of our support for the Jewish state, and I would call on all Democrats to respect  the needs and safety of the Jewish community at the same level that we respect the safety and the needs of every community.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Just quickly, before we let you go, Will Mamdani's win in the primary and potential win in November deepened the turmoil within the Democratic Party so much that nationally, this is your party, could you end up losing the midterms because of this, in the midterms that historically the party out of power, which in this case is the Democrats, are supposed to win?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: I can assure you of one thing. I represent a district in Queens, which is a little more suburban, and one thing that middle-of-the-road voters are not looking for is more socialism, more anti-Semitism coming out of the Democratic Party. It's going to be fascinating to watch.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Rory Lansman, thanks for being here, being a voice on this, even though it's tough in your party right now to be a voice, but you're here for your people, and I think that's what's most important, because it's a human rights issue. Thanks for having me.  I'm Steve Doocy. I'm Brian Kilmeade. And I'm Ainsley Earhardt. And click here to subscribe to the Fox News YouTube page to catch our hottest interviews and most compelling analysis.

summary.SPEAKER_00: Defends the Democratic Party as a "big tent" that allows for dissent. Acknowledges disagreements with Mamdani but does not explicitly condemn his stance on the slogan.
summary.SPEAKER_01: Agrees that Mamdani's statements and support for anti-Israel policies contribute to anti-Semitism. Emphasises the need for public officials to recognise Israel's right to exist and condemn hate speech. Notes that the support for Mamdani represents a small minority of the Jewish community. Warns that middle-of-the-road voters are concerned about socialism and anti-Semitism coming from the Democratic Party.
summary.SPEAKER_02: Criticises Mamdani and the DNC chairman for not condemning the slogan. Highlights the rise in anti-Semitism and argues Mamdani has no place in the Democratic Party. Points out the contradiction between Mamdani's support and the views of prominent Jewish Democrats, as well as the existence of "Jews for Zoran". Suggests Mamdani's win could deepen turmoil within the Democratic Party and potentially impact the midterms.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the controversy surrounding New York City mayoral candidate Zoran Mamdani, his refusal to condemn the anti-Semitic slogan "Globalize the Intifada", and its implications for the Democratic Party.

video_title: Trump blocks $40B in taxpayer-funded programs from illegal immigrants

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: What really enrages me is that Jackie was reporting with CBP Commissioner Rodney Scott saying that ten of those arrested were juveniles, all illegal aliens, eight of which were unaccompanied minors. So the full context here, for four years I stood, it broke our hearts. The agents, the media, everyone that encountered  7, 8, 10-year-olds being sent across the border with a sign around their neck with a phone number and someone to contact, not knowing if those were the real parents, not knowing if it was part of a cartel human smuggling operation, which was vast.  And now you're seeing in this specific raid, which was not, as Senator Padilla says, an unchecked power grab. It was a lawful warrant that was being carried out to stop what was happening, illegal aliens employed at this marijuana farm. But now you see that this was actually a rescue. These children were rescued from whatever situation they were in.  And yet the fact that Democrats, like Gavin Newsom, is trying to change the narrative by saying something about children fleeing and running, being torn from their mother, nothing could be further from the truth when you look at the actual facts.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: And Griff, to your point, I mean, there's a child labor investigation, so God only knows what these children have been through, yet we're the Democrats on that. Instead, what they are doing is being the party of lawlessness, protecting criminals, and that's what they're doing. Not only did Democrats import  millions of illegal aliens, many terrorists, many gang members as well, like we saw with Trinidad and Tobago in Colorado taking over apartment complexes. So not only did they import a lot of these people, but now they're trying to prevent the deportation  of gangbangers, of people who participate in potential child labor, which is this investigation. So that's what the Democrat Party is about. And then to add fuel onto the fire, you've got Democrats like Tim Walz out there calling ICE the Gestapo. You've got Congresswoman Jayapal saying ICE is a terrorist force. You've got a vice mayor of California literally calling on gangs like Florence and the 18th Street Gang to take back their turf.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: And you wonder why people believe that Democrats are genuinely, it's part of their policy to be in favor of open borders and illegal immigration, including child labor and unaccompanied minors coming over and threatening their lives coming into the country. Well, one of the big draws has always been, in addition to the open borders, our generous welfare system.  The Trump administration is now cracking down on taxpayer-funded benefits going to illegal aliens, including at HHS, new restrictions from 13 additional public programs, including Head Start, health workforce scholarships and loans, mental health and substance abuse support, family planning, and more.  Over at the Education Department, they are ending free tuition at post-secondary, career, and technical education programs. This is free tuition that is often not extended to actual U.S. citizens who pay taxes, by the way. At the Department of Agriculture, they are now restricting illegal aliens from getting federally funded food assistance programs.  At the Department of Labor, they're barring access to federal workforce development programs and grants. DOJ closing longstanding loopholes that have allowed illegal aliens to access taxpayer-benefited funds. And, you know, maybe the biggest thing and perhaps the most important thing that has been a problem for years are states that give in-state tuition to illegal aliens in their country  The tuition, not only does that give tuition breaks to those as opposed to actual American citizens who maybe live out of state, but it also means that that illegal takes up a spot that an American student who might be poor in Boston would like to get a shot at.  because of the Democrat policies have turned entirely towards benefiting illegals over Americans. Free education, free health care.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: I mean, we know the pull and push factors of the Biden crisis in unprecedented numbers coming. What was pulling them is free stuff. It's a major driver, was a major driver. So they are simply trying to cut off the incentive that would encourage people to make the dangerous trek to come illegally. By the way, when you read that, Charlie, like,  Other than maybe the Department of Transportation, I think you hit every department in the federal government. And so this clearly was not only a case of a few special incentives that the Biden administration was giving them, it was across the board.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Well, Joe Biden, it was like the Oprah with illegal aliens. You get this free thing, you get this free thing, you get this free thing. And we've also seen in just cities and towns about how mass migration can bankrupt  and can cause so many problems. We've seen this in Springfield, Ohio, with all these Haitian migrants going to the city, draining city resources. We've also seen it here in New York City. You've got a massive budget, a massive city, and you had Eric Adams out there saying, look, we're going to basically go broke.  this influx of migrants they're, you know, taking our resources and we just can't afford it. So, you know, there's so many problems with this. And also, by the way, Charlie, this was litigated during the last election and Americans said, we don't want our resources going to people who shouldn't be here in the first.

summary.SPEAKER_00: Speaker_00 strongly criticises Democrats for opposing the raid and for being the party of lawlessness. They argue that Democrats support illegal immigration, including child labour, and protect criminals. Speaker_00 also criticises the Biden administration for providing taxpayer-funded benefits to illegal aliens, arguing it is unfair to American citizens and drains resources. They mention specific cities and states overwhelmed by mass migration and its financial consequences.
summary.SPEAKER_01: Speaker_01 draws attention to the child labour investigation at the marijuana farm and suggests that Democrats are prioritising illegal aliens over American citizens. They criticise Democrats for their stance on ICE and their alleged support for gang activity. Speaker_01 implies that open borders and generous welfare systems attract illegal immigration and argues that the Trump administration is cracking down on these benefits.
summary.SPEAKER_02: Speaker_02 supports the raid, emphasising it was a rescue operation for the exploited children. They argue that the full context of the situation, including the previous issues with unaccompanied minors being smuggled across the border, is being ignored by Democrats. Speaker_02 criticises Democrats for trying to change the narrative and highlights the need to address the pull factors of illegal immigration, such as perceived free benefits.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses a recent raid on a marijuana farm where 10 arrested were juveniles, all illegal aliens, 8 of which were unaccompanied minors. The speakers criticise Democrats for portraying the raid negatively, arguing it was a rescue operation. They further argue that Democrats support open borders, illegal immigration, and criminal activity, and criticise the Biden administration for providing taxpayer-funded benefits to illegal aliens. The speakers emphasise the need to cut off incentives for illegal immigration and highlight the financial burden it places on cities and states.

video_title: NEW: ICE raid uncovers unaccompanied migrant kids on cannabis farm

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: All right, so David Webb, we were just educated on the facts by William. And the additional facts we saw unfold before our very eyes, which was protesters shooting and attacking federal law enforcement agents.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Well, one, they're not protesters. They're highly organized activists that, whether they're notified by local organizations, whether it's by app or social media, these are set up like a quick response force in different areas. You saw this in MacArthur Park with that. You see this going on. And now you  You have the complicity and, in fact, the tacit approval of Democrat politicians, whether it's a congressman, the Oxnard mayor, or others who show up to be a part of this, because this is now the policy of the Democrat Party, which, by the way, they claim to be in favor of protecting children. They're the same people who believe in mutilating children biologically, chemically, and otherwise. But yet, and this is something that really irritates, frankly, it angers me.  I've been working with the Young Marines Youth Organization for about 30 years now. We have the number one drug demand reduction program in the nation, a model for kids 8 to 18 to live a healthy, drug-free lifestyle.  And when you sit and you look at this and the work we do as an organization and that we do at the National Foundation level, this is what we're against, putting children in a dangerous environment where drugs affect them. It affects their development. It affects their growth. It opens that gateway to other things, not just marijuana. So this is beyond the pale.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: And Tommy, I was struck by the comments there by protesters. So we're just out here to protect our people. Well, who's protecting the American citizens from those that have been convicted and charged with terrible crimes that we are trying to get out of this country? And the concept of fascism rearing its ugly head is so shocking when this is just enforcement of federal laws.  light enforcement, per William, right? It was stronger under Obama. But I'm not quite sure why the protection isn't for those innocent victims in these communities.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: And not even just the innocent victims in the communities who are legal immigrants or American citizens. Let's just talk about, to your point, David, the children who are apparently being exploited working on a weed farm.  Were these children trafficked into this country by coyotes and smugglers? Were these some of the 300,000 that are unaccounted for that the Trump administration, by the way, is working hard to identify and to bring home? We don't know. We need to know.  But when you talk about protecting people, how about the people who are being exploited working for surf class labor wages on these marijuana farms and elsewhere? You're protecting these corporations who are hiring illegal alien labor and also suppressing the wages of Americans and legal immigrants. But beyond that, this is where the Democrat Party is now.  They are for those who break the law, not for those who enforce it. The men and women who are doing their job. Tom Homan has said it so many times, but it's worth repeating. Congress makes these laws. These men and women are out simply enforcing them and doing their job. And these are the ones that you're targeting. These are the ones you're demonizing, calling the Gestapo, the secret police. They will not stop until we have an ICE or federal agent who is seriously injured or murdered. I hope that they would stop then, but I'm not even sure that that's enough.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Jillian this is taking place just north of where you live in LA describe the landscape for us and and what the community Feels about this other than what we saw here to be honest.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: I no longer live in California for reasons like this But with that said I have obviously a lot of friends and family left in California and I came home last night to a series of text messages with a post from Gavin Newsom positioning this as  as though these innocent protesters were tear gassed and attacked for no reason on a vegetable farm. No mention of the fact that it was marijuana. Kids were ripped away from their parents. No mention of the fact that there were undocumented, unaccompanied minors there who  Question were they trafficked? I was asking the same exact question that Tommy was and it's the way they're Utilizing this to spin it as a tool in the next election and they're completely denying the facts of what's going on here It's it's alarming to say the least and can I ask quick follow-up?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: So where those texts that you were getting from the from your friends and family in California saying this is absurd You believe what a monster Trump and ice.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Can you believe it?  They were agreeing with it.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: They bought it. Oh, gosh.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: So when they saw the post from Newsom, and they're seeing children running through tear gas on a vegetable farm. And this guy's like, did you lose your mom? And of course, it turns out that these people were attacking federal agents. So they retaliated accordingly. And the children there were undocumented and unaccompanied working at a weed farm.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: But none of those facts were put forward by the left. Quite the opposite. Right. And these are allegations that they were actually employed there. The reality is, it's Newsom's California any way you look at it. Because it's the way that he spins it, but it's also the reality under which he governs.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Look, it's Newsom's legacy media, too. I mean, they're complicit in this. Oh, completely. We did a deeper dive on this last hour, so I won't reiterate everything that we looked at. But I will just say this one fine point.  When you have an echo chamber across legacy networks, not just liberal on cable, but the ones that don't spell anything, the alphabet soup networks, ABC, CBS, NBC, when you have them framing the nomenclature of what we're looking at, they don't call it a riot. They don't call it attacks on feds. They call it things like inaction. What the heck is that? Inaction?  No, it is assault. And you know what the federal government says about it? Interfering with law enforcement officers is illegal and can result in various charges ranging from misdemeanors to felonies, depending on the nature and the severity of the interference. It is not just about physical obstruction. Providing false information or refusing to cooperate with authorities can also be considered obstruction. I think it's pretty clear. So, you know, we will see the switch flip.  But Senator Tim Scott told me last hour his concern is that what happens when some of our guys are hurt, the feds? Do they fight back? And what I pray for is that they continue the restraint that they've used so far and that we clamp down using the real lawfare against the real criminals and go after them during and after the fact. If you're helping people stop the feds, you're going down legally too.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: I know we've got to run, but we cannot ignore what has also recently happened. Alvarado, Texas, an organized ambush. They didn't mostly peacefully shoot an agent in the neck.  Think about this, they are already at that point. That agent is not dead by the grace of God. Or that would be the first death.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Tom Holman's right, there will be this type of outcome.

summary.SPEAKER_00: Describes the activists as highly organised and criticises Democrat politicians for their tacit approval. Expresses anger about the situation, drawing from their experience with a youth organisation. Links the issue to broader concerns about child protection and drug abuse.
summary.SPEAKER_01: Condemns the activists' violence and criticises Democrat politicians for supporting them. Questions the protection of American citizens and highlights the enforcement of federal laws. Expresses concern about the media's biased portrayal of the incident.
summary.SPEAKER_02: Emphasises the potential exploitation of children on the marijuana farm and suggests they might have been trafficked. Criticises the Democrat Party for allegedly supporting lawbreakers and suppressing wages. Highlights the dangers faced by federal agents and warns of escalating violence.
summary.SPEAKER_04: Notes that the incident occurred near LA and expresses dismay at how Governor Newsom spun the narrative. Reports receiving texts from friends and family in California who agreed with Newsom's distorted version of events, highlighting the media's influence.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses a violent incident involving activists attacking federal law enforcement agents at a suspected marijuana farm. The speakers criticise the activists, Democrat politicians, and the media for their perceived complicity, double standards, and misrepresentation of the facts. They highlight concerns about child exploitation, illegal immigration, and the erosion of law and order.

video_title: Trump, first lady tour flood-ravaged Texas

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: We've got President Trump on the ground there. He's touring some of the damage. Let's see if we can listen in a little bit here.

lines.speaker: Unidentified SPEAKER
lines.text: Trump gets briefed on a devastation along the river.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: I can't really hear it too well, so it looks like he's looking at a map that's been set up there in front of that fire truck and in front of some of that debris. I imagine that's probably the river valley, and they're describing just how widespread this devastation was. As we saw all along the Guadalupe River, the flood stage go from what's normally about five feet of the depth of the river to 26 feet in the course of an hour, just sweeping everything away.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: We can't help but just feel absolute heartbreak and sadness when you see this image of this, the buildup, the wall of debris, John, that gathered as these floodwaters rushed through and sadly took the lives of so many. And you see the president, the first lady, the governor of Texas, Greg Abbott, on the ground there, obviously getting an update, going over the map and the region, and the president getting a look at all this with his own eyes.  and meeting with the first responders and meeting with local officials just to understand just how absolutely awful this was, John.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Yeah, and that's the, uh, I believe we've seen him before. That's the, uh, Kerr County, uh, manager. Uh, and, uh, he's describing the situation that we've seen him in a number of the briefings here. It goes over shakes the hand of Greg Abbott. Um, there's the president meeting, uh, another looks like police official there. Uh, we don't have a list of all of the folks that he's meeting with here, but you know,  You have to hand it to the president for going down there while the situation is still pretty tenuous for a lot of folks in that area because they're looking for comfort here. They're looking to know that the federal government, that the president of the United States has got their backs and that's what this president is doing right now along with the first lady.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: is that our understanding on the far right side of the screen there in the white shirt, that's Nim Kidd. He's the head of emergency management. He is the chief of emergency management there. As you see the Kerrville Fire Department truck positioned and  John, you know, you sort of just take in this image and a community that I'm sure is so glad to have their president on the ground and have leadership there ahead of this roundtable they're going to have where he'll get more of an update and really open up to discussion about how they're going to move forward here as they know that search and rescue efforts are still underway at this hour, John.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: And you've got quite a scene of debris there. You've got all of those trees piled on top of each other. And then there's some sort of structure. I don't know if that's a home or some kind of a building piled on top of it. And it shows you just how deep the water was. I was in the car with my son driving him to his basketball camp the other day. And he said, how high did the water go, dad? And I said, well, imagine  Our house, which is a two-story house, having no water around it, then all of a sudden it's up to the roof in water. That's how deep it got, and that happened in an hour. He just couldn't believe that something like that could happen. So you can imagine all of these young kids who are particularly at this Camp Mystic.  seven, eight years old, never dealt with anything like this. They're at camp to embrace each other, to spend some time in fellowship with their friends and with God as well. And then all of a sudden this torrent rages through the camp, just stealing everything, including their lives from them. I mean, I can't imagine the horror that those poor kids went through.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: You truly cannot and we pray for all on the ground affected by this. All the families of the victims and those innocent little lives lost. Those girls from the camp and we coming up and in just a bit we're going to have some guests of Pastor Joe Taylor and Hannah Taylor of Southern Oaks Church. They're part of the community coming together to gather supplies, gather monetary donations, do anything they can to help out the area.  So many have come together to distribute supplies for people, in some cases families, who lost everything. We know there are folks who lost their homes, their RVs, their businesses were washed away.  We're going to hear from some of those voices who are coming together to try to help those around them. And, you know, we had Todd Graves on, founder of Raising Cane's out of Louisiana, who's got, you know, so many locations and employees in the state of Texas who donated a million dollars to the relief funds there. People are trying to do absolutely anything they can and any little bit helps. Of course, the Red Cross stepping in, they're getting a lot of donations as well to try to help folks on the ground, John.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: And, of course, we here at Fox as well have got a donation drive going for people who live in the Hill Country of Texas as well. We'll put that up on the screen for you in just a little while. But in addition to the rescue, the recovery, the rebuilding efforts, over the next weeks and months, there's going to be a lot of lessons learned discussions as well, such as why weren't people told to go to higher ground? Why weren't the warnings more serious heading into this before everybody went to bed? We've heard the Lieutenant Governor Dan Patrick say that  He and the governor, Greg Abbott, want to put in a network of flood sirens through the Guadalupe River Valley, much the same as the tornado sirens that we see so prevalent across the Midwest that are very, very effective in telling people, hey, it's time to get out of harm's way, go to your storm cellar or go to your tornado shelter, whatever you've got on your property. But, you know, had some sort of siren system been in place and sounded, waking people up, maybe, you know, more folks could have got to higher ground.  You know, nobody's assessing blame at this point, as Dan Patrick said, repeatedly in our program earlier this week, but there will be, I think, a lot of discussions about lessons learned and how to avoid something like this in the future. Oh, and as we pull back wider, so that is debris on top of a truck that's flipped on its side and then some sort of structure on top of that. So you can just imagine the power of these floodwaters. You know, we, we, we hear about  the wind damage from tornadoes and yes that you know that can be horrible. We hear about earthquake damage but but a flood is a very unique type of natural disaster that just sweeps everything in its path out of the way I think about the power of those just rushing floodwaters John.

lines.speaker: Unidentified SPEAKER
lines.text: you

summary.SPEAKER_00: SPEAKER_00 expresses empathy and sadness for the victims and their families. They emphasise the significance of President Trump's visit and the role of leadership in addressing the crisis. SPEAKER_00 also highlights the ongoing search and rescue efforts, the community's resilience, and the various relief efforts underway, including donations from organisations and individuals.
summary.SPEAKER_01: SPEAKER_01 provides a factual account of President Trump's tour of the flood-damaged area. They describe the extent of the devastation caused by the rapid rise in floodwaters, highlighting the destruction of property and the loss of life. SPEAKER_01 also notes the President's meetings with local officials, first responders, and the Kerr County manager, emphasising the importance of his presence for providing comfort and assurance to the affected community.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation covers President Trump's visit to a flood-ravaged area in Texas, likely along the Guadalupe River. The speakers describe the devastating impact of the floods, which rose 21 feet in an hour, causing widespread destruction, loss of life, and significant damage to infrastructure and property. The focus is on the immediate response efforts, the President's meeting with local officials and first responders, and the community's need for support and recovery.

video_title: ‘SERIOUS CHARGES’ incoming after Camarillo ICE raid

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: All right, let's bring in the U.S. Attorney for the Central District of California, Bill Asili. Bill, thank you so much for being with us. Really appreciate your time. I know that we got you on here at the last moment. I wanted to get your thoughts on what William LaJunesse was talking about here, that we saw workplace enforcement under the Obama administration. We saw it under the Biden administration. We saw it under Bush. We saw it under Clinton. Yet under Trump, it's taking on a whole different tone.  What are your thoughts on that?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Yeah, because the left here, the political leadership, they have declared open war on our federal agents. They do not want us to... We seem to have lost him there for a second.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: We'll give him a moment to see if he comes back. Yep, and it looks like he's back again. Go ahead, Bill. We lost you for a second there.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Okay.  Sorry about that. Yeah, so the California leaders here and the politicians, they do not want us to enforce immigration laws. They've had open borders for the last few years. They've imported millions of people. And the president said, we are going to enforce immigration law. They are doing everything they can to encourage the public to openly, and yes, in some cases violently, resist our agents. And this is the reason the president sent the military.  be very clear about that. The military is here to protect our agents and our property so we can continue these operations. And we will not stop. We've arrested dozens of people already for assaulting. We're going to do more. And if we get our hands on the guy who fired that gun, he can expect to face some really serious charges here in the federal government.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Yeah, I wanted to ask you about that because we're seeing it in video up on our screen beside you. We've got him in a highlighted circle. But we also saw people throwing rocks, trying to smash out the windows of vehicles in which federal agents were riding. Do you have any leads yet on who this fellow with the gun was?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: We put out information about him. We're asking for the public's help. We currently do not know who he is, but we will find him. We've found lots of people already on video capture doing violent acts. We will find this guy, rest assured. We have the resources to do it. But I want to be clear, these tactics are escalating. You saw what happened in Texas, where they actually shot officers. Now you have rioters showing up prepared to shoot our agents. This is escalating, and it's not going to end well.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: So there's been a bit of a dust up here between Governor Gavin Newsom and the CBP Commissioner Rodney Scott on X. After Newsom tweeted this, he said, kids running from tear gas, crying on the phone because their mother was just taken from the fields. Trump calls me new scum, but he's the real scum. Rodney Scott's response to that was, here's some breaking news. 10 juveniles were found at this marijuana facility, all illegal aliens, eight of them unaccompanied. We now found that number is nine.  It's now under investigation for child labor violations. This is Newsom's California. Of course, big story during the Biden administration was that they lost track of some 320,000 unaccompanied minors in the millions that came across the border. It was feared that a lot of those unaccompanied minors might be vulnerable to child exploitation. Do we believe that that's what happened here?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: That we highly suspect that was happening there. It's an active, ongoing investigation. We did apprehend, we did locate some juveniles who were present at the facility. And just on the governor, he's extremely an unserious person. He has no idea what's going on at these locations. He doesn't know the facts.  He instantly just puts out these tweets with no information to create hysteria and to create drama against our agents. He does not care about the welfare of the American people. He does not care about people being exploited. He cares about illegal immigrants. That's what we are. We have politicians who care more about illegal immigrants than the people of this country.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: So there's a big federal case in court there in California that apparently the judge is going to make a ruling on today that could really dramatically affect how federal agents are able to carry out their operations. Here's what Tom Homan said about that pending ruling today. Listen here.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: If the judge is making a decision that's against what these officers are trained, what the law is based upon, then they're going to shut down operation. I think that's your endgame. They want ICE to stop doing this. But if they base it on the rule of law, they're going to find out Border Patrol and ICE is doing exactly what they're going to do in accordance with law.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: So there's all of this protest, all of these lawsuits filed against what ICE and what the Border Patrol are doing. But as Tom Homan points out, as Rodney Scott points out, as many federal officials have pointed out, they're just enforcing the laws that were passed in the building behind me here in Congress.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: That's exactly what we're doing in this operation yesterday. We had a warrant signed by a federal judge. They keep talking about warrants. Okay, we had a warrant yesterday and that wasn't good enough. They still sent out the rioters to attack the agents and they're still complaining about it. So just to be clear, they do not want us to enforce the law.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: All right. Bill O'Saley, the U.S. Attorney for the Central District of California, thanks so much for joining us. I assume that we're going to spend a lot of time together in the next four years.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Thank you again. Thank you for having me.

summary.SPEAKER_02: The moderator initiates the discussion by comparing workplace enforcement across different administrations. They highlight the current violent resistance against federal agents in California, the arrest of individuals for assault, and the ongoing investigation into a marijuana facility where unaccompanied juvenile illegal aliens were found, suggesting potential child labour violations. The moderator also brings up the political standoff between Governor Newsom and the CBP Commissioner, and the significance of a pending court ruling on federal operations.
summary.SPEAKER_03: The U.S. Attorney for the Central District of California, Bill Asili, asserts that California leaders oppose immigration law enforcement and have created an environment encouraging violent resistance against federal agents. He mentions the deployment of the military to protect agents, highlights arrests made for assault, and emphasises the seriousness of charges for those involved in violence. Asili criticises Governor Newsom for spreading misinformation and being unserious about the situation. He also underscores the suspicion of child exploitation at the marijuana facility and emphasises that federal agents are merely enforcing laws passed by Congress.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the escalating tensions between federal immigration enforcement agencies and California state leadership over immigration laws. The U.S. Attorney emphasises the administration's commitment to enforcing immigration laws, which they face resistance to from local politicians and the public. There are reports of violence against federal agents, child labour violations at illegal immigration sites, and a pending court ruling that could impact federal operations.

video_title: Trump admin SUED: ACLU claims ICE only arrests people based on this

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Welcome back. Let's go back live to the U.S. District Courthouse in Los Angeles, where the battle over President Trump's crackdown on illegal immigrants is taking place. Let's get right to Fox correspondent Bill Mulusian with the update on the hearings. Bill.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Yeah, well, good afternoon to you. This is a big hearing, and it just kicked off a few moments ago here in this federal courthouse behind us. We can tell you there's a totally packed courtroom in there, more than 100 people. There's also an overflow room. The judge started the hearing by talking to the people in the overflow room, saying, I'm not used to having this many people. So there's a lot of eyeballs on this case, and here's why. It has huge implications for ICE enforcement and Border Patrol enforcement of immigration law here in Los Angeles. What's happening is,  The Trump administration is being sued by the ACLU and a handful of plaintiffs who say that some of the arrests they have been making here in Los Angeles, particularly those mass arrests we're seeing at Home Depots and car washes and farms, they allege those arrests are based off only skin color and racial identity. And that is the only basis for which the federal government is arresting people, essentially only arresting people who have brown skin and are speaking Spanish.  The DOJ and the Trump administration have countered, saying that is not the case. Their arrests have followed the law. And they use a bunch of different tactics, a bunch of totality of circumstances when making arrests. That includes location, intelligence, surveillance, and a variety of other factors.  The plaintiffs in this case are asking the judge, who is a Biden appointee, to block the Trump administration from carrying out what they call a, quote, deportation dragnet. In other words, they want them to stop showing up to Home Depots and car washes and just scooping up anybody who they feel looks like a potential illegal immigrant to them. The DHS and the Trump administration, again, have countered that that is not what they're doing.  The arguments have just started in the courtroom behind us right now. The plaintiffs in this case are five people who say they were detained by the federal government. They've been joined by the ACLU, the City of Los Angeles, activist groups, and other cities and municipalities. So right now, we're just waiting for our producer in that courtroom to start feeding us some details about what exactly is happening in there. As soon as we get an update, we'll keep you guys posted. We'll send it back to you.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01

video_title: NEW details revealed in Trump assassination attempt nearly one year later

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Nearly one year later, and the nation is still waiting for answers on the assassination attempt against President Trump in Butler, Pennsylvania. In a sit-down interview with Lara Trump, the president looks back on that day.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Well, it was unforgettable. I didn't know exactly what was going on. I got whacked. There's no question about that.  And fortunately got down quickly and people were screaming and I got down quickly fortunately because I think they shot eight bullets and one got me and one got another one and one got another one and one killed Corey the firefighter. Great guy. And you know we had.  A tremendous, massive crowd. Tens of thousands of people were there. And the hour sniper, within less than five seconds, was able to get him from a long distance with one shot. If he didn't do that, you would have had an even worse situation.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: That full interview airs Saturday at 9 p.m. Eastern Time. Members of the Butler County Emergency Services Unit tell Fox Nation what it was like to respond.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Be on the lookout for a white male, blonde hair, backpacked, on a bicycle.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: I immediately contacted the state police sergeant, and I know for a fact he took that information and passed it forward to the Secret Service. And the Secret Service, they were actually answering you? I can tell you 100% that the Secret Service was absolutely aware.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: That's Corey Comparatore's wife asking those questions. And that's from a brand-new Fox Nation special, Butler Under Fire, The Search for Justice. Franco Purino Jr. and Butler County Sheriff Michael Sloop appeared with me today on The Wilkane Country Show. We talked at length about what we know here one year later about Thomas Crooks.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: We have exclusive video from Corey Comperatore's phone. She got the phone back from the FBI, and we actually have the video of Corey recording his final moments when shots were fired.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Over the past year, do you feel like you have understood and have answers to that question of who is Thomas Crooks?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Not at all.  not at all. What we know about Thomas Crooks is still very limited.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: And now we're learning the Secret Service has suspended six agents tasked with protecting President Trump at that rally. The suspensions ranged from 10 to 42 days without pay and happened back in February. Joining me now is former Secret Service agent under President Bush and President Obama, Bill Gage. Bill, thanks for being with us here today. I had a long half hour conversation with the director of this new documentary. He spent the past year investigating this. And I talked to the Butler County Sheriff's Department as well.  Clearly, it didn't go right that day. And I asked them, what went wrong? In the documentary, Bill, you see the TikTok. You hear the testimony of officers saying, we passed the information up about Thomas Crooks' presence to the Secret Service. And yet still, he was able to get on top of the building. And yet still, Donald Trump took the stage. What failed?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Thanks for having me, Will. And, you know, several things failed that day. You know, I've been on other outlets, numerous Fox outlets talking about this in the early hours and days after the Butler assassination. So one of the main things that failed there, clearly the communications, the Secret Service did not have  sort of a unified communication system. The radio comms were dated. When I was an agent, the Secret Service had sort of an antiquated radio system. They've since changed that, and they're in the process of changing that. And one of the other things that failed was the advance team. Clearly, the advance agent  did not make specific responsibilities to the local police of who was responsible for what. So, in my opinion, Will, it was really the radio communications and the advance agent not making clear areas of responsibility. And let me just touch on something you said there, Will, that was in the lead up here that, you know,  Every single event that I went to as a Secret Service agent, every single one, there was reports of a suspicious person, a person with a gun, a person sometimes with a bomb, somebody who was acting strangely. Every single event I went to had that. And the Secret Service has to take what is called a measured response to that. So if every single event this is happening, and every single event there's reports of a suspicious person, the Secret Service cannot go rush the president  or, in this case, a presidential candidate off the stage, it would just be embarrassing for the president or that candidate. So the service has to take what's called a measured response. You have to investigate that. And that's clearly what was going on in Butler. They were getting reports of the suspicious person. They were trying to investigate it the best they could, so to allow the event to continue and to not embarrass then-presidential candidate Trump.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: I appreciate that, Bill. I understand that every rally is going to be suspicious individuals. I would have to suggest that one with a range finder, ultimately a rifle, who climbs on top of a building might make himself stand out. And that over the course of over an hour, that should have been investigated more thoroughly. And I think there are also questions that were raised earlier today as well about whether or not that advance team and the assets on site that day were adequate to be covering a presidential candidate. And we know, from when he returned to Butler, the conditions and the assets dedicated to President Trump  were much greater the next time he comes around. So why wasn't there more the first time around? There's plenty of failure, but that shouldn't absolve us from trying to look for exactly where that failure occurred. All right, Bill, thank you for your time.

summary.Bill_Gage: A former Secret Service agent, Bill Gage, analyses the failures that day. He identifies communication breakdowns, particularly dated radio systems, and inadequate advance planning as key issues. Gage explains that the Secret Service often receives reports of suspicious individuals and must take a measured response. He acknowledges that the specific details of this case, such as the shooter being on a building with a rangefinder for over an hour, should have warranted more thorough investigation.
summary.SPEAKER_01: Former President Trump recounts the assassination attempt. He describes being hit by a bullet, acknowledges the heroism of the firefighter who was killed, and emphasizes the massive crowd present. Trump also suggests that the situation could have been worse if not for the quick action of a sniper.
summary.SPEAKER_02: The host leads the discussion, focussing on the security failures that led to the assassination attempt. They highlight the information passed to the Secret Service about the suspicious person (Thomas Crooks) and question why he was not apprehended. The host also introduces new exclusive video footage and expresses frustration with the lack of answers and accountability. They further discuss the suspensions of Secret Service agents and the inadequacy of the assets dedicated to protecting Trump at the first rally compared to subsequent ones.
summary.SPEAKER_03: A witness confirms passing the information about the suspicious person to the state police and subsequently the Secret Service, asserting that the Secret Service was aware of the threat.
summary.SPEAKER_04: Corey Comparatore's wife questions why her husband's information about the suspicious person was not acted upon by the Secret Service. She expresses her grief and seeks justice for her husband's death.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the assassination attempt on former President Trump nearly a year ago. It highlights the failures in Secret Service security, including communication breakdowns and inadequate advance planning, which allowed the shooter to reach Trump. The discussion also touches on the ongoing search for justice, the lack of information about the shooter, and the public's frustration with the unanswered questions.

video_title: Lisa Boothe EXPOSES Dems' upside-down world

lines.text: manhunt underway right now for a suspect who allegedly fired at ICE agents in Alvarado, Texas last week. Federal immigration officers have been in the crosshairs of violent attacks, literally, since anti-ICE rhetoric ramped up. And it has been. In recent days, federal officers faced two separate ambushes in Texas. 12 suspects now face serious charges in that Alvarado, Texas ambush I was just mentioning previously. 11 of them are facing attempted murder. I think it's very similar to what we're seeing here. I mean, people who, these are ICE agents who put their lives on the line and care about our country, who are just doing their jobs, and now because of people, these extremists, who hate Donald Trump and hate what those of us who care about strong borders stand for, they hate that so much that they're willing to attack the agents themselves. This is, I think, something that I thought we had moved beyond. When I served in uniform, you know, no one, you know, were pushing us or spitting upon us anymore because I thought as a country we had moved on.  But this footage tells me that there's still a segment of people in this country who think political extremist violence is still acceptable.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04

I was talking about the crazy people who they're looking for in the manhunts. But you make a good point. It's hard sometimes to tell the difference in how they express themselves.  No, it really does feel like even though, and we have seen this in Congress when Democrats and Republicans go in for security briefings, you know, Democrats in private will say, you know, I really support our troops. And so my challenge is, if you have a problem with ice and, you know, if it's an institutional problem, then write some legislation and get some of your colleagues on the other side to co-sign it with you to make it better. But this is only raising the temperature. And, you know, now we're just going to fixate on one issue, and that's face masks. And it really lets us take our eye off of the larger picture. lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01

They don't deserve that America. It's ours. They can't take it from us.  It is ours, and we should be taking it back, which is what the Trump administration's trying to do. Only in the Democrat Party are the villains the heroes and the heroes the villains. That's the upside down world that they live in. And make no mistake, our ICE agents are heroes. Look what they do. Absolutely.

video_title: Court throws out plea deal for alleged mastermind of 9/11 attacks

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: A court threw out an agreement that would have allowed accused September 11 mastermind Khalid Sheikh Mohammed to plead guilty and avoid the risk of execution for al Qaeda's 2001 attacks. The deal had been negotiated over two years and was approved by military prosecutors.  It stipulated life sentences without parole for Mohammed and two co-defendants. The decision by a panel of the Federal Appeals Court in Washington, D.C. undoes an attempt to wrap up more than two decades of military prosecution beset by legal and logistical troubles.  It also signals there will be no quick end to the long struggle by the U.S. military and successive administrations to bring justice to the man charged with planning one of the deadliest attacks ever on the United States. Mohammed is accused of developing and directing the plot to crash hijacked airliners into the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. Another of the hijacked planes flew into a field in Pennsylvania.

summary.SPEAKER_00: A court threw out a plea bargain for Khalid Sheikh Mohammed and two co-defendants in the 9/11 attacks. The agreement, negotiated over two years and approved by military prosecutors, would have resulted in life sentences without parole. However, a panel of the Federal Appeals Court in Washington, D.C. has overturned this decision. The court's ruling undoes efforts to conclude the over two-decade-long military prosecution, which has faced numerous legal and logistical challenges. This decision indicates that there will be no swift resolution to the U.S. military's and successive administrations' efforts to bring justice to Mohammed, who is accused of planning the 9/11 attacks.
summary.high_level_summary: A court has rejected a plea deal for Khalid Sheikh Mohammed, the accused mastermind behind the September 11 attacks, and two co-defendants. The deal, which involved life sentences without parole, has been overturned, prolonging the legal proceedings.

Also, performance food group shares surged higher today.  Bloomberg News reported that the company has attracted takeover interest from U.S. Foods Holding Corp. It's a potential deal that would create a food distribution company with a combined sales of roughly $100 billion. This is according to people familiar with the matter. Shares higher by more than 4.8 percent today.  The company would become the number one U.S. food service distributor with 18% of the $371 billion market. This is according to Bloomberg Intelligence. We should note there is no certainty that these deliberations will lead to transactions, and representatives for U.S. Foods and Performance Food declined to comment.  And finally, this is a former micro-cap that is now a small cap after today's move of close to 40 percent, Unusual Machines. It's a drone tech company based in Florida, and drone-related firms rallied today, this after Fox News reported that Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth has issued orders to ramp up production and deployment of drones.  unusual machines hired today by close to 40 percent. Josh Sullivan over at Benchmark says the memo focused on three main goals, bolstering U.S. drone manufacturing, delivering thousands of low-cost drones to the military, and integrating drone operating into training. Once again, shares higher by close to 40 percent, Nora.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Well, we've got a few names in the red as expected with the market closing lower today. I'm looking at shares of PayPal. That was the worst performing stock in the S&P 500 today. And we're seeing a lot of other fintech companies like Block and Affirm also falling as well. And that all came after a headline that we saw earlier.  as we were heading into the close with JP Morgan telling that these FinTech companies that they're gonna have to pay up for customer data. That could amount to hundreds of millions of dollars for access to customers, bank account information. So we're seeing those FinTech companies falling, but also credit card firms like Visa, MasterCard also lower with the move really threatening to upend specifically the FinTech sectors business models. Another stock I'm looking at is Albemarle, that's ticker ALB.  $8.3 billion company. It's a lithium producer based in Charlotte, North Carolina, and it was cut to sell from neutral at UBS, with its price target trimmed to $57 from $64. We have the analysts here encouraging investors to, quote, fade the bounce.  As he expects, lithium prices will remain lower. And one more stock we have for you, Boyd Gaming, ticker BYD, but not the BYD you're thinking of. It's a casino operator in Las Vegas, Nevada, $6.5 billion in market cap. And it was cut to neutral from positive. They're really pointing to the stock's valuation after selling its 5% ownership in FanDuel to Flutter. And this is all from Susquehanna Financial. They're also citing the renegotiation of its market  Access Agreement.

lines.text: All right, let's take a quick check in yields here. A little bit of a subdued day, but a lot of activity when we talk about what happened on the week. A push higher once again across the curve. A second straight week where we see yields move higher, but more importantly is the complexion of that move. A definite slam to the upside, a steepening, a bear steepening of that curve with most, of course, of the sell-off coming on the longer end of the curve. That 30-year yield up about eight basis points on the day and on the week. It's more than nine basis points higher than where it was last Friday.  What if I told you... Go on.

Kate Crater wrote a story for Bloomberg. She covers food all over the world. She's been in London these past few years. And she writes about some restaurants in London.  that are really serving a lot of food that we focused on here in New York and that New York has become known for. And it's actually really, really good.

And it's interesting because they're saying that even though it's a high tourist season here in New York, things are a bit quieter than usual. I don't really feel that when I'm walking through these streets at all here, Tim. But apparently that's the case right now.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: So I mean, the idea with this, though, too, I mean, we talk about this idea. And this is just sort of a part of the show where I get to dump on the British. Because it's like all their good food, none of their good food is actually British food. It's just like, I mean, you get some great New York food, as you just talked out. You get some great Indian food and South Asian food in there. You get all this great stuff there. What happened to, like, British food?  It's like peas and toast, right?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: The bangers and mash, the fish and chips. There's some good stuff there, guys.

lines.text: That's awesome. And Brexit hasn't affected any of this? Not that I know of.

lines.text: OK.

lines.speaker: Unidentified SPEAKER
lines.text: Wow.

lines.text: Anyway, do you want to talk about airplanes?

lines.text: Sure. Talk about airplanes.

lines.text: Okay, let's talk about airplanes. There's an interesting story on the terminal Delta apparently is stripping engines from new Airbus jets in Europe to use them on grounded planes in the U.S. This is according to Bloomberg reporting. This caught my eye.

lines.text: What do you mean stripping from airplanes? That's exactly what it sounds like.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: So these are planes they own. This isn't like the guy who comes down my block to steal carburetors or whatever.

But they have this fleet of grounded Airbus A320s that have these Pratt & Whitney engines that have worn out quicker than they were supposed to wear out because of a metal shavings issue.
