video_title: Dinosaur fossil found under Denver museum parking lot

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Dinosaur fossils are a big draw at the Denver Museum of Nature and Science. You can find them all over. But when a team of scientists from the museum were doing research in the parking lot back in January, they didn't expect to find one right below their feet.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: I mean, the probability, if you had drilled the well two feet over, might not have hit it. So it's pretty amazing.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Dr. James Hagedorn led the team drilling into the parking lot.  They were digging scientific cores, testing whether or not the museum could transition from natural gas to geothermal energy.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: So a scientific core is basically a cylinder of rock that we extract, kind of like a doctor uses a syringe to extract blood from you. So in a way, it is a bunch of dirt. It's kind of ancient dirt, actually. And nearly 800 feet into that ancient dirt, the fossil showed up. So one of the surprising things about this dinosaur in particular is that it turns out it's not only Denver's deepest dinosaur, but it's also its oldest. Those aren't the only records this bone is breaking.  This is the first, and as far as I know, the only dinosaur bone from a core in the world that you can go see. There's only three of these that have been discovered on Earth.  and then have been reported.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Dr. Hagedorn says his paleontologist colleagues determined the bone is the vertebra of a plant-eating dino.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: And thanks to the rest of the Corps, he says you can tell the layer the fossil was found near was that of a pond.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: So for me, it's pretty neat to see, was that dinosaur drinking water out of that pond or munching on plants nearby? It's just something cool to imagine.  A rare discovery made right beneath his feet. It is a needle inside of a needle inside of a haystack. Brian Wendland, Nine News.

video_title: FEMA records show alerts were not sent to all phones ahead of Texas flood

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: As the search for the missing continues in Kerr County, records reviewed by NBC 5 Investigates raise new questions about whether local officials could have used the nation's wireless emergency alert system to better warn people in the path of the flood.  Along with our partners at NBC News, we scoured a FEMA archive of cell phone alerts sent through FEMA's Integrated Public Alert and Warning System, or IPAWS, a system many local counties, including Kerr County, are authorized to use to issue warnings to all cell phones in a designated area. It's the same system used to send Amber Alerts.  The FEMA message archive shows as the water began rising in Kerr County on July 4th, the National Weather Service did send a flood warning to cell phones as early as 1.14 a.m. But Weather Service forecasters cannot issue instructions on whether to evacuate or wait for rescue. Those messages are up to county or city officials. And the FEMA archive shows Kerr County did not send any wireless alerts through IPAWS on the 4th when the flooding began.  Some families say they did receive what's called a Code Red alert from Kerr County that's similar to an I-Pause message. But Code Red only reaches people who signed up for alerts.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Most of the people I talked to didn't even know what Code Red was.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Lewis and Leslie Kossurik shared a screenshot of the Kerr County Dispatch code red they received, saying major flooding continues. But the Kossuriks say that message didn't hit their phones until after 10 a.m. By then, one flood gauge in Kerr County shows the river had already risen about 30 feet. And the Kossuriks had taken this photo showing roads in their neighborhood were already cut off.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: I'm mad because  you know, like I told ano lives do we have to lose the system. It's broken.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: more wide reaching IPAWS flooding in the past. Th  Last year, on July 23rd, the archive shows the county sent an I-Pause alert saying the Guadalupe River was expected to rise an additional four feet, telling people to avoid the river and move assets to higher ground immediately. So why no county I-Pause alert before the flood this time? NBC5 Investigates reached out to Kerr County Judge Rob Kelly and Emergency Management Coordinator William Thomas, but they did not immediately respond to questions.  At a news conference last week, Kelly was asked why children's camps along the river were not evacuated.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: I can't answer that. I don't know.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: He said the county never expected water would rise so fast.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: We didn't know this flood was coming. Rest assured, no one knew this kind of flood was coming.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Researchers who studied the IPAWS system tell us communities sometimes struggle to decide when to issue cell phone alerts, who should send those alerts, and what the messages should say. A struggle stemming in part, they say, from a lack of standardized nationwide policies.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: There is no required training. There's no certification process currently within IPAWS.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Emergency alert researcher Jeanette Sutton explained it's up to each local government to write its own policies. She says that's created differences in how effectively the system is used in each community.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: We need a lot of training and we need the resources to help people to get trained.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Sutton's team at the University at Albany recently helped FEMA develop a tool local emergency managers can use to pre-plan more effective messages before disaster strikes.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: they are generally facing a blank text box that says, insert message here. And you can imagine that in a situation where there's a lot of stress and uncertainty, that writing a message from scratch is very difficult.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: In a statement to NBC5, FEMA said its IPAWS office encourages and supports practicing and exercising, and said the agency makes training tools available, enabling public safety officials to gain confidence using IPAWS.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: It is really important to get it right when people's lives are on the line.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Sutton says cell phone alerts can be critical, especially in places like Kerr County, which doesn't have a siren warning system. But she says counties should also amplify alerts using tools like social media, or even knocking on doors, as cell phone service is sometimes spotty in rural areas. On the morning of the July 4th floods, the Kerr County Sheriff's Department did use its Facebook account, posting messages around 5.30 a.m. warning of dangerous flooding, urging people to move to higher ground.  Alerts that could reach social media users awake at the time, but would not sound a cell phone alert like an iPause message. At a news conference Wednesday, the sheriff said the county would look into whether evacuation orders should have been issued.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Sometimes evacuation is not the safest. Sometimes it's better to shelter in place.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: And he pledged to examine why cell phone alerts did not happen sooner.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Those are important questions. We will answer those questions.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Questions with answers that might help other communities face the next disaster. Scott Friedman, NBC5 Investigates.

summary.SPEAKER_00: The narrator investigates Kerr County's failure to use the WEA system during the July 4th flood. They highlight the timeline of events, the contrasting use of IPAWS in previous incidents, and the challenges faced by local governments in using the IPAWS system effectively. The narrator also mentions the statements from Kerr County officials, the efforts of researchers to improve the system, and the alternative alert methods used by the county.
summary.SPEAKER_01: Expresses frustration with the Code Red system, stating that most people didn't know about it. They also question the effectiveness of the alert system and the lack of timely warnings.
summary.SPEAKER_02: The Kerr County Sheriff acknowledges the importance of investigating the delay in issuing WEA alerts. He also mentions the complexities of deciding when to evacuate or shelter in place.
summary.SPEAKER_03: A resident, Lewis Kossurik, expresses anger that lives could have been lost due to the inadequate alert system, calling it "broken".
summary.SPEAKER_04: Jeanette Sutton, an Emergency Alert Researcher, explains the lack of standardized policies and training in the IPAWS system. She emphasizes the need for better preparation and resources to help emergency managers use the system effectively.
summary.high_level_summary: NBC 5 Investigates reports that Kerr County, Texas, failed to utilize the Wireless Emergency Alert (WEA) system during a flood on July 4th, despite the National Weather Service issuing a flood warning. Instead, they relied on a voluntary Code Red alert system. Some residents received Code Red alerts after 10am when the river had already risen significantly. The report highlights issues with the IPAWS system, including lack of standardized nationwide policies, required training, and certification process. Kerr County officials claimed they were unaware of the severity of the flood, and the sheriff pledged to investigate why WEA alerts were not issued sooner.

video_title: Trump speaks from Texas after deadly floods: ‘Filled with grief and devastation’

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: gone to a lot of hurricanes, a lot of tornadoes. I've never seen anything like this. This is a this is a bad one. We just visited with incredible families that I mean, look, they've been devastated. They lost their child or two children and  Just hard to believe what I've never seen anything like it a little narrow river that becomes a monster and that's what happened but the first lady and I are here in Texas to express the love and support and The anguish of our entire nation in the aftermath of this really horrific and deadly Flood nobody has any idea how and why a thing like this could happen and  It's and by the way, I have to tell you, the people here, first responders, the sheriff's office, all of the police, law enforcement, they've done an unbelievable job. And in speaking to the parents, they said everybody has been so professional from the governor to the senators all the way down.  to the local people on the site that really are a little bit used to this. They've been looking at this for years, but in much smaller doses, in a much, much smaller doses. Twelve years ago and then in 1932, they had a real bad one, but that bad one was half of what this was. But I was speaking to some of  the great people in the town, and they said, no, every year we get a little bit, but it was like a little bit of a flood, right? You were telling me, and it was just a flood. We got used to it. We had people, and we took care of it. And this year, it was like, what's going on, right? So all across the country, Americans' hearts are shattered. I had to be here as president. First lady wanted to be here.  all the beautiful souls. And we're filled with grief and devastation, the loss of life. And unfortunately, they're still looking. They're still looking. There's a lot of missing children, possibly, mostly. We don't know. But they're still looking.  And they'll find everybody. But it's not an easy thing. You would think it would be easy. It's very tough. I looked at what they're going through, what they have to do. But dozens and dozens of precious children taken from us with such — I looked at the pictures of almost all of them.  And it's terrible. Following a torrential downpour, the worst that anyone's ever seen, Guadalupe River rose 26 feet in less than 45 minutes. And I've even heard it went well over 30 feet. There's one story that one person said it had to be 60 feet at one moment. This is like a giant, giant wave in the Pacific Ocean.  that the best surfers in the world would be afraid to surf. And it unleashed a catastrophic flooding, as the most – most residents were asleep in their beds. A very dark evening. The waters claimed at least 135, 140 lives. They're getting that count, but the count that they don't have is how many are still  missing with a lot of lives, a lot of young angels. At the girls' Christian summer camp, known as Camp Mystic, a legendary camp, a camp that people would want to go to from all over the country. People, parents, they come and they would stay with their children. They'd stay in other cabins just to be with their children, but a legendary place. They were there because they loved God. And as we grieve this unthinkable tragedy,  We take comfort in the knowledge that God has welcomed those little, beautiful girls into his comforting arms in heaven. And we believe that, have to believe that, and we do. And we lost some wonderful people beyond the little girls. We lost some very brave men and women that tried to save the girls.  Our nation, we mourn for every single life that was swept away in the flood, and we pray for the families that are left behind. It's amazing the incredible spirit from those families. I don't know. I don't even know.  how they do it. For moments ago, Melania and I spent a lot of time with them. That's why we're a little late. I think this was a good reason to be late, frankly. And we just gave our warmest condolences. But you say to yourself, you know, how do you give condolences? How do you do that to a young person that  three days ago was here, four days ago was here, and vibrant, and now is no longer here. The search for the missing continues. The people that are doing it are unbelievable people. You couldn't get better people than this anywhere. Christy, right? Anywhere in the world, you couldn't get better people. And they're doing the job like I don't think anybody else could, frankly.  And I want to thank them. I want to thank all of these great first responders who raced into very grave danger. We have some people that were incredible. The single Coast Guard rescue crew saved an incredible 169 children at Camp Mystic. We thank you for watching. And remember, stay updated on breaking news and top stories on the NBC News app or watch live on our YouTube channel.

summary.Donald_Trump: The President described the flood as unprecedented and catastrophic, comparing it to a giant wave. He emphasised the loss of life, particularly among children at Camp Mystic, stating that dozens were taken away. He praised the first responders, law enforcement, and local officials for their professional and unbelievable job. The President also noted the historical significance of the flood, mentioning previous floods in the area but emphasising that this one was much worse. He shared stories he heard from the locals and expressed his anguish and disbelief at the tragedy. The President also acknowledged the search efforts for the missing people and thanked the Coast Guard rescue crew that saved 169 children.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation is about a devastating flood in Texas that caused widespread loss of life, particularly among children at a summer camp. The President and First Lady visited the affected area to express their condolences, support, and grief to the families and the entire nation. They highlighted the heroic efforts of the first responders and the resilience of the local community.

video_title: 'We are grieving with you': Melania Trump offers condolences to Texas flood victims

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: My deepest sympathy to all of the parents who lost beautiful young souls. Deepest sympathy from all of us, to the community, to everybody who lost a loved one.  We are grieving with you. Our nation is grieving with you. We just met with the wonderful families. We pray with them. We hug. We hold hands. They shared the stories and I met beautiful young ladies. They gave me  this special bracelet from the camp in honor of all of the little girls that they lost their lives. So we are here to honor them and also to give the support, help, and I will be back. I promise to them and I just pray for them and giving them my strength and love.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: We thank you for watching, and remember, stay updated on breaking news and top stories on the NBC News app, or watch live on our YouTube channel.

video_title: Trump rebukes Texas reporter for question on timing of flood alerts

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Several families we've heard from are obviously upset because they say that those warnings, those alerts didn't go out in time. And they also say that people could have been safe. What do you say to those families?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Well, I think everyone did an incredible job under the circumstances. This was, I guess, Christy said, a one in 500, one in a thousand years. And I just have admiration for  the job that everybody did. There was just admiration. Only a bad person would ask a question like that, to be honest with you. I don't know who you are, but only a very evil person would ask a question like that. I think this has been heroism. This has been incredible, really, the job you've all done. It's easy to sit back and say, oh, what could have happened here or there? Maybe we could have done something differently. This was a thing that has never happened before.  Nobody's ever seen anything. I've never seen anything like this. I've gone to some real bad ones I've never seen anything like this. So I Admire you and I consider you heroes and heroine and I think you've done an amazing job

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: We have to devise a response that's right for this community. And this community has to weigh in. And they need time to be able to convey that to us. But we're going to work on alerts. We're going to work on every single solution to make sure things like this don't happen again, not just in this community, but in other river basins across the state also. So we will work to get it right. We thank you for watching. And remember, stay updated on breaking news and top stories on the NBC News app or watch live on our YouTube channel.

video_title: Trump says he struck a deal to send weapons to NATO for Ukraine

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Welcome back. In my conversation with President Trump yesterday, I also pressed him on the war in Ukraine. The president telling me he's disappointed in Russia and hinting he has a major statement on Russia planned for Monday, but he declined to elaborate. President Trump also revealed to me a new weapons deal he reached with NATO, saying, quote, we're sending weapons to NATO and NATO is paying for those weapons 100%.  So what we're doing is the weapons that are going out are going to NATO, and then NATO is going to be giving those weapons, and NATO is paying for those weapons. When I asked him if the U.S. would also be sending weapons directly to Ukraine, the president said, no, we're not sending to Ukraine, we're sending them through NATO.  In response to those comments, a NATO spokesperson said, quote, allies continue to work to ensure Ukraine has the support they need to defend themselves against Russia's aggression. This includes urgent efforts to procure key supplies from the United States, including air defense and ammunition. Joining me now on set is NBC News national security reporter Gordon Lubold. Thank you so much for being here.  So when I first heard about this deal with NATO, I really tried to press the president on the specifics of this. How would a deal like this work? Can you provide more context? What exactly does it mean to have NATO pay for and supply the weapons, distribute the weapons?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: I mean, it means a completely different model than what has ever been used. I think it's unclear what exactly the president means, and we'll find out maybe in coming days if there's more to that. Clearly, the president wants to distance himself from contributing aid to Ukraine.  He's currently in a mode of frustrated with Russian President Vladimir Putin. We'll see how long that lasts. But for right now, it seems like this is a way to kind of thread the needle with Ukraine, provide some assistance through NATO at NATO's expense, however that exactly works, practically speaking, and maybe  still get to a deal somehow down the line.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: And it comes as he's expressing increased frustration with Russia this week publicly saying that the United States gets fed a lot of BS, although he said the full term.  by Putin and then in his call with me saying that he's really disappointed with Russia and that he has this major announcement coming on Monday. I pressed him over and over, what does that mean? Does it mean sanctions? He wouldn't say. We know that Senator Lindsey Graham, a Trump ally, has been preparing this sanctions package against Ukraine. Are you hearing anything about what he might be announcing or the implications of an announcement coming against the backdrop of momentum building for a sanctions package?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: I think it's anyways, yes, still. And they may be still trying to figure it out over the weekend, as you well know. The president sometimes gets over his skis in terms of what he says rhetorically, and then they kind of figure it out on the fly. Again, this is the kind of more  The furthest he's gone of late, with regard to Putin, in terms of his frustration. And it's kind of growing. I think, from what I understand, the reaction from Moscow is, we're calm here. We're going to weather this current storm. We'll see what happens. Now, if the frustration is sustained by the president, I think then Putin is going to have to maybe do a recalculation of his own position.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Yeah, well, we'll see what he announces. And I should say sanctions against Russia, not sanctions against Ukraine. Very quickly, I asked the president about Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth. He said he's doing a great job, despite the reports that Hegseth had actually paused weapons shipments without making the White House aware.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Right. And so we don't know who said what to whom just yet. It's been very confusing. I think he's sticking with his defense secretary. But as you also well know, he sticks with people until he doesn't stick with them.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: That's right. All right. Another storyline we'll be watching very closely out of the White House. Gordon, thanks so much for being here.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: We thank you for watching. And remember, stay updated on breaking news and top stories on the NBC News app or watch live on our YouTube channel.

summary.SPEAKER_00: The host summarises President Trump's interview, highlighting the new NATO weapons deal where NATO pays for US weapons supplied to them, and Trump's disinterest in direct US aid to Ukraine. The host also discusses Trump's frustration with Russia, his upcoming major statement on Russia, and the potential implications of this statement, including possible sanctions. Additionally, the host touches upon reports of tensions between Trump and Defence Secretary Pete Hegseth.
summary.SPEAKER_01: Gordon Lubold analyses the new NATO weapons deal, suggesting it is a novel approach to distance Trump from direct aid to Ukraine. He notes Trump's growing frustration with Russia but emphasises the uncertainty surrounding the specifics of the NATO deal and Trump's upcoming announcement. Lubold also mentions the reaction from Moscow and the possibility of Putin recalculating his position if Trump's frustration sustains.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses a new weapons deal with NATO announced by President Trump and his evolving stance on Russia and Ukraine.

video_title: Charlie Kirk: If Republicans Don't Do This Then 'Mamdani Will Just Be The Beginning'

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: All right, have a seat everybody. Who's excited to be here in Tampa, Florida for the Student Action Summit? This is the largest Student Action Summit in history. By far, nearly double the size of the one that we had a couple years ago. And for those of you that are visiting that are not students, we give the best seats to students for a reason. Because these students, every day,  are on the front lines being smeared, being slandered, being canceled, being kicked out of classes, kicked out of fraternities, kicked out of sororities. These are the students that worked so hard to register voters this last election. These are the students that start these chapters. They are the vanguard for saving this country.  13 years ago, when I first started Turning Point USA and this journey began, if you would have told me 13 years later that we would have someone running for the presidency as a Republican, winning the youth vote in major states,  I would say, how would that be possible? 13 years ago, we started the journey, and it was chapter by chapter, student by student, person by person, prove me wrong by prove me wrong, liberal by liberal, proving one wrong at a time, and billions and billions of views later, what happened in November was a shot heard around the world. You see, all Kamala Harris needed to do was get younger people to vote at the same margins that Joe Biden got them to vote back in 2020.  Did you know that baby boomers moved three points more Democrat back in November? Aha. But younger voters moved 22 points to the right in November. The youth delivered the White House to Donald Trump. The next generation rose up in record numbers, and I started to see it at the Prove Me Wrongs across America.  We would just start with a couple hundred students, and all of a sudden like a thousand students would come. And all of a sudden they'd be wearing red hats as far as the eye could see. I said, there's something profound happening in this country. There's something that is deep, that is larger than what the media is covering. And we turned that red MAGA hat from a symbol that everybody was afraid to wear back in 2016, where now in 2024, we turned that into a symbol of hope,  into a symbol of optimism, of patriotism, and taking back our country. Back in November, when we rose up, younger voters saw President Trump as a lifeline. President Donald Trump represented for them a way to try to get everybody's attention that things were not all right for this generation.  You see, I spend a lot of time talking to Next Generation. We just did an entire, prove me wrong with many of you out in the hall. I did over 100 hours of campus debates this last semester. 200 hours in one year. Over 65 campuses that I visit. And a through line is repeated. Whether they're Republican or Democrat or conservative or liberal, there is an angst, there's an uneasiness, there is a worry, there is a concern. And they say in no uncertain terms, Charlie, I'm trying to get my leader's attention. I can't afford a home.  I can't afford basic necessities. If I ask a girl out on a date and I get one word wrong, she could report me for sexual harassment. I am surrounded by this political correctness where if I don't get the pronouns correct of the trans activist next to me in class, it could be the end of my career.  My town, my city is flooded by illegal aliens. Charlie, when will my leaders start fighting for me and my generation? I hear every single day from you in this audience, the students, Charlie, why is it that we spend hundreds of billions of dollars on wars abroad, but our own generation has to go endlessly in debt to pay our medical bills and suffer under credit card debt? Why is it that our young, why you, the next generation, have to compete  to buy a home against a Chinese oligarch. Let me be very clear. No foreign national should be allowed to own single-family homes until this generation can have the same homes that their parents have. And this angst and this unease built up and built up, and it culminated in the election of Donald Trump. The youth delivered the White House for President Trump. And understand that now six, seven months later,  We've inherited a disordered economy from Joe Biden. If we do not deliver on economic promises, especially for the next generation, if we do not make you owners of this economy, not just renters of this economy, then you're going to see a lot more Zoran Mamdanis.  Now, we should boo Zoran Mamdani. The guy is a bigot, anti-civilization to his core, anti-American, anti-Western, wants to nationalize or make all the grocery stores run by the government, defund the police. All that is garbage. But we fail to understand why he is rising. Yeah, part of it is that people in New York are not like you wonderful people here in Florida. That's partially it. But there's a deeper thing at play.  Younger voters are trying to get their leaders' attention. We can't afford anything. Homes are out of reach. I'm tired of renting all the time, and I have zero equity to my name. If we do not solve the economic disorder that is facing this generation, from the debts, the deficits, student loan debt, cost of living, then Mamdani will just be the beginning  of what you're going to see in communities across the country. So what is the solution? Well, the solution is what President Trump is trying to do every single day, and we need more of it. We need double and tripling down on it. Starting with those of you that are looking for a job, you should not have to compete against a foreigner for your job. American college graduates should come first. And that starts with  President Donald Trump, and this will affect everybody in this room regardless of age. It is time for the largest deportation effort this country has ever seen.  If you are here illegally, you are deported from the United States of America. Period. No amnesty. Repeat after me. No amnesty. Period. End of story. We will not put up with any exceptions, any carve-outs, any loopholes, any exceptions, any asterisks, any iotas. I don't care if it's 10 years or 15 years.  We voted for mass deportations, we did not vote for mass amnesty, and we expect our leaders to deliver it and bring back our country to a place of citizenship and Americans being put first. Number two, very important, it is more than past time for our elected leaders to understand  that they're going to have to put the economics of the next generation into their calculus. This is something that Mom Donnie does, but he does it so sloppily. He says, if you're bitter and you don't like the country, vote for me and I'm gonna give you a bunch of free stuff. Everybody, endless tax cuts just for the wealthy. That's fine, I like tax cuts, it's good. My radio show does really well, podcast does well. But I'll tell you right now, you are going to see a massive breakdown of the political order. If people don't own stuff,  our politics are about to get a lot more radical. But let's go a step further. We need to celebrate, embrace, platform, and sometimes, if necessary, subsidize getting married and having children. We are not having enough children in this country.  This is a national crisis. I don't want to hear about, well, you know, racism is a threat to America. It's a bunch of horsepucky. Oh, environmentalism, climate change. Do you know what a threat to our country is? We're not having enough babies. Now, my wife and I, we are doing our part. We have two young children, and we'll see what else the Lord has in store.  But I was fascinated today by talking to our amazing young patriots as part of Turning Point USA. I was so moved. And they say, Charlie, I want to get married. I want to have kids. It's hard to find other people that share my values. By the way, for everyone watching online, if you want to find your future husband or wife, that's why you should be here in Tampa, Florida, because there's a lot of eligible bachelor and bachelorettes here, a lot. But we must prioritize it. We should tell our young ladies.  that if you wanna go be the CEO of a shoe company, that's fine, but do you know what's really gonna matter 30 years from now? What's gonna matter is whether or not you have the love of your life and you have decided to raise children. It doesn't matter how many trips to Thailand you make. It doesn't matter how many nights out at the club. What matters is what lasts, and what matters is things that are hard. What strikes me about this generation, this generation is the most conservative generation that we have seen in well over 50 years, and the numbers show it.  This is the greatest generational realignment since Woodstock. We have never seen a generation move so quickly and so fast. And you guys are making all the liberals confused. They thought you were going to be the most liberal generation.  But part of the reasons why this happened is those of you that are here in this audience and the millions of people that voted for President Trump and that are part of our movement, you were lied to so repeatedly. Wear the mask. Take the vaccine. No prom. No graduation. School closures. America's a racist country. You experienced the worst of the American left. And your politics now is a rejection of all of that garbage. No more political correctness. And you know what's amazing?  Church attendance was going down steadily in America the last 20 years. It's gone up slightly because this is the most religious generation that we have seen in 40 years. Do you understand the significance of that? Because at its core, what we are fighting is a spiritual battle. This is a spiritual sickness throughout the West. And if you're here and you don't believe in God, OK, fine, I'll pray for you. And I hope you find Jesus Christ as your Lord and Savior, because it will change your life.  But understand, you should even be cheering for a religious revival. You get the worst ideas when you have secularism. Men give birth. No borders. America's a terrible country. These things are almost all outgrowths of secularism. But this generation, you guys want something deeper. You want something more. And let me put this in existential terms.  If we do not deliver, we are going to see all of these gains made by Donald Trump, and many of these people will either not vote at all, or they'll be scooped up by some Democrat opportunist. What needs to happen is a couple things. I'm still waiting for it. Where is the national apology to you guys, this generation, for what happened to you during COVID?  Where is the apology saying, we never should have shut down the schools, we never should have taken graduation from you, we never should have forced a vaccine on you that doesn't work and kicked you out of school if you didn't take it? And the lack of the apology shows that we are in, we are in, dare I say, a turning point. We are in a place where decisions need to be made, a time for choosing.  And our leaders in D.C. better start to get the memo. Because there is a movement coming. And yes, it is the most conservative generation. But that doesn't mean they're gonna support every single Republican. If you're a Republican, and you support, yay, more foreign aid to endless countries, Gen Z doesn't want that, actually. They want Americans to be put first, not foreigners to be put first. If you're a Republican,  And all of a sudden you say, we're just going to, you know, let the market do its job. And we don't care, even though things are incredibly out of reach. You're going to say, you know what? No. I like what President Trump is doing at tariffs. I want stuff made in America again. You see, there is a new ascendant movement. I've done my best to try to warn people what is coming. And I think it's exciting. I think it's new. I think it's fresh. I think it's authentic. Because if you look at the last 50 years, we've had a ton of problems in this country, from our debts and our deficits to our hyperinflation.  to mass migration. And another thing that this generation increasingly believes, they don't necessarily believe that immigration makes your country better. You only get Mom Donny, you get Elon Omar and Rashida Tlaib not just because of illegal immigration.  It's legal immigration that is also the problem. When you allow a bunch of people into your country legally and they don't share your values, turns out they don't always assimilate. Mamdani and his entire family came here legally. They didn't come across the southern border. No one can tell me that that person is improving the United States of America. He's a self-righteous, narcissistic parasite on New York City and should be expelled from politics, but we let him in. Maybe it's time.  Maybe it is time for us to reconsider almost all of our political orthodoxies. Do immigrants really make our country better? Some do. Some of our amazing Cuban immigrants here that I see in the audience, you've assimilated, you make America better. But if you come from Somalia and you refuse to learn our language, adopt to our customs, and assimilate, I'm sorry, America is closed to the third world until further notice. We are not a dumping ground for the rest of the planet.  The Democrat Party is trying to figure themselves out right now, and they're in a position where they don't really know their leader, but they will eventually figure it out. They're a major political party, and they're desperate to get back into action. But this is where things really become real very quickly, is that this is the greatest opportunity that I am afraid that some in the Republican Party are messing up. President Trump understands this better than anybody else.  You understand how incredible that is, what a death blow it is to win the youth vote as a Republican? Do you know what that means? That means if you hold on to that demographic and that generation, it's done for the left. So shouldn't it be that our leaders should be thinking every single day, how do I hold on to this and grow it?  Instead, at times, I don't always feel that energy out of Washington, D.C. Instead, I feel as if they take you for granted, the younger voters that are going through this. And you know what? The next couple days, we need to make our voice heard. We need to send a message to D.C. and to the rest of the bipartisan cartel that we want our own interests represented. Because if we allow the generational theft to continue, which is the plundering of the next generation,  Then I'll say it once, I'll say it twice, you will see a radicalization event from the left that will take your breath away. But here is the advantage, everybody, is that we are the ascendant political force. We did the impossible. We turned campuses into MAGA. We moved the youth vote by 20 or 30 points. We turned the country from super woke to all of a sudden super patriotic in a short period of time.  But now this is where all of you, it matters. If you are not yet involved in a Turning Point USA chapter, start one. Start a high school or college chapter. Go to the Turning Point USA booth after this and say, I want to go start a chapter. I want to get involved on my college campus.  If you are not a student and you're listening to this, politics is now a 24-7 sport. Get involved in your school board. Get involved in your city council. Support your local Turning Point USA chapter. Hold your Senate accountable. Who here is from South Carolina? Anybody from South Carolina? Great. Go primary Lindsey Graham and make sure he's no longer a sitting U.S. Senator.  Who here is from—let's pick a state. Who here is from Kentucky? Anybody? Anybody from Kentucky? Great. I'm behind Nate Morris. I think he'd be a great person to replace Mitch McConnell. We need to make sure that the Mitch McConnell era ends in Kentucky and does not continue to spread. Everybody, this movement is a grassroots movement at its core. And it's a question the next couple of days, and you're going to hear from a wide variety of speakers. You're going to hear from Tucker Carlson tonight.  You're going to hear from Donald Trump Jr. You're going to hear from Megyn Kelly. You're going to hear from Pete Hegseth. You're going to hear from Kristi Noem. And it is time for us to chart a vision. President Donald Trump took the entire country on his shoulders and was millimeters away from having his brains blown out. And by the way, we're going to remember it this weekend. This weekend is July 13th, where President Trump was this close from losing his life.  But everybody, what a tragedy it would be if, by divine intervention, God saved the country and we decided to just cast it aside, where we have this ascendant, exciting, charismatic, bottom-up energy of young people from across America. And the mandate is very simple. Business as usual as D.C. will no longer work. It is time for us to get involved in primaries. It's time for us to make our voice heard.  It's time for us to take over the Republican Party in a conservative image. It's time for us to support the good guys and out the bad guys. And at times, for all the young people out there, you need to keep fighting on your college campus. I know you're outnumbered by the purple-haired jihadis on a daily basis. I know that everybody on a college campus, they try to intimidate you, they try to threaten you.  But everyone who's not a student in here, I want to reiterate this. What they're doing is one of the hardest things to do in the United States of America. They are deciding to be less popular on campus. They are deciding to actually speak out with a high social cost. They're deciding, even though it might jeopardize their job, their career, or their reputation, to put their country over themselves. And I think that deserves recognition and gratitude, because that is what is the best of this country is. I'll close with this.  We've been given this gift, popular vote majority, electoral vote majority, and now it's on us. We have to execute. We have to have mass deportations.  We have to make sure the border wall is secure. We have to make sure that we fulfill all of our promises when it comes to transparency. We have to make sure that young people can afford homes. If we fail to do this, the coalition will be put in jeopardy. I have faith in President Trump. I do not have faith in the Republican Congress.  These next couple of days here in Tampa, Florida, all 7,000 of you, you are the center of the political universe on the planet right now. Everybody is looking to Tampa, Florida. What will happen here will determine, will chart a new future course. Marriages will happen this weekend.  Lifetime friendships will happen this weekend. Careers will start this weekend. And my challenge for all of you is hold yourself to a higher standard. Make this an action event. This is not like just going to a Tampa Bay Buccaneers game and applauding all the time.  Every speaker say, what are you going to do about it? What are you going to do? Apply the applause into action. We've been given this gift. The next generation helped put Donald Trump into the White House. What comes next will determine whether or not we're a civilization, we're just a collection of colonies and strangers in our own nation. God bless you guys. Thank you so much.

video_title: Chris Deluzio Reacts To Iran Strikes, Calls On Congress To 'Assert Its Role' Over Declaring War

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Congressman, I would love to get your take and turn to things abroad and the situation specifically in the Middle East. Last month, the United States bombed multiple Iranian nuclear sites, involving us in a war between Iran and Israel. President Trump announced days after that that the two countries reached a ceasefire agreement after a tumultuous 12 days of fighting. Now, President Trump says Iran wants to meet with the U.S. for talks. What do you make of where diplomacy now goes from here?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Look, I think diplomacy can succeed. I think it was important that the president secured a ceasefire agreement between the Israelis and the Iranians. As I'm sure you know and your viewers know, the Trump administration was pursuing diplomacy with the Iranians before the decision to strike. I think it's wise, given how weakened the Iranians are, to try to reach an agreement to limit and make it impossible for them to obtain a nuclear weapon, which I think would be disastrous.  for our interest and for the region. And so I would urge any administration, I urge the last one, I urge this one, to try to reach a deal that can constrain the Iranians' ability to develop a nuclear weapon. We've got pretty clear data that when there was a nuclear agreement in place, the Iranians were enriching less uranium  then they were able to enrich once the Trump administration took us out of the nuclear deal with the Iranians. That tells us that a deal with, I think, strict scrutiny and safeguards can work. The devil will be in the details, but I very much encourage this administration to get back to the negotiating table and diplomatic talks and try to hammer out a deal that can protect us and our interest in the region.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, he touted the U.S. strikes as a historic victory that has already changed the face of the Middle East. What are your thoughts on that characterization?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Well, I think we've seen some jockeying back and forth from our own intelligence and defense communities assessment of the attacks. And as a member of the Armed Services Committee, as you can imagine, I won't get into the kinds of briefings I receive in those classified settings. But let's start with number one.  I share the goal that the Iranians should not have a nuclear weapon, period. I'm also someone who believes deeply, and I've thought this whether there was a Democratic president or a Republican president, that we have seen presidents for too long ignore Congress's constitutional power here to decide whether we send Americans to war. And in my book, certainly sending Americans over the airspace of a foreign country and dropping bombs is the kind of conduct that only the Congress can authorize in this kind of strike. And so I've been  Disappointed to see this president do that. I've been disappointed in the past to see Democratic and Republican presidents ignore Congress. And I think Congress has to step in to assert its role and to, frankly, stand up for the American people who get to decide whether we send Americans into the hell of war, as I say. I'm a veteran of the war in Iraq. I know what it is to see our country deliberate and deliberate poorly, to be frank, as they did 20 plus years ago with the decision to invade Iraq.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: And to that point, Congressman, after the U.S. struck the Iranian nuclear sites just a few weeks ago, there were real fears of a potential World War III, the United States entering another war in the Middle East. As someone who is a veteran who was deployed to the Middle East, I mean, do you share those fears right now?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Yes, and I don't want to see us embroiled in another Middle Eastern war with who knows what timeline to end. So I'm glad to see that the ceasefire was brokered between the Israelis and the Iranians. I hope that it can hold. I hope that diplomacy can be successful with the Iranians.  to reach some agreement to block their development of a nuclear weapon and to give us some pretty strict safeguards in place. But certainly, I don't want to see young Americans fighting in another forever war in the Middle East. And I don't think that's a partisan position. I think if you ask veterans of my generation, Republican or Democrat, they tell you the same thing. They want our government to be much, much more careful about committing American lives and American treasure to fight. And I don't think it's in our interest to send Americans off to fight another war in the Middle East right now.

summary.SPEAKER_00: The interviewer asks about the situation in the Middle East following the U.S. bombings of Iranian nuclear sites, the ceasefire agreement, and Iran's willingness to meet with the U.S. for talks. They also probe Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu's characterisation of the strikes as a historic victory and the fears of a potential World War III.
summary.SPEAKER_01: The Congressman believes diplomacy can succeed in limiting Iran's nuclear capabilities. He emphasises the importance of re-entering a nuclear deal with strict scrutiny and safeguards, noting that previous agreements reduced Iran's uranium enrichment. He criticises both Democratic and Republican administrations for ignoring Congress's constitutional power to authorise war, highlighting his concerns as a veteran who wants to avoid another forever war in the Middle East.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the recent U.S. strikes on Iranian nuclear sites, the subsequent ceasefire between Iran and Israel, and the potential for diplomatic talks with Iran. The focus is on the dangers of nuclear proliferation, the role of Congress in authorising war, and the shared desire to avoid another prolonged Middle Eastern conflict.

video_title: Secretary Of State Marco Rubio Says Trump's Tariffs 'Should've Been Done A Long Time Ago'

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Mr. Secretary, what do you say to those who make the argument that the U.S. tariffs or the threat of those tariffs in the region actually creates an opening for China to be seen as the stable economic partner here?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: I don't agree with that assessment. I mean, look, at the end of the day, the United States has built these tremendous trade imbalances over the last 30 or 40 years. It's unfair to American and American workers, and American, in addition to, threaten our industrial capacity. Trade needed to be revisited. The President campaigned on that, and that's what he's doing, and he's resetting it on a global scale.  At the end of the day, look, I think countries are going to trade with multiple countries. We don't view this as an opening for anyone. We don't view it that way. We view it as an opportunity to reset global trade in a way that's fair for Americans after two or three decades of unfairness. If you look at some of these trade deficits, they're massive. They're massive. That has to be addressed. And that's not sustainable at the current direction it had gone. This should have been done a long time ago. President Trump's finally done it.  And I think countries understand that this was different. If this was us targeting ten countries or five countries, then I would understand why countries would be upset. But the truth of the matter is we're resetting tariff levels with virtually every country in the world. And so I understand if you had a deal where you were running these huge trade deficits with the United States and exporting a lot to the U.S. and built your economy around exports,  but had very little import or very little economic activity coming in from the United States. I understand why you don't want that to change. But I think most mature leaders, and everybody here is a mature leader, understands that that's not a sustainable dynamic. It's one that had to be changed, and that's what the President's doing. So we're going to be okay.

summary.SPEAKER_01: Defends U.S. tariffs as a means to rectify decades-long unfair trade imbalances. Asserts that the tariffs are part of a global reset aimed at fairness for Americans and that countries will still trade with the U.S. Emphasises the magnitude of trade deficits and the unsustainability of the current trade dynamics.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses U.S. trade tariffs and their impact. SPEAKER_01 defends the tariffs as necessary to address unfair trade imbalances with various countries over the past 30-40 years, which have harmed American workers and industrial capacity. They argue that the U.S. is resetting global trade levels fairly and that countries will inevitably trade with multiple partners.

Because if you look at these amazing students, and do you notice, Don, we give the best tickets to our students? They should. Right? These are the warriors right here. lines.text: Listen, you get used to it, okay? So for me, it actually started less about just the hate. It was more about, you know, the cancel culture. And I was like, wow, like these people that I thought were friends for decades, they don't call anymore. Then when you won, they called. Oh, I love what you were doing. I was like, no, dude, I was reading your Facebook posts.  You're just trying to have the best of both worlds. It does take time, but I realized it was actually better even from a business standpoint.  to be a leader for a large group. If it was 50% of the country, it's like, wow, there's still something there, right? I'd rather be thought of by them as someone who's willing to have that conviction to fight for these things than be sort of agnostic to the general population. It was just another guy that was there. So it took a lot of time. I mean, it took a lot of loss.  hundreds of millions in business, not just on the sort of the lawfare side of things that we were fighting, but just people canceling as well. One person in a group of 100 doesn't like you, so we're just not going to go to your hotels. That was hard to get used to, but once you got used to it, you realized there's still hope, and what you're fighting for is so much more important in the grand scheme of things. I love what you do, and we've done, we did this in,  16 and 15. I've been doing it for 10 years.

video_title: 'It's Hard To Believe The Devastation': Trump Reacts To Survey Of Deadly Texas Flood Aftermath

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Well, this is a tough one. And we just we just were  making a little tour of the area. It's hard to believe the devastation. Trees that are 100 years old just ripped out of the ground. I've never seen anything like it. I've seen a lot of bad ones. I've gone to a lot of hurricanes, a lot of tornadoes. I've never seen anything like this. This is a this is a bad one. We just visited with incredible families that I mean, look, they've been devastated. They lost their child or two children and  Well, it's just hard to believe what — I've never seen anything like it — a little, narrow river that becomes a monster. And that's what happened. But the First Lady and I are here in Texas to express the love and support and the anguish of our entire nation in the aftermath of this really horrific and deadly flood. Nobody has any idea.  how and why a thing like this could happen. It's — and, by the way, I have to tell you, the people here — first responders, the sheriff's office, all of the police, law enforcement — they've done an unbelievable job.  And speaking to the parents, they said, everybody has been so professional, from the governor to the senators, all the way down to the local people on the site that really are a little bit used to this. But they've been looking at this for years, but in much smaller doses and a much, much smaller doses. Twelve years ago and then in 1932, they had a real bad one. But that bad one was half of what this was.  But I was speaking to some of the great people in the town, and they said, no, every year we get a little bit. But it was like a little bit of a flood, right? You were telling me. And it was just a flood. We got used to it. We had people, and we took care of it. And this year, it was like, what's going on, right? So all across the country, Americans' hearts are shattered. I had to be here as President. First Lady wanted to be here.  All the beautiful souls. And we're filled with grief and devastation. It's the loss of life. And unfortunately, they're still looking. They're still looking. There's a lot of missing children, possibly mostly. We don't know. But they're still looking. And they'll find everybody. But it's not an easy thing. You would think  It would be easy. It's very tough. I looked at what they're going through, what they have to do. But dozens and dozens of precious children taken from us with such. I looked at the pictures of almost all of them, and it's terrible. Following a torrential downpour, the worst that anyone's ever seen, Guadalupe River rose 26 feet in  less than 45 minutes. And I've even heard it went well over 30 feet. There's one story that one person said it had to be 60 feet at one moment. This is like a giant, giant wave in the Pacific Ocean that the best surfers in the world would be afraid to surf.  And it unleashed a catastrophic flooding, as the most — most residents were asleep in their beds. A very dark evening. The waters claimed at least 135, 140 lives. They're getting that count. But the count that they don't have is how many are still missing. But a lot of lives, a lot of young angels.

summary.Donald_Trump: The speaker expresses shock and grief at the severity of the flood in Texas, describing it as the worst he has ever seen. He emphasises the loss of life, particularly the many children who have died or are missing. He praises the first responders and local authorities for their professionalism and compassion. The speaker also notes the unprecedented nature of the flood, how quickly the river rose, and the devastation it caused, comparing it to a giant wave. He mentions previous floods in the area but emphasises that this one was much worse.

video_title: Fox reporter GRILLS Biden’s doctor

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: President Biden's former doctor, Kevin O'Connor, appeared on Capitol Hill yesterday for a highly anticipated House deposition on the possible cover-up of Joe Biden's declining health. But even though he was Biden's doctor for all four years of his presidency, the interview lasted less than one hour. O'Connor refused to talk. He pled the fifth over a dozen times.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Dr. O'Connor, were you ever told to lie about the president's health?  On the advice of counsel, I must respectfully decline to answer based upon physician-patient privilege and in reliance on my right under the Fifth Amendment of the Constitution. I am not a lawyer. I must follow my lawyer's advice in this matter. I must respectfully decline to answer based on the physician-patient privilege and in reliance on my right under the Fifth Amendment of the Constitution. On my right under the Fifth Amendment of the Constitution. On my right under the Fifth Amendment of the Constitution. On my right under the Fifth Amendment of the Constitution. On my right under the Fifth Amendment of the Constitution.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Our senior congressional correspondent Chad Pergrim chased the doctor down after his deposition and got similar results.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Well, I guess we're just on repeat today. Thank you very much for that. I did not know that Dwight Schrute was President Biden's physician for all four years. So exciting. Michael Scott is chief of staff and we're just finding out now. Yeah, I mean this is this is wholly unsurprising because  He has something to hide. It's very obvious. But the question is, you know, is this a congressional issue? Do you keep trying to put the screws to the guy because he's not going to answer a thing? Or, you know, I ask you, does this rise to the level of criminality? Should there be a criminal investigation of this doctor?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: And what happened?  Well, that would be separate from him pleading this. And that sort of, I think, begs that bigger question of, is there a difference between an inference and then the legal protection? So Lisa, to that point, the only Democrat in the room, Congresswoman Jasmine Crockett, said, oh, come on. You know, it's ridiculous that someone pleading the Fifth should  rise to the level of an assumption of covering up criminal behavior, right? And that's an admonition by judges in court. They specifically say, just because someone pleads the fifth, you cannot infer that. But at the end of the day, why aren't you saying anything if you don't have someone to hide? The argument goes. So here, the good doctor, why couldn't you even answer the question, did someone tell you to lie? Wouldn't you take the opportunity to even say in that deposition, let me set the record straight, no one told me to lie and plead the fifth otherwise?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Well, because he doesn't want to put Biden in a bad light, and he also doesn't want to perjure himself. Also, I would like to test Jasmine Crockett's mental acuity, so just her mental fitness. But beyond that, so the two key questions that the Oversight Committee were trying to get to and ask him, were you ever told a lie about the president's health, and did you ever believe President Biden was unfit to execute his duties? Pretty simple questions that he refused to answer.  Also, what's interesting is if you go back to 2019, Dr. Kevin O'Connor had told the public that Biden was being treated for an enlarged prostate, but he specifically said it wasn't prostate cancer. So was he lying to us then as well in 2019? Because you even have Democrats like Dr. Ezekiel Emanuel after the prostate cancer diagnosis who went on MSNBC telling us,  that Biden probably had cancer dating back to the start of his presidency in 2021. So I have questions about that. But I think we can all pretty much conclude that, you know, he's lying to us.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Right. And also, not to add in another layer, but all of the ethical malpractice questions, either you didn't test for prostate cancer or you did and then you lied to the patient, right? There's a whole host. The whole point is of a million questions that this good doctor needs to answer for and pleading the fifth in this particular proceedings, not going to cut it.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: It's hard, Emily, between what you just said, Lisa, and what you're pointing out, it's hard to get around these questions. Are you deficient as a physician? Did you fail the former president? Did you fail in the areas of testing, treatment? I mean, it's hard not to ask those questions when he pleads the fifth to something like this, and when we know the history of how long that enlarged prostate dates back to.  and what he had to say about it. And how did he know it wasn't cancer? Can we get that answer now? How did you make sure that it wasn't cancer back then? Look, Neera Tanden, one of the aides who's already testified in the auto-pin part of the investigation,  received one of these letters. And I want to point this out because this is what the House Oversight Committee said with her. In light of unique and extraordinary nature of these matters under investigation, President Trump has determined that an assertion of executive privilege is not in the national interest and therefore is not justified with respect to particular subjects within the purview of the House Oversight Committee.  That same waving of immunity was given to Dr. Kevin O'Connor. So my question is, when he says he can plead the fifth and patient doctor privilege, oh, yes, all that is true to a certain degree. But the White House has waived your immunity and cleared you to be able to talk. Why won't he answer questions?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: That's right, because Jeremy, so initially his attorney said, well, this is alarming and unprecedented, talking about the subpoena to have him come. And he said, it's privileged, and this is ridiculous. But the point is that what was alarming and unprecedented was the cover up of a declining Cryptkeeper president that led to massive destruction of our country's borders and lost lives at least of 13 service members. So the American people need answers. And it's not up to this kid to say whether or not he's underprivileged beforehand.  You go in, you give your answers, and then we'll decide. And then the administration will decide what the repercussions are.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Yeah, that's exactly right. I mean, we are, the American people are owed answers here. We have a right to know what happened. And his whole demeanor is almost as if, you know, he's just doing, you know, asking for some type of favor of him. You know, would you share a little bit about what happened? No, no, no.  We owe us answers. And I've been in the congressional hearings, you know, before we were a few years ago, we were talking about exposing the issues in the military under the Biden administration. And you take time to prepare. You know, you're going to get some questions from the people on the other side of the aisle. They're going to be tough questions. You prepare for those questions. He didn't even try.  I mean, didn't even try to even get out his own points or make any type of argument about what happened. And to your point, I mean, ask the very basic question about, were you told to lie? It couldn't even answer that. So I think what it does is adds more fuel to the fire. I do want to make sure that our Congress continues to carry this out. They can't take the foot off the gas now. They have to, because the next investigation, the next hearings that come up, we need to make sure that they don't try to do the same thing. They'll say, I plead the fifth and not say anything at all. Is this a precedent for what's to happen?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: So I hope that we continue to put the foot on the pedal and make sure that we actually get answers from this. That's right.

summary.SPEAKER_00: Agrees that the American people are owed answers and highlights O'Connor's evasive behaviour and lack of preparation. Suggests that his pleading the fifth sets a bad precedent and that Congress should continue to pursue the investigation to ensure transparency.
summary.SPEAKER_01: Expresses frustration with O'Connor's refusal to answer basic questions, such as whether he was told to lie about the President's health. Questions O'Connor's competence as a physician and suggests that his demeanor and lack of preparation add to the suspicion that he is hiding something.
summary.SPEAKER_02: Chased O'Connor down after the deposition and noted that he received similar non-answers. The speaker suggests that O'Connor's pleading the fifth implies he has something to hide but acknowledges the legal principle that it cannot be inferred as guilt.
summary.SPEAKER_03: O'Connor's deposition was brief as he pled the fifth over a dozen times. The speaker questions the validity of pleading the fifth when executive privilege has been waived and suggests there are ethical malpractice questions surrounding O'Connor's handling of Biden's health information, particularly regarding his prostate treatment.
summary.SPEAKER_04: Argues that O'Connor's pleading the fifth is a clear indication of a cover-up and questions why he wouldn't answer simple questions to clear his name. Suggests that there should be a criminal investigation and raises doubts about the accuracy of previous health disclosures made by O'Connor.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses President Biden's former doctor Kevin O'Connor's House deposition where he repeatedly pled the fifth amendment regarding questions about Biden's health. The speakers debate the implications of his pleading, with some arguing it suggests a cover-up while others emphasise that pleading the fifth does not imply guilt.

lines.text: But I got to disagree with you, Harold. Men don't want to be lifted up. We want to be left alone. We don't want to be pandered to.
