We do play too much identity politics, but men certainly don't want to be belittled.  Men want, like, women want as well. Good jobs. Men want their boys and their girls to be raised in safe communities and safe houses. I mean, I agree with you. I think those are two different points.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Yeah, we don't all men want to be left alone, Greg. I mean, we like to be given attention once in a while. She's right there, Jesse. Look at Jesse's hair. You know he wants it.  And that was really smart what you just said, Harold. We'd like to hear more of that coming from you.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Good job.

summary.SPEAKER_00: Argues that the Democratic Party has a long history of neglecting men, focussing solely on women's issues from the Obama administration onwards. He believes this exclusionary approach has built up resentment among men and that the Democrats need to address this to win back male voters.
summary.SPEAKER_01: Does not contribute significantly to the main discussion points. Their comments are mostly light-hearted or tangential.
summary.SPEAKER_02: Argues that the Democratic Party has actively rejected and vilified men, creating an environment where masculinity is seen as toxic. He asserts that Trump and the GOP respected masculinity and protected biological women, appealing to male voters. He believes the Democrats need to stop belittling men and recognise the concerns of parents about their children's futures.
summary.SPEAKER_03: Suggests that men generally want to be left alone and not pandered to by politicians. However, they also acknowledge that men value attention and respect. She questions the notion that all men want to be isolated and emphasises the importance of balanced representation and understanding.
summary.SPEAKER_04: Agrees that the Democratic Party has a problem with alienating men but emphasises that men don't want to be lifted up or pandered to; they want to be left alone. He argues that the Democrats' approach to identity politics has been divisive and that they need to shift their focus to addressing the concerns of all voters, regardless of gender. He believes that things can change in politics and that the Democrats can win back male voters if they remember to respect and value men.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the perceived alienation of men by the Democratic Party, suggesting this has led to a political shift. The speakers argue that the Democrats have ignored, vilified, and excluded men, focusing excessively on women's issues and identity politics. They believe this has created a backlash and that the Democrats need to change their approach to win back male voters.

video_title: ‘WE'RE NOT STOPPING’: Homan on looking for ‘every single criminal threat’ in US

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: All right, back to the breaking news that we brought you earlier this hour. ICE agents arrested an MS-13 kingpin in Nebraska. He has now been identified as Melvin Varela-Perez. He has been on El Salvador's most wanted list for nearly a decade, but was somehow released into the United States after he crossed the border illegally in 2023. Let's bring in White House Border Czar Tom Hullett.  Tom, let me just put up the record here of this guy that somehow got missed. First of all, here's the mugshot from his arrest in Oklahoma.  Now here is the, or Omaha, Nebraska, I'm sorry. Here is the picture from 2016. This was put out by the national police. He's on the top 100, Los 100 Mas Buscados. Then here's another notice from 2019 looking for the same guy and another one from 2019 that was put out by Crimestoppers looking for this guy. And yet somehow Tom, when he came across the border illegally in 2023,  He was paroled into the country. How in the world could that have happened?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Well, look, this is just one example of what I've been saying for the last four years. The Biden administration lied to the American people. When they said everybody they released in the country is property vetted, they weren't.  No, first of all, we don't have access to other countries' criminal data, but as you said, this was the public information, and this has been easily found. But this administration, their main focus under Biden administration, Borbatto had one directive, process quick,  release quick. Because if there's no overcrowding, we can keep claiming the border is secure and we got control of everything. And they kept lying to the American people. Everybody releases is vetted. I can't tell you how many criminals under the Trump administration we have arrested and deported that were released in the country by Joe Biden saying they were vetted. We have arrested murderers, people that were convicted of murder in other countries. People had murder warrants in other countries. People had sexual assaults in other countries. People had sexual assaults here.  that they weren't found during the vetting process because they weren't vetted. The last administration lied and that's why we're so busy right now going across the country trying to find these people.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: All right. So I could go you one better on this, Melvin Varela Perez. So he was nailed in Omaha with another guy named Rene Escobar Ochoa. We'll put his picture up on the screen for you. This guy had an Interpol red notice against him for drug trafficking and conspiracy to commit murder. He had an Interpol notice against him and that got missed. How does that happen?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: incompetence. I mean, it incumbents from last administration, their directive, to how border patrol process releases without proper vetting. And also, let's remember, ICE was told by Secretary Mayorkas, you can't arrest someone for being here illegally. They probably won't even look at this person unless you had a serious criminal conviction.  not a warrant, not a want, but a conviction. So look, the last administration, they totally screwed it up from releasing people from the border for non-vetting to tying ISIS hands. We had a record number, 10.5 million illegal aliens come to our border and Joe Biden, ICE had the lowest numbers of arrests and removals in the history of the agency because their hands were tied. And that's why we're working so hard under President Trump  Under his leadership, we're working so hard right now, sending as many teams out in the communities as possible to look for these criminals that the last administration released in this country. And that's why we're so busy right now, and that's why you see all the teams out in every major city in the nation.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: All right. Mark Zito is the special aide in charge of the Kansas city Homeland security investigations. Here's what he said about these arrests. He said, quote, these illegal aliens didn't just sneak into our country. They brought with them a legacy of violence, terror, and death. They thought they could hide in America's heartland, but they were sadly mistaken, not on our watch. So two things falling out of that. First of all,  These two guys, this is the worst of the worst. How many more like them got into this country? Do we know? And secondly, you're going after these bad guys. And again, these are the worst of the worst. International Interpol read notices, top 100 most wanted in El Salvador. And yet ICE and border patrol agents are being attacked for trying to get these guys off the streets. Comment on both those things, if you would.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Well, first of all, how many? I know that we got at least 600,000 illegal aliens in this country with criminal records walking the streets of this country. As far as how many criminals and national security threats that Biden administration released in the country, we don't have a clear number on that. We got over 2 million known got away.  Two million people crossed the border under Biden, weren't arrested, weren't vetted, weren't fingerprinted. They got away because the border patrol so overwhelmed that humanitarian crisis. So we don't have a number. And that's why we're working so hard with the intelligence community and FBI, ICE. We're all working together trying to find these people.  And look, this is why I'm proud to be a part of this administration. President Trump has given the leadership that we're not going to zero tolerance. We're out there looking for every single criminal threat and national security threat we can find in this nation. As far as the hate, it's because the media is lying to the American people. They keep talking about ICE raiding schools, ICE raiding churches, which isn't happening.  We are focusing on the public safety threats. The men and women always put their lives on the line every day for this nation. They're American heroes. But I knew from day one, we talked about this, John. From day one, I said they're going to vilify ICE. They're going to vilify the Border Patrol because they don't want President Trump to be successful. They hate Trump more than they love their communities. They hate Trump more than they want law enforcement. But we're not giving up to them. We're going to be out there every damn day across this nation with over a thousand teams looking for these people every single day. We're not stopping.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Well, I'll tell you, Tom, the fact that two guys like this got into the country undetected, now they're out the streets, that's good. But the fact that they got in and there could be more, that is truly frightening. Tom Homan for us from the White House. Tom, thank you so much. Appreciate it. Thank you.

summary.SPEAKER_00: The host questions how two high-profile criminals, one with an Interpol red notice and the other on El Salvador's most wanted list, were released into the U.S. after crossing the border illegally. He emphasises the severity of the situation, raising concerns about public safety and the potential presence of more such individuals in the country.
summary.SPEAKER_01: Tom Hullett blames the Biden administration for incompetence and prioritising quick processing and release of illegal immigrants over proper vetting. He claims that the administration's policies have led to the release of numerous criminals into the country, undermining public safety. Hullett also criticises media portrayal of ICE and emphasises their efforts to track down and arrest these individuals.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the arrest of two illegal immigrants in Nebraska, Melvin Varela-Perez and Rene Escobar Ochoa, highlighting failures in the U.S. border vetting system. It underscores concerns about the potential release of numerous other criminals and national security threats into the country due to inadequate vetting processes and policy directives.

video_title: This ‘validates’ possible involvement in ‘coverup,' says GOP rep

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: House physician to Presidents Trump and Obama. He also served in the White House Medical Unit under President Bush. So he understands the role of White House physician probably better than anybody else around. Congressman Jackson, thank you very much for joining us today. So what goes through your mind with your experience as you watch him refuse to answer those questions?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, Martha, I think he's in a bad spot. You know, he tried initially to go with the presidential privilege and say he had presidential privilege, and President Trump waived that, opening up his opportunity to testify there. Then he went to the doctor-patient privilege.  And that was forwarded to the committee. The committee looked at that and they agreed with HIPAA and with the AMA that you can be legally compelled to discuss conversations between the doctor and the patient, the doctor can, under the right legal circumstances. And certainly a congressional subpoena fits that bill. So he was kind of left with nothing but the Fifth Amendment, pleading the Fifth. And that's what he did. He pleaded the Fifth. And I think it was an effort to keep from implicating himself in what we, and I think it actually,  To me, it looks like this actually happened, that there was a cover-up. This kind of validates that. And it almost certainly indicates that Dr. O'Connor was actively involved in it. So it's a bad situation. I think the American people deserve answers at this point. And we talked about this before. I've talked about this on Fox a lot lately. This is not about looking back and going back and digging into the past. This is about what happened. Did we have people in the White House that were unelected officials that were acting as the president?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Yeah, I mean, it's a great question, and there's a lot of questions about this auto pen. His staff has said that he approved any time that the auto pen was used. We know many presidents use the auto pen, but it just raises a lot of questions. Congressman Jackson, we've got some breaking news, so I'm going to have to leave it there, but thank you very much. Great to have you with us, as always.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Hey, Sean Hannity here. Hey, click here to subscribe to Fox News' YouTube page and catch our hottest interviews and most compelling analysis. You will not get it anywhere else.

summary.SPEAKER_00: The host introduces the topic of a former White House physician's testimony and raises questions about his refusal to answer certain questions.
summary.SPEAKER_01: This speaker is Sean Hannity who provides a brief closing statement promoting Fox News' YouTube page.
summary.SPEAKER_02: The Congressman believes the physician pleaded the Fifth to avoid implicating himself in a cover-up involving the White House and West Wing staff. He argues that doctor-patient privilege does not apply in this case and that the American people deserve answers. The Congressman also suggests that the use of an auto-pen by the President raises further questions.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses a former White House physician's testimony, where he pleaded the Fifth, suggesting a potential cover-up involving unelected officials acting as the president.

video_title: ‘EPIC FAILURE’: 6 agents tasked with protecting Trump during assassination attempt suspended

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Joining me now, former FBI special agent Nicole Parker, a Fox News contributor. Nicole, welcome. Great to have you with us today. You know, I go to this quote, which I think of everything I looked back at today in this story really says it all. Let's put this up on the screen.  A Senate briefing later revealed that Secret Service agents first spotted the gunman on the rooftop 10 minutes before Trump took the stage and 20 minutes before, 20 minutes, that's a really long time, before he opened fire. So they spotted someone on the roof 10 minutes before Trump took the stage and 20 minutes before he started shooting. What goes through your mind as you look back on all this, Nicole?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: As a former FBI special agent, when I hear that, it literally makes my blood boil. It is entirely inappropriate, unacceptable, and that was an epic and colossal failure. And I am so grateful that under this current administration, the Secret Service has taken full ownership of this.  I am so grateful that there is a new Secret Service director, Sean Curran, who was on the stage, actually put his life on the line for President Trump. That's what real leadership does. But, on that day, July 13, like we said, we all remember where we were. It was absolutely stunning. And it was terrifying. And that should never, ever happen in our country. But, again, we go back to the employees, the six suspended employees.  Incompetency, laziness and complacency is what it comes down to, in my opinion. And I think under the former leadership of the Secret Service, that director was focused on the wrong things. They need to be laser focused. Your number one priority as a Secret Service agent  is keeping your protectees safe and making sure that they go home alive and are safe and unharmed every single day. You are expected to put your life on the line and do that. And I understand, with these suspensions, there were people that were five members from the Pittsburgh field office, from the Secret Service, and there was actually an individual who was on the advance team from Trump's protective detail team, who was not on the stage, but was part of his protective detail team. And what I appreciate now is that there must be accountability.  My deepest sympathies go out to Helen, Cory's wife. I mean, that's heartbreaking, as an agent, to have to go through that and to tell a wife, yes, we failed. She deserves answers. She deserves to know what happened. The country deserves to know. President Trump deserves to know.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: And I hope that's coming.  Yeah, I mean, it really is. It's so shocking. I mean, you know, every American should be grateful that we didn't lose a former president at that time, a candidate, and now the current president of the United States on that day. I mean, it was an absolutely unbelievable day. And it just I keep going back to the fact that they knew for 10 minutes that there was someone on the roof. It would have just been like, OK, hold the president over there. Let's wait till we clear the roof. And the whole thing would have been completely different. And I understand, Helen, when she says they should have been fired.  Do you think they should have been fired?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Look, I know how OPR works, Office of Professional Responsibility at the federal government, and it's basically internal investigations against agents and employees, and they do a full investigation. They're the ones that make the decisions at the end of the day. We call it, you know, they were 10 to 42 days on the bricks. Leave without pay. But again, I believe that there should be stiffer consequences than that. I mean, there is a dead civilian, and President Trump is alive only because of the grace of God.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: And two injured, people who were very, very injured that day.  I just want to play really quickly just to this is Selena Zito talking about her conversation. She was there covering it that day and then she spoke with President Trump right afterwards. And here's what he said. Watch.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: I thought it was important to just listen, just let him get there. And so we talked a lot about God. We talked a lot about purpose.  God, in that moment, he's kept saying, Selina, why'd I turn my head? Why'd I put that chart down? Why'd I turn my head? I believe I have purpose. I think this was the hand of God in this moment. Quick thought on that, Nicole, before I let you go.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: It gives me the chills because I agree 100%. By the grace of God, President Trump is still with us today.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Nicole Parker, thank you very much.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Always good to have you with us.

summary.SPEAKER_01: Nicole Parker, the former FBI special agent, condemns the Secret Service failure as epic and colossal. She attributes it to incompetency, laziness, and complacency under former leadership. Parker emphasises the need for accountability, highlighting the six suspended employees. She believes stiffer consequences are warranted due to the death of a civilian and the grave risk to Trump's life. Parker also expresses sympathy for the fallen agent's wife and stresses the country's deserve for answers.
summary.SPEAKER_03: The host expresses shock and gratitude that no one more prominent was lost. He questions why the President wasn't held back when the gunman was spotted and suggests the suspended agents should have been fired. The host also plays a clip of Selena Zito talking to Trump after the incident, where Trump reflects on why he turned his head at the crucial moment, believing it was God's hand keeping him safe.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses a failed Secret Service operation where a gunman was spotted on a rooftop 20 minutes before opening fire on former President Trump. The focus is on the incompetence of the suspended agents, the need for accountability, and the gratitude that Trump survived by what many believe was divine intervention.

They also make light-hearted comments and engage in the humorous banter of the show.
summary.SPEAKER_03: Expresses concern that Kamala Harris would be worse than Biden and questions the lengths the government and media have gone to cover up Biden's alleged cognitive impairment.
summary.SPEAKER_04: The main host leads the conversation, humourously yet critically discussing various political topics. He focusses on Joe Biden's health, suggesting there is a cover-up regarding his true condition. He questions the doctor's testimony, the media's role, and implies that the deep state is running the administration. The host also makes jokes about current events, political figures, and uses sarcasm to express his views on the perceived lack of transparency and accountability.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses Joe Biden's former doctor's testimony before Congress where he pleaded the Fifth Amendment to all questions regarding Biden's health. The speakers criticise the doctor, the Biden administration, and the media for alleged cover-ups and lack of transparency. They debate the importance of medical privacy versus the public's right to know about the fitness of their leader, and express scepticism about Biden's cognitive abilities and the handling of his health information.

summary.SPEAKER_01: Agrees with the notion that women often lack confidence until later in life but criticises generalisations. She finds statements about women being invisible at 50 dismissive and highlights that confidence varies widely among individuals regardless of gender or age.
summary.SPEAKER_02: Dismisses the idea that men are inherently more confident. She argues that confidence is something everyone works on and that insecurity is universal. She criticises both Michelle Obama and James Carville for their statements and finds their opinions outdated or repetitive.
summary.SPEAKER_03: Starts the conversation by criticising the Democratic Party and Michelle Obama. He makes derogatory remarks about women and suggests that the media perpetuates negative stereotypes about men. He also promotes his book and engages in personal attacks and off-topic remarks.
summary.SPEAKER_04: Expresses frustration with what he perceives as anti-male sentiment in the media, particularly on NPR. He feels that men are marginalised and their voices ignored due to the emphasis on women's issues.
summary.Unidentified SPEAKER: Joins in the criticism of Michelle Obama and agrees that her statements about confidence are dismissive. However, their comments are limited and lack specific details.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation is a critique of various political and social figures, particularly Michelle Obama and James Carville, with discussions on gender, confidence, and media representation. The speakers express dissatisfaction with perceived gender biases and the state of political discourse.
